wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Fingerprint
Fingerprint belongs to the type SFTP Client , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: To guarantee that the controller connects to the expected SFTP server, and not a malicious server, a server fingerprint can be used.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Fingerprint is set to another value than the default value (only zeros), the fingerprint value from the SFTP server must match this value. If the fingerprint does not match, it will not be possible to connect to the SFTP server.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Fingerprint is used only with the RobotWare option FTP & SFTP Client .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: 20 two-digit hexadecimal numbers, separated by colon.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
, section SFTP Client .

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Syslog, type This section describes the type Syslog which belongs to the topic Communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The type Syslog contains parameters to enable forwarding of log events to a remote syslog server.
If a Server address and a Server port number are defined, syslog event messages can be sent to a remote syslog server using the transport protocol UDP.
The parameter Protocol cannot be modified.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: A syslog entry is written with the following format:
The message corresponds to:

paragraph.phrase: <event text>|<extra info>|<event id>|<sequence no>|<source>|<product name>|<user name>

wrapper.paragraph: In its entirety, a syslog entry will have the following format:

paragraph.phrase: <priority>timestamp hostname application:<event text>|<extra info>|<event id>|<sequence no>|<source>|<product name>|<user name>

wrapper.paragraph: Sample events logged in the Syslog

listitem.paragraph: User login successful
User login failed, unknown user
User login failed, incorrect password
User login failed 3 consecutive attempts
User logout
Configuration uploaded
System parameters changed successfully
Software updated successfully
Software failed unsuccessfully
Control system restarted
System time updated manually
Previous configuration successfully restored

wrapper.title: Example 1
wrapper.paragraph: A sample of the syslog message generated when a user logs in:

wrapper.title: Example 2
wrapper.paragraph: A sample of the syslog message generated when a user logs out:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Server address belongs to the type
Syslog
, in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Server address specifies the IP address of the remote syslog server.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string consisting of 4 integer values between 0 and 255, each specifying one of the four parts, separated by dots.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: An IP address consists of four parts, each with eight bits, separated by dots.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Server port number belongs to the type
Syslog
, in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Server port number specifies the port number on the network node identified by Server address .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer value between 0 and 65535.
The default port number for syslog events is 514.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Enabled belongs to the type Syslog , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: This defines if the transfer to the syslog server is turned on or off.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is No .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type UDP Unicast Device which belongs to the topic Communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: UDP Unicast Device, type The type UDP Unicast Device (UdpUc) is a generic device type, that can be used by different applications.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type UDP Unicast Device , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name specifies the name of the UDP Unicast Device instance.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 16 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Type belongs to the type UDP Unicast Device , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Type defines the type of UDP Unicast Device protocol to be used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The only available UDP Unicast Device type is UDPUC .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Remote Address belongs to the type UDP Unicast Device , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Remote Address specifies the IP address of the external device, for example, sensor.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string consisting of 4 integer values between 0 and 255, each specifying one of the four parts, separated by dots.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: An IP address consists of four parts, each with eight bits, separated by dots.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Remote port number belongs to the type UDP Unicast Device , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Remote port number specifies the port number on the network node identified by Remote Address .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer value between 0 and 65535.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Local port number belongs to the type UDP Unicast Device , in the topic Communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Local port number specifies the port number on which the controller will listen for broadcast messages.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer value between 0 and 65535.
0 means that the controller software itself selects an available port number.
The local port number cannot be 6510, since this is reserved for the remote port.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This chapter describes the types and parameters of the Controller topic. Each parameter is described in the section for its type.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph:
The controller, topic
Controller topic contains parameters for safety and RAPID specific functions.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Safety in program execution is essential. The function hold-to-run control is used when extra safety is necessary in the operating mode Manual. The hold-to-run function only allows robot movements when a button is manually actuated and immediately stops these movements when released.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The hold-to-run control is always activated in Manual Full Speed mode.

wrapper.title: How to activate the hold-to-run control
wrapper.paragraph: To activate the hold-to-run control for manual reduced speed mode:

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller topic, choose the type Operator Safety . For more information, see The Operator Safety type.
Edit the parameters for robot movement control and execution. Set the parameter Active to True.
For detailed information about the parameters, see the descriptions in the Operator Safety type.
Save the changes.

section.title: How to define path return region

wrapper.title: Return movement
wrapper.paragraph: A return movement must take place if the current robot path deviates from the programmed path. This happens for example if an uncontrolled stop has occurred or the robot has been jogged away from its path. A return movement begins when program start is ordered and stops before the program continues with the instruction that was interrupted.

wrapper.title: Path return region
wrapper.paragraph: In a return movement, the path return region specifies the distance from the current robot position to the last executed path. The maximum path return region can be set both for start in manual mode and for start in automatic mode. For more information, see The Path Return Region type.

wrapper.title: How to define path return region
wrapper.paragraph: To define the path return region:

listitem.paragraph: In the Controller topic, choose the type Path Return Region .
Edit the Mode parameter to specify the operating mode.
Edit the parameters for movement in the selected mode. For detailed information about each parameter, see the descriptions in the type Path Return Region .
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Input I/O signals can be assigned specific system inputs. The input triggers a system action that is handled by the system, without using the FlexPendant or other hardware devices.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input I/O signal with a defined signal name has to be configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following limitations have to be considered:

listitem.paragraph: Only one system action can be assigned to the input I/O signal. However, several input I/O signals can be assigned the same system action.
When deleting a system action, the I/O signal itself remains defined. The I/O signal has to be deleted separately.

System input I/O signals are only valid for the currently executed program in the system, with exceptions on the action value level. These exceptions are described together with the corresponding action value.
The system must be in automatic mode to react on the system signal.

wrapper.title: How to define system inputs
wrapper.paragraph: To define a system input:

listitem.paragraph: In the topic Controller , choose the type System Input .
Select the system input to change, delete, or add a new one.
Enter, change, or delete the values for the parameters.
Save the changes.
Restart the controller.

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see The System Input type and The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Rejected system inputs
wrapper.paragraph: If the system is in manual mode or cannot perform the defined system action due to any other unfulfilled requirement, no error message is displayed. When a system action is rejected the error message is stored in the error log (ELOG).

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Output I/O signals can be assigned specific system outputs. The output triggers a system action that is handled by the system, without using the FlexPendant or other hardware devices.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital output I/O signal with a defined signal name has to be configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following limitations have to be considered:

listitem.paragraph: Only one system action can be assigned to the output I/O signal. However, several output I/O signals can be assigned the same system action.
When deleting a system action, the I/O signal itself remains defined. The I/O signal has to be deleted separately.

System output I/O signals are only valid for the currently executed program in the system, with exceptions on the action value level. These exceptions are described together with the corresponding action value.
The system must be in automatic mode to react on the system signal.

wrapper.title: How to define system outputs
wrapper.paragraph: To define a system output:

listitem.paragraph: In the topic Controller , choose the type System Input .
Select the system output to change, delete, or add a new one.
Enter, change, or delete the values for the parameters.
Save the changes.
Restart the controller.

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see The System output type.

wrapper.title: Rejected system outputs
wrapper.paragraph: If the system is in manual mode or cannot perform the defined system action due to any other unfulfilled requirement, no error message is displayed. When a system action is rejected the error message is stored in the error log (ELOG).

section.title:
The Auto Condition Reset type
Auto Condition Reset, type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Auto Condition Reset , which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The type Auto Condition Reset defines if a number of conditions should be reset when switching to auto mode.
A message box is displayed on the FlexPendant with information about the reset conditions.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one instance of the type Auto Condition Reset .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Auto Condition Reset , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: AllDebugSettings (cannot be changed).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Reset belongs to the type Auto Condition Reset , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Reset defines if a number of conditions should be reset when switching to auto mode.
If any of the conditions cannot be executed, then switching to auto will be rejected. The Reset setting is also applied when starting the controller in auto mode.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Reset is set to YES then the following conditions are reset when switching to auto:

listitem.paragraph: The Program Pointer (PP) is set to Main module for all tasks if callchain does not originate from Main routine.
All tasks are enabled.
All stopped background tasks are started.
Simulation of all simulated I/O signals is removed.
Speed is set to 100%.
RAPID Spy is deactivated.

wrapper.paragraph: If Reset is set to NO, then none of the above conditions are reset automatically.
If a service routine is running and PP was manually moved to another routine before the service routine was called, then the above does not apply. Switching to auto will then be rejected.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is YES.

section.title: The Automatic Loading of Modules type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Automatic Loading of Modules which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID modules can be loaded automatically when the controller is restarted if they are specified in the type Automatic Loading of Modules .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: There must be one instance of the type Automatic Loading of Modules for each of the module to be loaded.

wrapper.title: System restart
wrapper.paragraph: All changes in the type Automatic Loading of Modules will take effect after a normal restart or using the restart mode Reset RAPID.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If the configuration module is changed, it may in one case (see below) replace the loaded module after a normal restart. In any other case, you will get a warning. To replace the loaded module regardless of task type, restart using the restart mode Reset RAPID. For more information, see The Task type.
The configuration module replaces the loaded module if the:

listitem.paragraph: loaded module is a program module AND
the task is semistatic.

wrapper.paragraph: The program pointer is only lost if a configuration change results in unloading of the module that the program pointer is in. If a shared or installed module is changed from True to False, or is moved to another task, the task will be reinstalled and the program pointer is reset. All previously loaded modules are reloaded and unsaved changes will not be lost.
If a changed and unsaved user-loaded module is unloaded due to configuration changes, it will be saved to a recovery directory and pointed out in an ELOG message.
If a changed and unsaved configuration loaded module is unloaded due to configuration changes, it will be saved from where it was loaded.

All tasks are reinstalled with modules according to the configuration after a restart using the restart mode Reset RAPID. Note that after using the restart mode Reset RAPID, all user-loaded modules are lost.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
ELOG messages are described in
Technical reference manual Event logs for RobotWare 7

Restarts are described in
Operating manual OmniCore

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: File belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter File describes a path to the module file.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The module file shall contain one module to be loaded, installed, or shared.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A path, for example, HOME:MyModule.modx

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Task belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Task is the symbolic name of the task to which the module will be loaded.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The task is defined in the type Task .
The available task(s) is shown under the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with All Tasks , All Motion Tasks , or Shared . For more information, see The Task type, All Tasks, and Shared.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A task name with maximum 30 characters.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: All automatically loaded modules need information on which task they will be loaded or installed in, even if only one task is configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Installed belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: A module can be installed or loaded. A loaded module is visible in remote clients, for example, RobotStudio and FlexPendant. An installed module is not visible, that is, it does not occur in the list of modules. For more information, see All Tasks.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Installed to Yes to install a module, and to No to load a module.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Shared .
For more information, see Shared.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
The default value is No.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: To remove an installed module, the parameter Installed must be set to No and restart the system.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Shared belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: It is possible to install the module (and all its objects) as shared so it is reachable from all the tasks.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If a module should be reachable from any task, set the parameter Shared to YES. This installs the module to the system internal shared task, not visible from any user interface or in the configuration. All data in the module is then shared (that is the same) for all tasks.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Task, All Tasks , All Motion Tasks , or Installed . For more information, see All Tasks, Task, and Installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
Default value is No.

td.paragraph: The module is installed shared. Module data is shared between all tasks.
The module is installed and only available from the named task.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: All Tasks belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The All Tasks module will be loaded or installed in all the tasks available in the system.
Note that there can be more tasks available in the system than can be seen, that is, tasks with Type defined as STATIC or SEMISTATIC, or Hidden defined as YES.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The tasks are defined in the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Task, All Motion Tasks, or Shared . For more information, see Task, Shared, and The Task type.
A module with All Motion Tasks set to Yes can only contain the code possible to run in any motion task in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is No.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If All Tasks is set to Yes and Installed is set to Yes then the module is installed in each task as a separate module. That is, the module data is not shared between the tasks (as opposed to if the module is installed shared).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: All Motion Tasks belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The All Motion Tasks module will be loaded or installed in all motion tasks available in the system.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The tasks are defined in the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Task , Shared , or All Tasks . For more information, see Task, Shared, and The Task.
A module with All Motion Tasks set to Yes can only contain the code possible to run in any motion task in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
The default value is NO.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If All Motion Tasks is set to Yes and Installed is set to Yes then the module is installed in each motion task as a separate module. That is, module data is not shared between the tasks (as opposed to if the module is installed shared).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Hidden belongs to the type Automatic Loading of Modules , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID modules, routines and data may be hidden, which may be used to prevent inexperienced end users from tampering (accidentally deleting or changing) with the contents.
Note that the hidden contents is not protected! It can easily be shown again by setting the parameter value to NO.
Note that any hidden contents will still be available when using the SetDataSearch instruction to search RAPID data.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter affects only modules, routines, and data that are loaded automatically on start, that is no programs etc. that are loaded by the operator once the system has been started.
Changes to the parameter will be effective only after using the restart mode Reset RAPID.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
Default value is NO.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Cyclic Bool Settings which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The type Cyclic Bool Settings defines the behavior of the cyclic bool functionality.

wrapper.title: System restart
wrapper.paragraph: All changes in the type Cyclic Bool Settings will take effect after a normal restart, or using the restart mode Reset RAPID.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Cyclic Bool Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the cyclic bool setting.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one instance of each allowed value, that is a maximum of three instances in the system. All three instances will be installed in the system (by default) and cannot be removed.

td.paragraph: Defines if connected cyclic bool is to be removed when setting PP to Main
Defines which error mode to use when evaluation fails
Defines which recovery mode to use when evaluation fails

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Value belongs to the type Cyclic bool setting , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the cyclic bool values for the value defined in parameter Name . For more information, see Name.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The allowed values depend on the parameter Name , and are described on the following pages:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: ErrorMode is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type Cyclic Bool Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value ErrorMode is used to configure how to handle failure when evaluating a connected cyclic bool.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The behavior can only be configured for all tasks that is, the behavior cannot be different from one task to another.

td.paragraph: Stop RAPID execution and produce error log if evaluation of cyclic bool fails.
Produce warning log if evaluation of cyclic bool fails.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RecoveryMode is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type Cyclic Bool Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value RecoveryMode is used to configure if to recover a failing connected cyclic bool or not.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The behavior can only be configured for all tasks that is, the behavior cannot be different from one task to another.
It cannot be disabled if action value ErrorMode is set to value SysStopError .

td.paragraph: Try to recover when evaluation fails.
Remove cyclic bool that fails during evaluation.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RemoveAtPpToMain is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type Cyclic Bool Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value RemoveAtPpToMain is used to configure if a connected cyclic bool shall be removed or not, when PP is set to Main.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The behavior can only be configured for all tasks that is, the behavior cannot be different from one task to another.

td.paragraph: Remove all connected cyclic bool setting PP to Main.
Do not remove all connected cyclic bool when setting PP to Main

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Event Routine which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type event routine, type
Event Routine contains parameters for event handling. Special system events, such as program stop, can be connected to a RAPID routine. When the event occurs, the connected event routine is executed automatically.
An event routine is made up of one or more instructions. The routine runs in the task specified in parameter Task or All Tasks . For more information, see The Task type.
The RAPID code in the event routine shall be written in such a way that it is executed as fast as possible without any delay.
The tasks available are dependent on the type Tasks .

wrapper.title: Event routines
wrapper.paragraph: The following event routines are available:
Event routines can be started for one or many tasks.
A stopped event routine will continue from where it was stopped when pressing the start button on the FlexPendant or when calling the start command via a system I/O.

Pressing the stop button when the Stop event routine is executing does not generate a new Stop event. However, if a problem has occured in the event routine then pressing the stop button will force the execution to leave the event routine after 10 seconds.
The only way to cancel a stopped event routine from system I/O is to start the program from main.

A Stop instruction (without the optional argument -All) or a Break instruction in an event routine will stop the program execution. This means that instructions after the Stop or Break instruction will never be executed. See Example.

wrapper.title: Event routine execution examples
wrapper.paragraph: The following is an illustration of the sample code that is shown below it. The examples that follow show which event routines are executed for the various buttons pressed on the FlexPendant.
PROC main()
MoveJ p20, v100, fine, tool0;
MoveJ p10, v100, fine, tool0;
ENDPROC

wrapper.title: Example 1
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure shows that the START, STOP, and RESTART event routines are executed when the Start and Stop buttons are pressed on the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Example 2
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure shows that the START, STOP, and RESTART event routines are executed when the Start, Stop, and Step buttons are pressed on the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Example 3
wrapper.paragraph: The following procedure shows that the START, STOP, and STEP event routines are executed when the Step and Stop buttons are pressed on the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: System restart
wrapper.paragraph: Any changes in configuration of event routines are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Example 1
wrapper.paragraph: This example illustrates the consequences after a Stop instruction in a routine.
At restart mydo will be set to 1. mydo will never be set to 0 since the execution stops after the stop instruction.
The instruction TPWrite will never be executed because myexample2 has sequence number (SeqNo) 1.
MODULE example(SYSMODULE)
PROC myexample1()
SetDO mydo, 1;
Stop;
SetDO mydo, 0;
ENDPROC
PROC myexample2()
TPWrite "This is an example";
ENDPROC
ENDMODULE
CAB_EXEC_HOOKS:
-Routine "myexample1" -Shelf "RESTART"
-Routine "myexample2" -Shelf "RESTART" -SeqNo 1

wrapper.title: Example 2
wrapper.paragraph: This example illustrates how to use the same routine for both Start and Step events.
MODULE example(SYSMODULE)
PROC myexample2()
TEST RunMode()
CASE RUN_CONT_CYCLE:
! PLAY button pressed
CASE RUN_INSTR_FWD:
! FORWARD STEP button pressed
CASE RUN_INSTR_BWD:
! BACKWARD STEP button pressed
ENDTEST
ENDPROC
ENDMODULE
CAB_EXEC_HOOKS:
-Routine "myexample2" -Shelf "START"
-Routine "myexample2" -Shelf "STEP"

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.

Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
. The function EventType can be useful.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Routine belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Routine specifies which routine that should be run for an event.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Define the routine to be assigned to a system event.
It is advisable to use a routine in a system module.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The specified routine must be a procedure without any parameters.
The event Reset requires a routine in a system module.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining a routine.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Event belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Event specifies which system event in the robot system the routine should run.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
A system event can trigger a corresponding routine to be run, see
Operating manual OmniCore
.
It is advisable to keep the routines short and quick.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following limitations should be considered:

listitem.paragraph: The events are not activated when executing a routine manually, for example, a service routine.

A maximum of 20 routines may be specified for each system event and each task (multitasking). The same routine can be used in more than one event (e.g. the same routine can be run for both Start and Restart).
The specified event routine cannot be executed if the task program has semantic errors (reference errors and so on). If this is the case, the system generates an error.

Only the event routine for Start can have motion instructions. A motion instruction in any other event routine will result in a runtime execution error. The only exception is the motion instruction StepBwdPath, which is allowed in the event routine for Restart.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed.

td.paragraph: The specified routine will run when the controller is restarted (restart) from a remote client or by power on.
If the routine cannot be started due to a program error, it will run at the next normal start of RAPID if the error is resolved.
The Power On event routine will not be stopped by emergency stop, but can be stopped by pressing the stop button on the FlexPendant.
Execution is started from the beginning of the program. This is when you press the start or step buttons after having:

listitem.paragraph: loaded a new program or a new module
ordered Start from beginning
ordered Debug/Move PP to Main
ordered Debug/Move PP to Routine
moved the program pointer in such a way that the execution order is lost.

td.paragraph: The specified routine is run for every forward and backward step.
Use the RAPID function RunMode to see if it is a forward or backward step.
Use the RAPID function ExecLevel to see if it is executing on trap or normal level.

listitem.paragraph: with the stop button
with a STOP instruction
stop after current instruction.

wrapper.paragraph: A delayed stop after current cycle will not execute the routines connected to this state.
The event is not activated at Exit instruction or stop due to execution error.

td.paragraph: The robot was stopped with category 0 stop (emergency stop).

Execution is started from the position where it was stopped, or from another instruction the program pointer has been moved to, without having lost the execution order. The event is not activated after having executed one instruction in step by step mode (FWD or MStep).
Close and load a new program using the FlexPendant. The event is not activated after having loaded a system module or a program module.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The following event routines are predefined for all tasks in all systems and must not be removed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Sequence Number belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Sequence Number specifies in which order the routine should be executed for a specific event.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Order the event routines in a sequence where the first routine shall have a low value and the routines that shall run last has the highest value.
0 will run first.
If several event routines has the same sequence number, the execution order will be unpredictable.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 100.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Task belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Task specifies the name of the task that the routine will run in.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The task is defined in the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with All Tasks or All Motion Tasks . For more information, see The Task type, All Tasks, and All Motion Tasks.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Names of configured tasks of the type Task .

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: All event routines need information on which task they will run, even though only one task is configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: All Tasks belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: All Tasks defines if the routine will run in all configured tasks in the system. For more information, see Task and The Task type.
Note that there can be more tasks available in the system than can be seen, that is tasks with Type defined as STATIC or SEMISTATIC, or Hidden defiined as YES.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The tasks are defined in the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Task or All Motion Tasks .
A routine with All Tasks set to Yes can only contain code possible to run in any task in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
The default value is No.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: All event routines need information on which task they will run, even if only one task is configured in the system.
If Exclude from Load Modules in All Task is set for a task, that task will also be excluded when running event routines for All Tasks .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: All Motion Tasks belongs to the type Event Routine , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: All Motion Tasks defines if the routine will run in all configured motion tasks in the system.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The tasks are defined in the type Task .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Cannot be combined with Task or All Tasks . For more information, see Task and The Task.
A routine with All Motion Tasks set to Yes can only contain the code possible to run in any motion task in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
The default value is No.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: All event routines need information on which task they will run, even if only one task is configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Fan Control which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
fan control functionality
silent fan
Fan Control, type The cooling fan on OmniCore C30 controllers will work on reduced speed or shut off while the controller is in motors off state to lower the sound level. This is called fan control functionality.

The fan will run with full cooling capacity when the controller is in motors on state. When changing to motors off, the fan will shut off if the temperature on the incoming air is low enough, or run in reduced speed if the temperature is too high.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Fan Control , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Turn Off Fan. The value cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Value belongs to the type Fan Control , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Value defines if the fan should shut off in motors off state when the temperature on the incoming air to the controller is low enough.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
The default value is Yes.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type General Rapid , which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
General Rapid, type
General Rapid contains parameters that are general for the controller.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the ID of the actions listed below. The parameter Value defines the value for the instance.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one instance with Name set to each of the allowed values.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed and are described on the following pages:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Value belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the values for the action values defined in parameter Name .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The allowed values depend on the parameter Name , and are described on the following pages:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: BrakeMaintenance is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: BrakeMaintenance (BM) is a feature in the Cyclic Brake Check (CBC) functionality.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: CBC automatically detects if maintenance of the mechanical brakes is needed and then activates the BM functionality during CBC execution. There are event logs that shows if the brake maintenance has been run and also shows the result of the maintenance.

td.paragraph: BrakeMaintenance is deactivated. CBC runs as normal, but without brake maintenance.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated directly. No restart is required.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about Cyclic Brake Check, see
Application manual Functional safety and SafeMove
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: CollisionErrorHandling is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines if the execution shall stop or not when a motion collision occurs. If CollisionErrorHandling is set the execution will continue to the Error handler.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Used if it is possible to execute after some error handling after a collision.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO
Default value is NO.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes will take effect immediately. It does not need a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
See Collision Detection in
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: MathLibMemSize is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value MathLibMemSize specifies the amount of memory allocated for use by mathematical instructions in RAPID.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: With this parameter it is possible to increase memory used for mathematical RAPID instructions, such as MatrixX and FitX , so they can handle bigger input data.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer value between 500000 and 20000000.
Normally the default value is enough for most calculations and should only be changed if event log 41807, Not enough memory is reported.
Default value is 500000.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: ModalPayLoadMode is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: ModalPayLoadMode defines whether or not ModalPayLoadMode shall be used. When ModalPayLoadMode is used, any payload is set by the GripLoad instruction. When ModalPayLoadMode is not used, the optional argument TLoad is used for setting payload.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Can be useful, for example, if the modal instruction GripLoad is not desirable.

td.paragraph: ModalPayLoadMode shall be used. Any payload is set by the GripLoad instruction. This is a default value.
ModalPayLoadMode shall not be used, instead the optional argument TLoad is used. The argument TLoad is available on all motion instructions.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about GripLoad and TLoad , see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: NoOfRetry is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value NoOfRetry specifies the number of times the routine with a recoverable error is called before the error is reported as fatal and execution is stopped.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Can be useful, for example, if the network is shaky and the first attempt at opening a file does not work.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Works only if an error handler that takes care of the error situation is programmed with the RETRY statement.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer value between 0 and 1000.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: This example shows that it can take some time before an I/O unit is enabled. Several attempts are needed before it is possible to set the digital output signal.
PROC A()
IOEnable "cell_1", 0;
SetDO cell_1_sig3, 1; !This might not work on the first attempt
ERROR IF ERRNO = ERR_IOENABLE THEN
RETRY;
ENDIF
ENDPROC

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: PayLoadsInWristCoords is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: PayLoadsInWristCoords defines whether or not this mode shall be used. The PayLoadsInWristCoords will only have impact when the tool holds an additional payload.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Can be useful, for example, if several tool/TCP (Tool center Point) or work objects (when stationary tool) are used for one payload. In this case only one Load Identification is needed instead of one for each tool/TCP or work object.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter PayLoadsInWristCoords will only impact if an additional payload is used beyond the tool.

td.paragraph: PayLoadsInWristCoords shall not be used, any payload is added relative to the TCP or work object.
PayLoadsInWristCoords shall be used. Any payload is added relative to the wrist.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.
The default value is changed compared with IRC5.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about how loads are added, see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
, loaddata and GripLoad .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: QueueBackup is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: QueueBackup is used when the system input signal Disable Backup is frequently used, and there is a risk that a backup not will be taken. If QueueBackup is set to TRUE , the backup will be queued until the signal is reset.

In automatic mode the backup will also be queued while executing and the system input signal is low. The signal must then be set and reset before a backup is performed. This is to prevent that a backup is started just before entering or during a sensitive path in the program when the signal for Disable backup is used.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: To queue a backup can be useful if there is no cross-checking done between taking a backup and running robot movements, where a backup can disturb the process, for example, when gluing.

td.paragraph: Any backup that is ordered is neglected if the system parameter Disable Backup is set. This is the default value.
Any backup that is ordered will be queued until the system parameter Disable Backup is reset.

wrapper.paragraph: The changes are effective after a normal start.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Operating manual OmniCore
section Important when performing backups.

Operating manual Integrator's guide OmniCore
section Back up the system.
Disable Backup.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RapidInstructionsPerMs is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: RapidInstructionsPerMs defines how many RAPID instructions are executed per ms by the controller.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The default value should not be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RapidLogging is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter RapidLogging enables logging of RAPID execution. It is very useful when sending system diagnostic data for troubleshooting.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This functionality is useful when finding errors related to the RAPID program. The logging is included in the system diagnostic and can be used by ABB personnel.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No
The default value is Yes.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: ReportNonActiveSingles is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: ReportNonActiveSingles is used to warn user and stop execution in case a single, that is not active, has a valid value in RAPID.

Setting this value to Yes will stop execution if the position value in RAPID differs from 9E9, for a deactivated single. This can help prevent unexpected movement when a single axis is not consistent between RAPID value and activation status.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: When having mechanical units that can be deactivated, this parameter will prevent the robot from moving.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: SimulateMenu is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The WaitTime , WaitUntil , WaitDO , and WaitDI instructions generate an alert box in manual mode to make it possible to simulate the instruction and continue to execute the next instruction. The parameter Value defines if SimulateMenu is on or off.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: It is useful to switch this parameter off if no alert boxes are desired. Set Value to No to disable menus.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter is only active in manual mode. There are no alert boxes in automatic mode.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: StationaryPayLoadMode is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: StationaryPayLoadMode defines whether or not this mode should be used. The StationaryPayLoadMode only have effect when a stationary tool is used. When StationaryPayLoadMode is used, any payload is added relative to the wrist coordinate system. When StationaryPayLoadMode is not used, any payload is added relative to the work object.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Can be useful, for example, if several work objects are used for one stationary tool. In this case only one Load Identification is needed instead of one for each work object.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter StationaryPayLoadMode will only impact if a stationary tool is used.

td.paragraph: StationaryPayLoadMode shall not be used, any payload is added relative to the work object when a stationary tool is used.
StationaryPayLoadMode shall be used. Any payload is added relative to the wrist when a stationary tool is used.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about how loads are added, see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
, loaddata and GripLoad .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: StepOutNoStepin is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: StepOutNoStepin is used when changing direction from forward to backward step when the program pointer is inside a nostepin routine.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: StepOutNoStepin is used to be able to change from forward to backward step when the program pointer is inside a nostepin routine. If any UNDO-handler available in the the nostepin routine, then it is run. Regardless of the UNDO-handler is run or not, the program pointer will be set to the instruction above the call to the nostepin routine.
If StepOutNoStepin is not activated, the change of direction will result in rejection of backward step.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TruncateLongRapidStrings is an action value for the parameter Name that belongs to the type General Rapid , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: TruncateLongRapidStrings defines if long RAPID strings should be truncated or not.
The parameter is used in combination with the RAPID instructions StrFormat and TextGet , as well as when combining two strings (for example, string1 := string2 +string3;).
If TruncateLongRapidStrings is activated, the program will not be terminated even if the RAPID string is too long. Instead, the string will be truncated and a warning will be displayed.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Normally, strings that exceed the limit of 80 bytes will cause termination of the program. Using this function, the program will not be terminated even if the strings are too long. Instead, the strings will be truncated.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Changes are activated after a normal restart.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about StrFormat , TextGet see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Mechanical Unit Group , which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section. For more information, see Use Mechanical Unit Group.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: With the option MultiMove comes the possibility to control several robots from one controller. Each task can control one robot and up to six positioners. The mechanical units that will be controlled by one task are grouped in a mechanical unit group, type mechanical unit group.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual MultiMove
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Mechanical Unit Group , in the topic Controller . For more information, see Use Mechanical Unit Group.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the mechanical unit group.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This is the public identity of the mechanical unit group. It is used by the parameter Use Mechanical Unit Group in the type Tasks .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit Group is only used if you have the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Robot belongs to the type Mechanical Unit Group , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the robot (with TCP), if there is any, in the mechanical unit group.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Robot is set to the same value as the parameter Name for the Mechanical Unit Group type that it represents. For more information, see Name.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Robot is only used if you have the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit 1 , Mechanical Unit 2 , Mechanical Unit 3 , Mechanical Unit 4 , Mechanical Unit 5 , and Mechanical Unit 6 belong to the type Mechanical Unit Group , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit 1 specifies the first mechanical unit without TCP, if there is any, in the mechanical unit group.
Mechanical Unit 2 specifies the second mechanical unit without TCP, if there is more than one, in the mechanical unit group.
Mechanical Unit 3 specifies the third mechanical unit without TCP, if there are more than two, in the mechanical unit group.
Mechanical Unit 4 specifies the fourth mechanical unit without TCP, if there are more than three, in the mechanical unit group.
Mechanical Unit 5 specifies the fifth mechanical unit without TCP, if there are more than four, in the mechanical unit group.
Mechanical Unit 6 specifies the sixth mechanical unit without TCP, if there are more than five, in the mechanical unit group.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit is set to the same value as the parameter Name for the Mechanical Unit Group type that it represents. For more information, see Name.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameters Mechanical Unit is only used if you have the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motion Planner belongs to the type Mechanical Unit Group , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies which motion planner shall be used for calculating the movements of the mechanical units in this group.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motion Planner is set to the same value as the parameter Name for the Motion Planner type that you want to use. For more information, see The Motion Planner type in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Use Motion Planner is only used if you have the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type ModPos Settings which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: It is sometimes desirable to limit how much a robtarget position can be moved by a modpos settings, type ModPos or HotEdit operation. The limited deviation concerns both the linear distance and the orientation.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one set of parameters of the type ModPos Settings in the system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines that the parameter configuration is for ModPos.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limited ModPos belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Limited ModPos defines if a ModPos change must be within a limited sphere for the position deviation and within a limited cone for the reorientation.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Limited ModPos to False when no limit is required, and to True when limits should apply.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: FALSE or TRUE.
Default value is FALSE.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mode belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mode defines how the limit is defined; to an absolute point or relative to the current position.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Setting Mode to Absolute means that the limited sphere/cone is around a fixed original point, i.e. position changes are accumulated and the accumulated deviation value is checked against the set max limits each time a change is made.
Setting Mode to Relative means that the limited sphere/cone is around the current point and will be moved when you modify the position.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Mode is available only if Limited ModPos is set to TRUE. For more information, see Limited ModPos.
Absolute is effective only on named robtargets, for example, p10, p20. * robtargets are not visible on the tree view.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Absolute or Relative.
Default value is Relative.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: In this example, the original point P1 is moved two times, first to P2 and then to P3. In figure A, Mode is set to Absolute, and in figure B, Mode is set to Relative.
The allowed move distance, R does not change in figure A. This makes it impossible to move the point to P3, as this is beyond R.
In figure B however, the allowed move distance follows the last point. So from P1 it is possible to move as far as R1 allows, and from P2, it is allowed to move as far as R2, etc.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=4.951in 2.719in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Trans belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Trans defines the maximum allowed deviation in mm from the current or original position.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Limited ModPos is set to TRUE, then Limit Trans is used by both ModPos and HotEdit, otherwise it is only used by HotEdit. For more information, see Limited ModPos.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is 5.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Rot belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Rot defines the maximum allowed reorientation in degrees from the current or original position.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Limited ModPos is set to TRUE, then Limit Rot is used by both ModPos and HotEdit, otherwise it is only used by HotEdit. For more information, see Limited ModPos.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: 0 - 360 degrees (0 - 6.280 radians).
Default value is 10 degrees (0.17 radians).

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Convert degrees to radians: radians = (degrees/360)*(2*pi)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit External Trans belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Limit External Trans defines the maximum allowed deviation in mm from the current or original position concerning external linear axes.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Limited ModPos is set to TRUE, then Limit External Trans is used by both ModPos and HotEdit, otherwise it is only used by HotEdit. For more information, see Limited ModPos.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is 50.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit External Rot belongs to the type ModPos Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Limit External Rot defines the maximum allowed deviation in degrees from the current or original position concerning external rotational axes.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Limited ModPos is set to TRUE, then Limit External Rot is used by both ModPos and HotEdit, otherwise it is only used by HotEdit. For more information, see Limited ModPos.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: 0 - 360 degrees (0 - 6.280 radians).
Default value is 10 degrees (0.17 radians).

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Convert degrees to radians: radians = (degrees/360)*(2*pi)

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Move In Auto which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Some robots are allowed to be moved in AUTO mode which normally is restricted. To use this functionality, a system input ( MoveInAuto ) must be used to prove the local presence. It is then possible to move the robot, since it will get a certificate key when the system input is set, that are used when jogging. The certificate key will be valid only for a certain time, and that time can be configured with the parameter MoveInAuto .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The type Move In Auto defines the timeout or how long the local presence certificate key is valid.
All changes in the type Move In Auto will take effect immediately and no restart of the controller is required.
Available only for some robots.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Timeout belongs to the type Move In Auto , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The timeout in seconds for allowing the movement of the robot in AUTO mode and is valid when using a local presence certificate key.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 30, and there is normally no reason to change this value.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Timeout is used only if you have this functionality .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer between 10 and 3000.
Default value is 30.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Operator Safety which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The operator safety, type
Operator Safety type is used to define extra safety for system execution.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Function belongs to the type Operator Safety , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Function defines safety functions for the robot system.

td.paragraph: Hold-to-run enables a functionality that requires a button to be pressed in to allow execution in Manual Reduce Speed mode. When the button is released the executions are immediately stopped.
Hold-to-run is always activated in Manual Full Speed operating mode.
Hold-to-run is further described in standard ISO 10218 (EN775).
For more information, see How to activate hold-to-run control.

AllowMoveRobAuto is only available for robots that are allowed to be moved manually in automatic mode. If the function is activated it is possible to move the robot in automatic mode without executing.
AllowMoveRobAuto is not available for all robots.

When using an external cableless device to start RAPID execution, there is a risk if the robot starts to move and the communication is lost. For those applications, it is vital to ensure that the device has contact with the controller the whole time during execution. HeartBeat must then be enabled.
When ZeroSpeedEMStop is activated, 0% speed is set and kept when the emergency stop button is pressed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Active belongs to the type Operator Safety , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Active defines whether the value of Function is activated. For more information, see Function.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is FALSE.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Options , which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: Options contains read-only names and descriptions of the installed options in the system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Options , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Short unique ID of an option.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Uniquely identifies an option.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Read-only

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Description belongs to the type Options , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Complete name of an option.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Human friendly identification of an option.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Read-only

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Path Return Region which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: In a return movement, the path return region, type path return region specifies the distance from the current robot position to the last executed path.
There are three sets of parameters defined for this type; automatic mode (AUTO), manual mode (MAN), and StartMove. All are predefined on delivery.

wrapper.title: Return movements
wrapper.paragraph: A return movement must take place when the current path of the robot deviates from the programmed path. For example, this is required when an uncontrolled stop has occurred or when the robot has been jogged away from its path.
A return movement begins when program start is ordered and stops before the program continues with the instruction that was interrupted due to a stop request.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mode belongs to the type Path Return Region , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mode defines in which operating mode or instruction a return movement will start.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Auto, Man and StartMove mode must be defined in the system and are configured on delivery.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Distance belongs to the type Path Return Region , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Distance defines the maximum allowed TCP distance from the current robot position to the last executed path.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Distance is used to limit the return movement if there is a risk that the robot will collide with an object.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Specify which operating mode the return movement is valid for. This is defined in the parameter Mode . For more information, see Mode.

td.paragraph: 0-2.00 meters, specifying the movement in meters.
0-2.00 meters, specifying the movement in meters.
0-2.00 meters, specifying the movement in meters.

wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Rotation defines the maximum allowed TCP rotation from the current robot position to the last executed path.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Rotation is used to limit the return movement if there is a risk that the robot will collide with an object.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Specify which operating mode the return movement is valid for. This is defined in the parameter Mode . For more information, see Mode.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: To convert degrees to radians, use this formula:

wrapper.paragraph: External Distance defines the maximum allowed external axes distance from the current robot position to the last executed path.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: External Distance is used to limit the return movement if there is a risk that the robot will collide with an object.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Specify which operating mode the return movement is valid for. This is defined in the parameter Mode . For more information, see Mode.

wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.paragraph: External Rotation belongs to the type Path Return Region , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: External Rotation defines the maximum allowed external axes rotation from the current robot position to the last executed path.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: External Rotation is used to limit the regain movement if there is a risk that the robot will collide with an object.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Specify which operating mode the return movement is valid for. This is defined in the parameter Mode . For more information, see Mode.

section.title: The Run Mode Settings type Run Mode Settings, type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Run Mode Settings which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The type Run Mode Settings defines if the run mode should change when changing operating mode.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Run Mode Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name of the operating mode setting.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one instance with each allowed value, that is a maximum of two instances in the system.

td.paragraph: Defines settings when switching from automatic to manual operating mode.
Defines settings when switching from manual to automatic operating mode.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Switch belongs to the type Run Mode Settings , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Switch defines the run mode when switching operating mode.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Defines if the run mode should be changed when changing operating mode.

td.paragraph: Set run mode to single cycle.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type System Input which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section. For more information, see How to define system inputs.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: system input, type Input I/O signals can be assigned specific system inputs, for example Start or Motors on. The input triggers a system action that is handled by the system, without using the FlexPendant or other hardware devices.
It is possible to use a PLC to trigger the system inputs.

wrapper.title: Rejected system inputs
wrapper.paragraph: If the system is in manual mode or cannot perform the action due to any other unfulfilled requirement, no error messages are displayed. When a system action is rejected the error messages are stored in the error log.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following limitations have to be considered:

listitem.paragraph: Only one system action can be assigned to the input I/O signal. However, several input I/O signals can be assigned the same system action.
When deleting a system action the input I/O signal itself remains defined. The I/O signal has to be deleted separately.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Most system inputs are 0 to 1 level sensitive. The pulse length must exceed 50 ms or according to the configured filter settings for I/O signals.
The following System Input signals are both 0 to 1 and 1 to 0 level sensitive. For more information, see Filter Time Passive and Filter Time Active.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Name belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller , see Signal.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Name is the name of the configured digital input I/O signal to use. It connects the system input with a configured digital input I/O signal, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Available configured digital input I/O signal names.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action belongs to the type System Inputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Action defines the system action to be triggered by the input signal. The system action is handled by the system without input from the user. A PLC can be used to trigger the system action.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed and described on the following pages:

listitem.paragraph: Backup.
Collision avoidance.
Disable Backup.
Enable Energy Saving.
Interrupt.
Limit Speed.
Load.
Load and Start.
Motors Off.
Motors On.
Motors On and Start.
PP to Main.
ProfiSafeOpAck.
Quick Stop.
Reset Execution Error signal.
SimMode.
Start.
Start at Main.
Stop.
Stop at End of Cycle.
Stop at End of Instruction.
System Restart.
Trust Revolution Counter.
Verify Local Presence.
Verify Move Robot In Auto.
Write Access.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Backup is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Backup starts a backup as defined by the parameters Argument .

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Backup , the following parameters must also be used. For more information, see Action.

td.paragraph: Specify a name for the backup. If the string "SYSTEM:" is specified, the name is set to be the system name, see Argument 1.
Specify a path for the backup. Always define the entire path, for example, BACKUP/sysinBackup, see Argument 3.
UniqueName means that the backup gets a unique name. If the name already exists, a higher number is added at the end of the name.
Overwrite means that a backup with the same name is overwritten, see Argument 4.
AddDate means that the backup gets the date in the name automatically.
NoDate means that the name of the backup does not get the date.
The date is in YYYYMMDD format and is put at the end of the name but before any sequence number, see Argument 5.
Archive means that the backup is archived and saved as one file with the file suffix .tar.
No Archive means that the backup is not archived.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be available, not used by any other resource (system input).

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The backup order is ignored with a warning if a backup is already in progress. It is also ignored if the the parameter Action is set to Disable Backup .

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The system output Backup Error tells if the backup was successful or not, see Backup error, see Backup Error.
The system output Backup in progress tells if the backup process is active or not, see Backup in progress.
