The ordered backup will take the program control during the operation.

Be aware that the RAPID execution can be disturbed while taking a backup. Please use the System input signal Disable Backup (see, Disable Backup) and the action value QueueBackup (see, QueueBackup) during critical movements or other RAPID code that shall not be disturbed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Avoidance is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Collision Avoidance is used to activate the Collision Avoidance functionality.

A high signal will activate the functionality and a low signal will deactivate the functionality. The functionality is by default active if no signal has been assigned to the system input Collision Avoidance .

The function Collision Avoidance monitors a detailed geometric model of the robot. If two bodies of the model come too close to each other, the controller warns about a predicted collision and stops the robot. The system parameter Coll-Pred Safety Distance determines at what distance the two objects are considered to be in collision, see Coll-Pred Safety Distance.
The Collision Avoidance functionality is configured partly in the system parameters (on/off and distance), and the geometric models are configured in RobotStudio.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Disable Backup is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Disable Backup will prevent starting a backup as long as the signal is set.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: If a backup is prevented, it will not be started when the signal gets low unless the functionality to queue the backup is configured. See QueueBackup.
If a backup is ongoing when the signal is set, the backup will continue until it has finished.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Enable Energy Saving is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Setting the action value Enable Energy Saving enables the controller to enter an energy saving state. Resetting the signal while in an energy saving state will cause the controller to resume.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Signal sequence
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequence for Enable Energy Saving is:
A: Enable Energy Saving (IN)
B: Energy Saving Blocked (OUT)

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: It is not only the system input signal Enable Energy Saving that can cause the energy saving functionality to be blocked. That is, the system output signal Energy Saving Blocked can be set even if the system input action Enable Energy Saving is set.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Interrupt is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Interrupt executes a routine and after running the routine the execution will resume to the same instruction as before. If necessary, a regain movement is always performed before the interrupt routine executes.
Interrupt can be used by a PLC to let the robot go to a service position.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Interrupt , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: The name of the routine to be executed, see Argument 1.
The task in which the routine defined in Argument 1 should be executed. This is only used with MultiMove , see Argument 2.
If Argument 2 is not set, then the first found motion task is used.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The system must be in automatic mode and Motors On.
You cannot use this action value if the actions QuickStop , Stop , Stop at end of Cycle , or Stop at end of Instruction are set.
The Interrupt action will be applied only when the program execution is stopped.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: When the execution is stopped, the robot still remembers the point to which it is supposed to go. To prevent the robot going to this position when the Interrupt routine starts and delay it until after the Interrupt, the following RAPID sequence can be used in the Interrupt routine:
PROC A()
StopMove\Quick; !Prevent current move instruction to continue
StorePath; !For later use
currpos:=CRobT(); !Save current position
----- ! Place the code for the routine to run here.
MoveJ currpos,v600,fine,toolx; !Move back to programmed position
RestoPath; !Restore StorePath
StartMove; !Restore StopMove
ENDPROC
After the StartMove instruction, the stopped movement will continue to move to its fine point. When the routine A has been executed, the normal program can be restarted.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Speed is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value LimitSpeed should be set when the speed of one or all motion task should be reduced. The reduction of the speed is considered to be completed when the system output signal LimitSpeed is set to 1.

There is a time lag of 0.35 to 0.5 seconds for the LimitSpeed to be triggered in the robot. Hence, this additional time should be considered when setting up the robot, for example, safety distance for an operator.

The speed limitation is set up with RAPID instructions SpeedLimAxis and SpeedLimCheckPoint (see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
for further details) or the manual mode default values will be used. The default value for manual mode is defined by the parameter Teach Mode Max Speed .

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Limit Speed , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: The parameter specifies a mechanical unit, see Argument 6.

wrapper.paragraph: The drop-down list in the FlexPendant or RobotStudio configuration tool shows only TCP robots. Use ABC... to add any other mechanical unit.
Connecting more than one signal to the system input signal Limit Speed (connected to same robot) can cause unpredictable behavior during power failure restart.

wrapper.title: Program execution
wrapper.paragraph: When the system input signal LimitSpeed is set to 1, the speed is ramped down to the reduced speed.
When the system input signal LimitSpeed is set to 0, the speed is ramped up to the programmed speed used in the current movement instruction.
The maximum allowed acceleration during ramping up is controlled by the system parameter Limit Speed Acc Limitation in the type Motion Planner .
The system output signal LimitSpeed is set to 1, when the reduced speed is reached.
The system output signal LimitSpeed is set to 0, when the speed starts to ramp up.
The default values for speed limitation are automatically set

listitem.paragraph: when using the restart mode Reset RAPID.
when a new program is loaded.
when starting program execution from the beginning.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The system input Limit Speed should not be used together with applications where it is critical that the robot maintains a specific TCP speed. Also, the system output Limit Speed should not be used together with external equipment that requires that a large equipment lag is set up.
Specifically, the following features should not be used together with Limit Speed:

listitem.paragraph: Motion system parameter Event Preset Time
System outputs TCP Speed and TCP Speed Reference
Dispensing, that is, RAPID instructions DispL , DispC , and TriggSpeed
Arc welding

wrapper.title: Signal sequence
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequence for Limit Speed is:
A: LimitSpeed (IN)
B: LimitSpeed (OUT)

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: System output LimitSpeed

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Load is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Load loads a RAPID program (files of type .modx, .mod, .sysx, .sys, and .pgf). The program starts from the beginning.
The previously loaded files (of type .pgf) will be unloaded.

In RobotWare 7.0 and earlier, the formats were .mod and .sys. When loading these in a RobotWare 7.1 controller or later using RobotStudio, they are automatically converted when saved. When saved, the new file extensions are .sysx and .modx. Note that the files must be converted, not just renamed.
To convert a file manually, the file must be saved as UTF-8 without BOM (Byte Order Mark).
The program pointer is set to the main entry routine after the program is loaded. Program pointers in other tasks are not affected.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Load , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: The name of the program file to load, including the file format (.modx, .sysx, or .pgf). Always define the path to the file, e.g. HOME:ModuleA.modx , see Argument 1.
The task in which the program defined in Argument 1 should be loaded, see Argument 2.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller has to be in automatic mode.
Load is not valid during program execution.
If the current program has been changed, the changes will not be saved before that program is unloaded.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: When a program is loading, all routines connected to the event routine Reset will be executed. It is only possible to initiate loading of programs in one task at a time by using system inputs. To load in several tasks, the system output System Input Busy can be used so that the current execution of Reset routines are finished before the next load is initiated. See The Event Routine.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Load and Start is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Load and Start loads a RAPID program (files of type .modx, .mod, .sysx, .sys, and .pgf). The program starts from the beginning.
If a program is loaded, all modules of type .modx will be unloaded.
It can be used by a PLC to load and start a program, instead of using the FlexPendant.
The program pointer is set to the main entry routine after the program is loaded. Program pointers in other tasks are not affected.

In RobotWare 7.0 and earlier, the formats were .mod and .sys. When loading these in a RobotWare 7.1 controller or later using RobotStudio, they are automatically converted when saved. When saved, the new file extensions are .sysx and .modx. Note that the files must be converted, not just renamed.
To convert a file manually, the file must be saved as UTF-8 without BOM (Byte Order Mark).

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Load and Start , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: The name of the program file to load, including the file format (.modx, .sysx, or .pgf). Always define the path to the file, for example HOME:ModuleA.modx , see Argument 1.
The task in which the program defined in Argument 1 should be loaded, see Argument 2.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller must be in automatic mode.
You cannot use this action value if the actions QuickStop , Stop , Stop at end of Cycle , or Stop at end of Instruction are set.
Load and Start action cannot be executed during program execution.
The run mode will always be set to Cyclic.
If the controller is in Motors Off state, only the load is performed.
If the current program has been changed, the changes will not be saved before the load.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequence for Load Start is:

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.289in 1.013in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: A: Load and Start (IN)
B: Cycle On (OUT)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors Off is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Motors Off sets the controller in the Motors Off state. If a program is executing, it is stopped before changing state.
We recommend stopping the program execution before using the action Motors Off to secure a controlled stop.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequence for Motors Off is:

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.289in 1.013in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: A: Motors Off (IN)
B: Motors Off (OUT)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors On is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Motors On sets the controller in the Motors On state.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller has to be in automatic mode, see Run Chain OK.
If the system input I/O signal action Motors Off is high, then setting Motors On high has no effect, see Motors Off.
The Motors On action is not valid during program execution.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequences for Motors On is:

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.289in 1.013in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: A: Motors On (IN)
B: Motors On (OUT)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors On and Start is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller . For more information, see Action.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Motors On and Start sets the controller in the Motors On state and starts the RAPID program from the current instruction, continuous or cycle execution.
Motor On and Start can be used by a PLC to set Motors On in one single step and start a RAPID program, instead of using the FlexPendant and the control panel.
The Program Pointer needs to be set in all tasks before starting the program. The action will be rejected if the program pointer is missing in any task.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Motors On and Start , the parameter Argument 1 must also be used.
, specifying continuous or cycle. The default value is continuous. For more information, see Argument 1.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies the run mode, Continuous or Cycle . See Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller must be in automatic mode.
You cannot use this action value if the actions Motors Off , QuickStop , Stop , Stop at end of Cycle , or Stop at end of Instruction are set.
The Motors On and Start action is not valid during program execution.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: PP to Main is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller . For more information, see Action.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value PP to Main sets the program pointer to the configured production entry that is the main routine.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to PP to Main , the following parameter must also be used:

td.paragraph: The parameter can be used to set PP to Main in a specific task. If the parameter Argument 7 is not defined, all tasks will be affected. For more information, see Task Name.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: PP to Main can only be used with normal tasks.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: ProfiSafeOpAck is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: ProfiSafeOpAck is used for PROFIsafe F-Host . It is used to acknowledge a change in the PROFIsafe communication, for example if the communication cable was disconnected and reconnected.
The system input ProfiSafeOpAck has the same effect as tapping the button F-Host Op. Ack. on the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The action value ProfiSafeOpAck can only be used with the option PROFIsafe F-host .

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Functional safety and SafeMove
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Quick Stop is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Quick Stop stops the RAPID program execution quickly. This stop is performed by ramping down motion as fast as possible using optimum motor performance. The different axes are still coordinated to try to keep the robot on path even if the robot may slide off with some millimeter.

This system output should not be used for safety functions since it is not a safety I/O signal according to ISO 10218-1 and ISO 13849-1:1999. For safety functions the options Electronic Position Switches or SafeMove can be used.
A program cannot start when this signal is high.
This stop should not be used for normal program stops as this causes extra, unnecessary wear on the robot.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Reset Execution Error Signal is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller . For more information, see Execution Error.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Reset Execution Error Signal resets the system output signal action Execution Error .
This action can be used by a PLC to reset the error signal.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Set Speed Override is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Set Speed Override should be set to a specific percentage, and block any other user settings of speed override until the signal is reset.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Set Speed Override , the following parameter must also be used:

td.paragraph: The parameter specifies the speed in percentage, see Argument 9.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: SimMode is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value SimMode shall be set when the simulation mode shall be entered.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Signal sequence
wrapper.paragraph: The signal sequence for SimMode is:
A: SimMode (IN)
B: SimMode (OUT)

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: A system output signal (also called SimMode ) can be configured that reflects the status of the system state SimMode , see System Output Signal SimMode.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Start is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller . For more information, see Action.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Start starts a RAPID program from the current instruction, continuous or cycle run mode.
Start can be used by a PLC to start the program execution.
The program pointer must be set in all tasks before starting the program. The action will be rejected if the program pointer is missing in any task.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Start , the following parameter must also be used:

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies the run mode, Continuous or Cycle . See Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.
The controller must be in motors on state and the program control must be available, that is not used by any other resource.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller must be in automatic mode.
You cannot use this action value if the actions QuickStop , Stop , Stop at end of Cycle , or Stop at end of Instruction are set.
The Start action is not valid during program execution.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Start at Main is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller . For more information, see Action.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Start at Main starts a RAPID program from the beginning, continuous, or cycle run.
Start at Main can be used by a PLC to start the program execution from the beginning.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Action is set to Start at Main , the following parameter must also be used:

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies the run mode, Continuous or Cycle . See Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.
The controller must be in motors on state and the program control must be available, that is not used by any other resource.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This action value has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: The controller must be in automatic mode.
You cannot use this action value if the actions QuickStop , Stop , Stop at end of Cycle , or Stop at end of Instruction are set.
Start at Main action is not valid during program execution.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Stop is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Stop will stop the RAPID program execution much like an ordinary program stop, but slightly faster. The stop is performed by ramping down motion in a controlled and coordinated way, to keep the robot on the programmed path with minor deviation.
This stop has the same braking performance as stopping on path to a fine point.
A program cannot start when this signal is high.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Stop at End of Cycle is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Stop at End of Cycle stops the RAPID program when the complete program is executed, i.e. when the last instruction in the main routine has been completed. A program cannot be started when this signal is high.
Stop at End of Cycle can be used by a PLC to stop the program execution when the complete program has been executed.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Stop at End of Instruction is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Stop at End of Instruction stops program execution after the current instruction is completed. A program cannot start when this signal is high.
Stop at end of Instruction can be used by a PLC to stop the program execution when the current instruction is completed.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If using Stop at End of Instruction in combination with an instruction that is waiting for an I/O signal or an instruction, for example WaitSyncTask , WaitDI , or SyncMoveOn , then the waiting instruction may not be finished.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: If a WaitTime instruction is executed, it can take a while before the execution is stopped.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: System Restart is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value System Restart performs a controller restart, similar to power off/on.
This action can be used by a PLC to restart the controller.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.
All RAPID programs should be stopped before using the action.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Trust Revolution Counter is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Trust Revolution Counter should be set when the controller reports that revolution counters must be updated, but nothing has changed and setup for the revolution counters are correct. This can happen if the SMB has been switched during power off. The signal can then be set, to trust the revolution counters.
The Trust Revolution Counter action value is available only for IRB 365.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Verify Local Presence is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Verify Local Presence is used to verify local presence when no FlexPendant is available.
Changing the value 3 times rapidly (for example 0 -> 1 -> 0 -> 1), corresponds to clicking the enabling device on the FlexPendant two times when you log in for the first time.
The action value must be changed 3 times within 40 seconds.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations

wrapper.paragraph: The action value Verify Local Presence shall not be changed remotely. In order to verify local presence, you must have visual control of the robot.
It is the responsibility of the integrator to set up this input so that local presence is always achieved.
It is only possible to configure one system input with the action value Verify Local Presence .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Verify Move Robot In Auto is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The action value Verify Move Robot In Auto is used for verifying local presence and provides opportunity to move the robot in AUTO mode for a limited time.
The value of Verify Move Robot In Auto must be changed to 1 within 30 seconds after a request for moving the robot in Auto mode, to enable move in Auto.

The action value Verify Move Robot In Auto shall not be changed remotely. In order to verify local presence, you must have visual control of the robot. It is the responsibility of the integrator to set up this input so that local presence is always achieved.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Moving the robot in Auto mode is not available for all the robots.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Write Access is an action value for the parameter Action that belongs to the type System Input in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The Action value Write Access can be used by an I/O client to request write access the same way as can be done from RobotStudio.
The write access is granted if not already held by any other client and will prevent other clients from requesting write access, until the signal is reset.
single point of control This system input signal can be used to obtain single point of control.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A digital input signal must be defined and this signal should not used by any other system input.
The signal can be used only in automatic mode. The write access is released while entering the manual mode.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The system output signal Write Access can reflect if the I/O client has write access or not, see Write Access.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 1 belongs to the type System Inputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 1 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

td.paragraph: The name of the backup. If the value is SYSTEM: or not defined, then the name is set to be the system name.
The name of the routine to be executed (without path), e.g. HOME . Cannot be undefined.
The name of the program file to load, including the file format (.modx, .sysx, .pgf) and the path, e.g. HOME:ModuleA.modx . Cannot be undefined.
The name of the program file to load, including the file format (.modx, .sysx, .pgf) and the path, e.g. HOME:ModuleA.modx . Cannot be undefined.
Argument 1 specifies the run mode, Continuous or Cycle . See The Run Mode Settings type.
LOAD , no other value is allowed.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Backup.
Interrupt.
Load.
Load and Start.
Motors On and Start.
Start.
Start at Main.
SimMode.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 2 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 2 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 2 is only used with the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values

td.paragraph: The task in which the routine defined in Argument 1 should be executed. This is only used with MultiMove , see The Event Routine type.
If Argument 2 is not set, then the first found motion task is used.
The task in which the program defined in Argument 1 should be loaded, see The Task type.
The task in which the program defined in Argument 1 should be loaded, see The Task type.

wrapper.paragraph: If MultiMove is not installed, then Argument 2 must be set to T_ROB1.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Interrupt.
Load.
Load and Start.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 3 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 3 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Backup.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 4 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 4 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

td.paragraph: UniqueName means that the backup gets a unique name. If the name already exists, a higher number is added at the end of the name.
The default value Overwrite means that a backup will overwrite an existing backup with the same name.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Backup.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 5 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 5 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

td.paragraph: AddDate means that the date is added at the end of the name.
NoDate means that no date is added.
If the parameter Argument 4 is defined as UniqueName , the sequence number is added after the date.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Backup.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 6 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 6 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

td.paragraph: A mechanical unit from the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical Unit type.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Limit_Speed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 7 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 7 is an argument required to perform the system input action PP to Main . It is available when the parameter Action is set to PP to Main . For more information, see PP to Main.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Task Name can be used to specify a RAPID task or can be left blank for all normal tasks.

td.paragraph: A task from the type Task in the topic Controller , see The Task type.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: PP_Main.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 8 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 8 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

td.paragraph: Archive means that the backup is archived and saved as one file with the file suffix .tar.
The default value No Archive means that the backup is not archived.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Backup.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 9 belongs to the type System Input , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 9 is an argument required to perform some of the system actions.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Set Speed Override.

section.title: Overview of the values for Action

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Overview showing all values for Action in System Input and how they are allowed to be used in different type of system modes and states.

td.paragraph: Manual full speed mode motors on program execution
Manual reduced speed mode motors on program execution
Auto mode motors on program execution

The controller system is in system failure state
The cause of the System Failure can have impact on the function for the given System Input Actions
An external client has write access (e.g. RobotStudio)

X
Does not affect the ongoing backup

See note
Only load of the program module is performed

See note
Execution error triggered during program execution

X
Ongoing backup will be deleted

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type System Output which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: system output, type Output I/O signals can be assigned for a specific system action. These I/O signals are set automatically by the system without user input when the system action occurs.
The system output I/O signals can be both digital and analog. For more information, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: An I/O signal must be configured in the system. The signal name must be a string of maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following limitations have to be considered:

listitem.paragraph: Several output I/O signals can be assigned the same system action, but several system actions may not be assigned to the same I/O signal.
When deleting a system action the I/O signal itself remains defined. The I/O signal must be deleted separately.
The predefined system output for the Motors On lamp cannot be edited.

wrapper.title: Predefined system outputs
wrapper.paragraph: Motors On is predefined in the robot system. This output is linked to the Motors On lamp on the controller.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The actions are valid for both manual and automatic mode unless stated otherwise in the value descriptions.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Name belongs to the type System Output , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Name is the name of the configured output I/O signal to use. It connects the system output with a configured output I/O signal, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A name of an already configured output I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The signal must be digital for all outputs excepts TCP Speed , TCP Speed Reference and Speed Override that uses analog signals.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Status belongs to the type System Output , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Status defines what state the output signal will reflect.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed and are described on the following pages:

listitem.paragraph: Absolute Accuracy Active.
Auto On.
Backup Error.
Backup in progress.
Collision Avoidance.
Control On State.
Cycle On.
Emergency Stop.
Energy Saving Blocked.
Execution Error.
Limit Speed.
Mechanical Unit Active.
Mechanical Unit Not Moving.
Motion Supervision On.
Motion Supervision Triggered.
Motors Off.
Motors Off State.
Motors On.
Motors On State.
Path Return Region Error.
Power Fail Error.
PP Moved.
Production Execution Error.
Revolution_counter_lost.
Robot In Trusted Position.
Runchain Ok.
SimMode.
Simulated I/O.
SMB Batteries Charge Low.
Speed Override.
Stop from client.
System Input Busy.
TaskExecuting.
TCP Speed.
TCP Speed Reference.
Write Access.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Absolute Accuracy Active is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Absolute Accuracy Active , the I/O signal is set when the absolute accuracy is activated. The signal is cleared when the absolute accuracy is not activated.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Auto On is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Auto On , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in automatic mode.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Operating manual OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Backup Error is a value for the parameter Status and belongs to the type System Output , in the topic Controller . For more information, see Backup.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Backup Error , the signal is set when the system detects the backup failure. The failure can be detected during the backup or after a power failure if the backup has been interrupted by this. The signal is cleared when a new backup is started.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The output signal reflects the overall system backup error state independent of the application starting the backup, that is, RobotStudio, FlexPendant, and system input signal Backup .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Backup in progress is a value for the parameter Status and belongs to the type System Output , in the topic Controller . For more information, see Backup.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Backup in progress , the signal is set when a backup is started and cleared when the backup is complete with or without errors.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: This output signal reflects the overall system backup state independent of the application starting the backup, that is, RobotStudio, FlexPendant, and system input signal Backup .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Avoidance is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal is set when the functionality for Collision Avoidance is activated. The signal is cleared when the functionality for Collision Avoidance is deactivated.

The function Collision Avoidance monitors a detailed geometric model of the robot. If two bodies of the model come too close to each other, the controller warns about a predicted collision and stops the robot. The system parameter Coll-Pred Safety Distance determines at what distance the two objects are considered to be in collision, see Coll-Pred Safety Distance.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Control On State is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Control On State , the signal is set when the controller is in the state Motors On and the brakes are released. The signal is reset when the brakes are applied.
The brakes are applied in the state Motors Off. The brakes can also be applied in the state Motors On, for example, at Brake On Timeout.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Cycle On is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Cycle On , the I/O signal is set when the robot program is executing.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Cycle On is also active for service and event routine execution ( Start , Restart , and Stop ).
During path recovery operations, the I/O signal is set.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Emergency Stop is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Emergency Stop , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in emergency stop state.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Energy Saving Blocked is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Energy Saving Blocked , the I/O signal is set when the energy saving functionality is blocked (disabled).

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: It is not only the system input signal Enable Energy Saving that can cause the energy saving functionality to be blocked.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Execution Error is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Execution Error , the I/O signal is set high because the robot program execution has been stopped due to a program error during execution. The execution error state occurs when there is no error recovery, that is if there is no error handler that takes care of the current error.
The I/O signal is set to high until one of the following events occur for the task:

listitem.paragraph: Program start.
Program restart.
Reset of program pointer.
System signal Reset Execution Error set high (resets all tasks). For more information, see Reset Execution Error Signal.

wrapper.paragraph: If Argument 2 is not specified with a task name, the I/O signal will react on execution errors in any task. In this case, the I/O signal stays high until any of the events listed above occur for any of the tasks.
The signal state is not kept after power fail (Restart of controller).

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Status is set to Execution Error , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: If Argument 2 is specified with a task name, the I/O signal will only react on execution errors for that task. For more information, see Argument 2.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Speed is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value LimitSpeed , the I/O signal is set when the specified mechanical unit is running with reduced speed triggered by the system input signal Limit Speed .
See description for Limit_Speed.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Status is set to Limit Speed , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the signal is used for, see Argument 1.
Argument 4 specifies a delay when setting the output to minimize the risk of faulty triggering by SafeMove when the output is used to start the supervision.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: System input Limit_Speed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit Active is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Mechanical Unit Active , the I/O signal is set when the configured mechanical unit is active.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the signal is used for, see Argument 1.

wrapper.paragraph: The drop-down list in the FlexPendant or RobotStudio configuration tool shows only TCP robots. Use ABC... to add any other mechanical unit.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If the configured mechanical unit is active, the system output will be set.
If the mechanical unit is configured to be active, the system output will already be set at start.
It is possible to deactivate a mechanical unit on the FlexPendant or via RAPID.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mechanical Unit Not Moving is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Mechanical Unit Not Moving , the I/O signal is set high when the configured mechanical unit is not moving. Using the parameter Mech.Unit Not Moving Detection Level will also set the output when all axes of the mechanical units with a defined level running in the same motion group are moving slower than its level. For more information, see Mech.Unit Not Moving Detection Level, in the topic Motion , type Robot and Mech.Unit Not Moving Detection Level, in the topic Motion , type Single .

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the signal is used for, see Argument 1.

If Argument 1 is not defined (no value) then the I/O signal will reflect the state of the system. The I/O signal will be set low when the first mechanical unit starts to move and will be set high when the last mechanical units stops to move.

wrapper.paragraph: The drop-down list in the FlexPendant or RobotStudio configuration tool shows only TCP robots. Use ABC... to add any other mechanical unit.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: For conveyors and mechanical units that are moved using independent move or sensor synchronization the system output remains high if the robot is not moving.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: In situations where units (for example, a TCP robot and an additional axis) are synchronized in the same movement instruction or by move instructions with same ID in different tasks, the I/O signals will for all units have the same value, that is the I/O signals will not be set until all synchronized units are stopped.
The state of the I/O signal is changed during regain movement. This can make the I/O signal toggle for example when stepping over logical instructions.
This system output should not be used for safety functions since it is not a safety I/O signal according to ISO 10218-1 and ISO 13849-1:1999. For safety functions the option SafeMove can be used.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision On is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motion Supervision On , the I/O signal is set when the motion supervision function is active.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the supervision is used for, see Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision On is only valid when the robot is in status motors on.

After motion supervision has triggered, the robot moves away from the collision, see
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
, section Collision detection. To make sure that it is possible to back away, the motion supervision is always turned off during this movement, which means that the I/O signal will be set to low directly after motion supervision is triggered. The I/O signal will then be reset to the previous value after one of the following actions:

listitem.paragraph: The program is restarted.
The program pointer is manually moved to Main.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Triggered is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motion Supervision Triggered , the I/O signal is set when the motion supervision function has been triggered.
The signal is set when Manipulator Supervision (IRB 360 only) is triggered as well.

wrapper.title: Arguments

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the supervision is used for, see Argument 1.

wrapper.paragraph: The signal is set when Manipulator Supervision (IRB 360 only) is triggered as well.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal is reset by one of the following actions:

listitem.paragraph: The program is restarted.
The program pointer is manually moved to Main.
The error message is acknowledged.

The collision has been handled in an error handler and resumed to normal execution. The signal will then be set only for a short while during execution in the error handler. For more information, see CollisionErrorHandler.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors Off is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motors Off , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in motors off state.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph:
If the controller is in guard stop
The controller is in motors off state and a safety chain is not closed. , the output starts pulsing with a frequency of 1 sec. If the controller is not calibrated or the revolution counter is not updated, the output will pulsate even faster in manual mode.
If only motors off state is of interest, the action value Motors Off State is preferred.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Motors Off State.
Run Chain OK.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors Off State is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motors Off State , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in motors off state.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors On is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motors On , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in motors on state.
For more information, see Motors On State.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph:
If the controller is in guard stop
The controller is in motors off state and a safety chain is not closed. , the output starts pulsing with a frequency of 1 sec. If the controller is not calibrated or the revolution counter is not updated, the output will pulsate even faster in manual mode.
Motors On can be used to detect if the controller is in motors on and whether the controller is synchronized or not.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motors On State is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Motors On State , the I/O signal is set when the controller is in motors on state.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Path Return Region Error is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Path Return Region Error , the I/O signal is set when an attempt to start the robot program has been made but failed since the robot was too far from the programmed path.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the supervision is used for, see Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The value Path Return Region Error is set, for example, if the current movement is interrupted and then:

listitem.paragraph: The robot is jogged too far from the programed path and then restarted.
An emergency stop has occurred and the robot has slid too far away from its programmed path and then restarted.

wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal is reset by one of the following actions:

listitem.paragraph: The program is restarted after the robot has been jogged into the regain zone.
The program pointer is manually moved to Main.
The program pointer is manually moved and the program is restarted.

wrapper.paragraph: The distances of the zones can be configured in the type Return Region in the topic Controller , see The Return Region type.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Power Fail Error is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Power Fail Error , the I/O signal is set when a program cannot continue from its current position after a power failure.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The program will not restart after the value Power Fail Error is set. Usually, the program can be started, but it will always start from the beginning.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: PP Moved is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The signal is set when PP is moved. Argument 3 decides what kind of PP movement that will trigger the signal and how the signal is set.
If Argument 3 is set to MAIN, the signal will be set when PP is moved to main. The signal will stay high until the Cycle On parameter is set and the execution starts.
If Argument 3 is not set, the signal will pulse once when you move the program pointer to Main, routine, or within a routine.

td.paragraph: Argument 2 defines a RAPID task. For more information, see Argument 2.
Argument 3 defines if the the output shall reflect only PP moved to main, and will then be set instead of pulsed. For more information, see Argument 3.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Production Execution Error is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller . For more information, see Execution Error.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Production Execution Error , the I/O signal is set high if the system is in automatic mode and when at least one normal task is running and one of the following occurs:

listitem.paragraph: A program execution error in any normal task.

A collision
This is not a replacement for Motion Supervision Triggered .
A system error: SysFail, SysHalt, or SysStop RapidBlock.

wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal is reset by:

listitem.paragraph: Program start.
Program restart.

wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal value is not kept after a restart.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Using Production Execution Error does not effect the functionality in the option Collision Detection , nor can it replace the option Collision Detection .

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: System errors are described in parameter TrustLevel.

The instruction SystemStopAction , see
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Revolution Counter Lost is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The signal will be set when revolution counters must be updated.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Robot In Trusted Position is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Robot In Trusted Position , the I/O signal is set when the robot is on the programmed path.

td.paragraph: Argument 2 specifies which RAPID task controls the mechanical unit that the signal is used for, see Argument 2.
Argument 5 defines the maximum TCP distance that the robot can diverge from the programmed path, see Argument 5.
Argument 6 defines the maximum TCP rotation, see Argument 6.
Argument 7 defines the maximum TCP distance that the external axis can diverge from the programmed path, see Argument 7.
Argument 8 defines the maximum TCP rotation that the external axis can diverge from the programmed path, see Argument 8.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The value Robot In Trusted Position is reset if:

listitem.paragraph: The robot is jogged too far from the programed path.
The robot has slid too far away from its programmed path, for example, caused by an unplanned stop.
The program pointer is moved to either Main, Routine, or Cursor.
A position in the program is modified or the program is edited so that the program pointer is lost.

wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal is set by one of the following actions:

listitem.paragraph: When a fine point is reached.
If the first position is a zone, the signal is set when leaving the zone.

wrapper.paragraph: If the signal is set and the controller is restarted, then the signal will not be set until the controller is in Motors On state.
Robot In Trusted Position will not be updated correctly in case the robot has deviated from the programmed path due to corrections such as conveyor tracking, soft servo, etc.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Run Chain OK is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Run Chain OK , the I/O signal is set when the safety chain is closed. The safety chain must be closed to be able to go to motors on.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: In manual mode the safety chain is opened and Run Chain OK is not set.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: SimMode is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value SimMode , the I/O signal is set when the state SimMode is set. The signal is cleared when the state SimMode is cleared.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: After a restart, the system output signal SimMode will also reflect the state SimMode .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Simulated I/O is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Simulated I/O , the I/O signal is set when at least one I/O signal at any I/O device is in simulated mode.
I/O signals can be set to simulated mode during testing, using the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: SMB Battery Charge Low is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value SMB Battery Charge Low , the I/O signal is set when the SMB battery capacity is running low and the battery needs to be replaced soon. The signal is cleared when the SMB battery charge is okay.

There is only one battery in a normal single robot system. However, there can be up to 16 SMB batteries in a MultiMove system or when using external axes. The output is activated if any of the batteries need replacement.
An event log message gives information about which battery should be replaced.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: SMB batteries are cyclically supervised every 10th hour. After replacing a battery, it can take up to 10 hours for the signal to reset. The value is saved during a restart.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Speed Override is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Speed Override , the I/O signal reflects the speed override in percent.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: An analogue output signal with the signal name defined as Speed Override must be available, and it cannot be used by any other resource.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Stop From Client is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value Stop From Client , the I/O signal will pulse for one second when a stop is done by an external client, such as the TPU, RobotStudio, and so on. A stop made from a PLC with a system input signal Stop, an execution error, an emergency stop or any other action not taken by a client will not affect the system output signal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: System Input Busy is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value System Input Busy , that means the I/O signal is set when the system input mechanism is busy.

For some actions the controller is busy for some time and cannot receive any commands, thus rejects any order. A new command must be sent when the controller is ready again. The status System Input Busy can be used to show if the incoming system input request will be rejected or not.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: In this example the controller is set to motors on and a program is started by setting a system output status Motors On . This signal is cross connected to a system input signal configured with the action Start . As the controller is busy with changing state to motors on, the start order will be rejected while the controller is still busy with the state change.

A solution to this is to use the system input action System Input Busy and add an AND operator with System Input Busy inverted to the cross connection. This will delay the start request until the motors on action is completed. Since the start order also will make the system busy, that is, doSystemInputBusy will be set again, an extra inverted system output signal for Task Execution must be added so the logic does not end up in a loop.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TaskExecuting is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value TaskExecuting , the I/O signal is set when the configured task is executing.
During path recovery operations, the I/O signal is not set.

wrapper.title: Arguments
wrapper.paragraph: When the parameter Status is set to TaskExecuting , the following parameters must also be used.

td.paragraph: The parameter has to be defined with a task name. For more information, see Argument 2.
The parameter Argument 2 can only be configured with the name of a normal task.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Speed is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value TCP Speed , the I/O signal reflects the speed of the robot's TCP.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the speed refers to, see Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The logical value of the I/O signal is specified in m/s, for example a speed of 2000 mm/s corresponds to the logical value 2 m/s. The scaling factor for the physical value is specified in the parameters of the corresponding I/O signal. For more information, see Max Logical Value and Max Physical Value.
The analog output is set approximately 40 ms before the actual TCP speed occurs. This prediction time is constant during acceleration and deceleration.

The Event Preset Time parameter affects the time interval between the setting up of the analog output and the occurrence of the TCP speed. For example, if Event Preset Time is set to 0.2 (200 ms), the analog output is set 240 ms before the occurrence of the TCP speed. For more information, see Event Preset Time.
This system output should not be used together with the system input Limit Speed . The system output will not reflect the change in TCP speed that is activated when the Limit Speed signal is set.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Speed Reference is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Status has the value TCP Speed Reference , the I/O signal reflects the programmed speed of the robot's TCP.

td.paragraph: Argument 1 specifies which mechanical unit the programmed speed refers to, see Argument 1.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: TCP Speed Reference works in the same way as TCP Speed but uses the programmed speed. For more information, see TCP Speed.
TCP Speed can differ from TCP Speed Reference , for example at acceleration or if the override speed has been changed.
This system output should not be used together with the system input Limit Speed . The system output will not reflect the change in TCP speed that is activated when the Limit Speed signal is set.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Write Access is a value for the parameter Status that belongs to the type System Output in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The status value Write Access can be used to reflect if the I/O client has write access or not.
Write access can be requested through the system input Write Access , see Write Access.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 1 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 1 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: A mechanical unit of the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical unit type.
A mechanical unit of the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical unit type.
If no mechanical unit is specified, the I/O signal reacts on any mechanical unit in the system.
A mechanical unit of the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical unit type.
A mechanical unit of the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical unit type.
If no unit is specified, the I/O signal reacts on any mechanical unit in the system.
A mechanical unit of the type Mechanical Unit in the topic Motion , see The Mechanical unit type.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision On.
TCP Speed.
TCP Speed Reference.
Motion Supervision Triggered.
Path Return Region Error.
Mechanical Unit Active.
Limit Speed.
Mechanical Unit Not Moving.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 2 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 2 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: A task from the type Task in the topic Controller , see The Task type.
If no task is specified, the I/O signal reacts on any task in the system.
A task from the type Task in the topic Controller , see The Task type.
A task from the type Task in the topic Controller , see The Task type.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Execution Error.
PP_Moved.
TaskExecuting.
Robot In Trusted Position.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 3 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 3 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 4 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 4 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: Argument 4 specifies a delay when setting the output to minimize the risk of faulty triggering by SafeMove when the output is used to start the supervision.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Limit Speed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 5 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 5 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: Argument 5 defines the maximum TCP distance that the robot can diverge from the programmed path.
Allowed values are 0-2.00, specified in meters. Default value is 0.05 meters.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Robot In Trusted Position.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 6 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 6 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: Argument 6 defines the maximum TCP rotation.
Allowed values are 0-6.280, specified in radians. Default value is 1.57 radians.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Robot In Trusted Position.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 7 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 7 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: Argument 7 defines the maximum TCP distance that the external axis can diverge from the programmed path.
Allowed values are 0-2.00, specified in meters. Default value is 0.05 meters.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Robot In Trusted Position.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Argument 8 belongs to the type System Outputs , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Argument 8 is an argument required for some of the system output status values.

td.paragraph: Argument 8 defines the maximum TCP rotation that the external axis can diverge from the programmed path.
Allowed values are 0-6.280, specified in radians. Default value is 1.57 radians.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Robot In Trusted Position.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Task , which belongs to the topic Controller . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
Each set of parameters of the task, type
Task type represents a program task on the controller.
If you have the option Multitasking , there can be up to 20 tasks. Otherwise there can be only one.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
chapter Multitasking .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Task belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the task.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This is the public identity of the task.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 30 characters. The first character may not be a digit.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Editing the task entry in the configuration editor and changing the task name will remove the old task and add a new one. This means that any program or module in the task will disappear after a restart with these kind of changes.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Task in Foreground belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Used to set priorities between tasks.

Task in Foreground contains the name of the task that should run in the foreground of this task. This means that the task for which the parameter is set will only execute if the foreground task is idle.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default behavior is that all tasks run at the same priority level. If you want to customize the priorities, the Task in Foreground parameter can be set for the tasks that should run in the background.
If Task in Foreground is set to empty string, it runs at the highest priority. That is, no other task can suspend its execution.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Task in Foreground can be used only if you have the option Multitasking .
A motion task cannot have another task in the foreground. Any such eventual task set will be ignored.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 30 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Type belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Controls the start/stop and system restart behavior of a task.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: When creating a new task, use the Type parameter to configure how the task should be started.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: A task that controls a mechanical unit must be of the type NORMAL.
The parameter Type can only be used if you have the option Multitasking .

wrapper.title: Allowed values

td.paragraph: The task reacts on START/STOP requests given from the FlexPendant or other sources.
The task is stopped when an emergency stop occurs.
At restart, the task restarts at the current position.
The task is not stopped by emergency stops.
The task is normally not stopped by the stop button on the FlexPendant. This can be configured on the FlexPendant by the operator.
The task restarts from the beginning at all restarts.
The task is not stopped by emergency stops.
The task is normally not stopped by the stop button on the FlexPendant. This can be configured on the FlexPendant by the operator.

wrapper.paragraph: Default value is SEMISTATIC.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Check Unresolved References belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Check Unresolved References determines if the system shall check for unresolved references or ignore them.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter should be set to 0 if the system is to accept unresolved references in the program while linking a module, or otherwise set to 1.
If set to 1, a runtime error will occur on execution of an unresolved reference.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter has no effect when using instructions Load , StartLoad , WaitLoad , or Erase . In this case the system will never check for unresolved references.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: 1 or 0.
Default value is 1.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Main Entry belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the start routine for the task.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The task starts its execution in the routine specified by Main Entry . It should be a RAPID routine without any parameters and reachable in this task.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A routine name, with maximum 32 characters.
Default value is main.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: TrustLevel belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: TrustLevel handles the system behavior when a semistatic or static task is stopped or not executable.

wrapper.title: Usage
