wrapper.paragraph: If a task that handles safety supervision stops, it might be dangerous to continue running the task that controls the robot motion. Use TrustLevel to set the behavior of normal tasks when a semistatic or static task stops.

To simplify debugging of background tasks you can make all tasks (including the background tasks) visible in the task panel on the FlexPendant. Then, in manual mode, all tasks that are selected in the task panel (including background tasks) will stop when pressing the stop button.
See Task Selection Panel Settings in the Control Panel for FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter TrustLevel can only be used if you have the option Multitasking .

wrapper.title: Allowed values

td.paragraph: All normal tasks will be stopped. Besides that the system is set to system failure state (SYS_FAIL). All jogging and program start orders will be rejected. Only a new normal restart resets the system. This should be used when the task has some safety supervisions.
All normal tasks will be stopped. The system is forced to Motors off state. Taking up the system to Motors on resets the system.
All normal tasks will be stopped but are restartable. Jogging is also possible.
Only the task itself will stop.

wrapper.paragraph: The default value is SysFail.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Mechanical Unit Group belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines which mechanical unit group is used for the task.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A motion task ( MotionTask set to Yes) controls the mechanical units in the mechanical unit group. A non-motion task ( MotionTask set to No) will still be able to read values (for example, the TCP position) for the mechanical units in the mechanical unit group. For more information, see Motion Task.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Use Mechanical Unit Group is only used if you have the option MultiMove .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Use Mechanical Unit Group is set to the same value as the parameter Name for the type Mechanical Unit Group . For more information, see Name.
A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: MotionTask belongs to the type Tasks , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Indicates which task is the motion task, e.g. can be able to run RAPID move instructions. MotionTask must be used even though only one task is configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set MotionTask to YES for the task that will be used for robot move instructions.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Only one task in the system can be a motion task unless you have the option MultiMove .
The parameter MotionTask is only used if you have the option Multitasking .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
The default behavior is NO.
The value must be set to YES for one, and only one, task.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual MultiMove
.

Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Hidden belongs to the type Task in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: RAPID tasks may be hidden, which may be used to prevent inexperienced end users from tampering (accidentally deleting or changing) with the contents.
Note that the hidden contents is not protected! It can easily be shown again by setting the parameter value to NO.
Note that any hidden contents will still be available when using the SetDataSearch instruction to search RAPID data.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: Only tasks with Type defined as Static or Semistatic can be hidden. A Normal task cannot be hidden.
This parameter is only available for multitasking systems.
Changes to the parameter will become effective only after using the restart mode Reset RAPID.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
Default value is NO.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Type belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Used for the functionality RAPID Message Queue . RMQ Type defines if the queue of this RAPID task should accept messages from anyone, only other tasks on the same controller, or from no one.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Type can be used to turn off all RAPID Message Queue communication to a RAPID task. It can also be used to limit the communication so that only other RAPID tasks on the same controller may send messages to this task.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter RMQ Type is only used if you have the functionality RAPID Message Queue .

wrapper.title: Allowed values

td.paragraph: Disable the receiving of RAPID Message Queue messages in this RAPID task.
Enable the receiving of RAPID Message Queue messages from other tasks on the controller.
Enable the receiving of RAPID Message Queue messages both from other tasks on the controller, from the FlexPendant and from PC applications.

wrapper.paragraph: The default value is None.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about RAPID Message Queue , see
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Max Message Size belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The maximum data size, in bytes, for a RAPID Message Queue message.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 400, and there is normally no reason to change this value.
The value cannot be changed in RobotStudio. The only way to change the value is to edit the sys.cfg file by adding the attribute RmqMaxMsgSize with the desired value.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter RMQ Max Message Size is only used if you have the functionality RAPID Message Queue .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer between 400 and 3000.
Default value is 400.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about RAPID Message Queue , see
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Max No Of Messages belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum number of RAPID Message Queue messages in the queue to this task.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 5, and there is normally no reason to change this value.
The value cannot be changed in RobotStudio. The only way to change the value is to edit the sys.cfg file by adding the attribute RmqMaxNoOfMsg with the desired value.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter RMQ Max No Of Messages is only used if you have the functionality RAPID Message Queue .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer between 1 and 10.
Default value is 5.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about RAPID Message Queue , see
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Mode belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Used for functionality RAPID Message Queue . RMQ Mode defines which mode the message queue for this task will use.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: RMQ Mode defines the message queue handling should be based on interrupts (data types) or synchronous (all messages are handled).

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter RMQ Mode is only used if you have the functionality RAPID Message Queue .

wrapper.title: Allowed values

td.paragraph: A message can only be received by connecting a trap routine to a specified message type. See instruction IRMQMessage.
A message can only be received by executing an RMQReadWait instruction.

wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Interrupt .

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about RAPID Message Queue , see
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

RAPID instructions are described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

title.phrase: Exclude From Load Modules In AllTasks

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Exclude From Load Modules In AllTasks
Exclude From Load Modules In AllTasks belongs to the type Task , in the topic Controller .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: For the Automatic Loading Of Modules type, RAPID modules can be configured to load AllTask. With this argument it is possible to suppress that for a certain task. If the value of Exclude From Load Modules In AllTasks is set to YES, modules that are set to be loaded AllTask will not be loaded into this task.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: YES or NO.
Default value is NO.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This chapter describes the types and parameters of the I/O System topic. Each parameter is described in the section for its type.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph:
The I/O, topic
I/O System topic contains parameters for I/O devices and signals.
The types and parameters that are specific for the industrial networks are described in the respective application manual.

wrapper.title: Configuration results
wrapper.paragraph: The changed I/O System parameters are effective after a restart of the robot controller.

section.title: How to configure an industrial network

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: There is a systematic way to configure the parameters before actually operating the I/O system. This is an overview of how to configure the industrial networks, I/O devices, and I/O signals in the I/O system. For different industrial network configuration details, refer to the respective application manuals.
The following diagram shows the systematic way of configuring the different parameters to set up the I/O system.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: I/O device is a logical software representation in I/O system of a physical device that is connected to an industrial network handled by the robot controller. I/O devices allow you to control electronic devices and read sensor data. They are used for controlling I/O signals in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Available I/O devices
wrapper.paragraph: Several I/O devices can be defined within the robot system. The types of I/O devices available, depend on what type of industrial network is being used. For more information, see Device.
The following are examples of available I/O devices:

listitem.paragraph: Digital I/O
Analog I/O
AD Combi I/O
Relay I/O
Gateways
Simulated I/O
Encoder interface devices

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Before defining an I/O device, you must:

listitem.paragraph: Configure the industrial network, if necessary.
Make sure the appropriate Device Trust Level is available, either by creating it or using a predefined device trust level. For more information, see Device Trust Level.

wrapper.title: How to define I/O devices
wrapper.paragraph: To define an I/O device:

listitem.paragraph: In the topic I/O System , choose the type Device .
Select the I/O device to change, delete, or add a new one.
Enter, delete, or change the values for the parameters.
Save the changes.
Restart the controller.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: An I/O signal is the logical software representation of a:

listitem.paragraph: Inputs or outputs located on an I/O device that is connected to an industrial network within the robot system (real I/O signal).
An I/O signal without a representation on any I/O device (simulated I/O signal).

wrapper.title: Available input and output I/O signals
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signals can be of different types.
The type of I/O signals available depends on the type of I/O device. Typical I/O signal types on an I/O device are:

listitem.paragraph: Digital inputs and outputs 24 V DC
Digital inputs and outputs 120 V DC
Analog inputs and outputs +10 V
Analog outputs 0 to +10 V

wrapper.paragraph: The I/O signal types possible to configure in the robot system are:

listitem.paragraph: Digital input, DI
Digital output, DO
Analog input, AI
Analog output, AO
Group input, GI
Group output, GO

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum 12000 user I/O signals can be defined in the robot system. This includes digital, analog, and group I/O signals of both input and output type. For more information, see How to define a signal group.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Before defining an I/O signal, you must:

listitem.paragraph: Configure the Device.
Make sure the appropriate Access Level is available, either by creating it or by using a predefined access level.
Make sure the appropriate Safe Level is available, either by creating it or by using a predefined safe level. For more information, see Signal Safe Level.

wrapper.title: How to define I/O signals
wrapper.paragraph: To define I/O signals:

listitem.paragraph: In I/O Engineering Tool, select the I/O device or I/O module to which signals should be assigned.
On the row below the existing signals, add a new signal by completing the empty field Name. Assign properties to the new signal.
Save the changes.
Restart the controller.

section.title: How to define an I/O signal group

wrapper.title: Signal group
wrapper.paragraph: Digital inputs or outputs located on an I/O device can be grouped and handled as one I/O signal in the robot system. The value of such an I/O signal will thus be a positive integer that is binary coded using the individual digital inputs or outputs on the I/O device as a basis.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: When defining I/O signal groups, you have to consider the following limitation in the robot system:

listitem.paragraph: Maximum 32 inputs and outputs located on an I/O device can be defined in an I/O signal group.

wrapper.title: How to define an I/O signal group
wrapper.paragraph: To define an I/O signal group:

listitem.paragraph: In I/O Engineering Tool, select the I/O device or I/O module to which the group signal should be assigned.
Add a new I/O signal, or select an existing I/O signal to be changed or deleted.
Enter, delete, or change the values for the parameters. Set the parameter Type of Signal to value Group Input or Group Output .
The required parameters depend on the type of signal. See parameter descriptions and examples of typical configurations in the description of the type Signal .
Save the changes.
Restart the controller.

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see How to define input and output I/O signals, The Signal type, and Signal Safe Level.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: If an I/O signal group spans over 4 digital inputs on the I/O device, the maximum value is 15 (24-1) and the minimum value is 0.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the Access Level type which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
An access level, type
Access Level type is a configuration that defines the write access to I/O signals for categories of I/O controlling clients connected to the robot controller.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: To limit write access to I/O signals from clients it is necessary to use an access level. The access level settings differentiates local clients (for example, FlexPendant) from remote clients (for example, RobotStudio).

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to configure different write access levels for different remote clients, since the controller does not differentiate, for example, RobotStudio from other remote clients.

td.paragraph: No client has write access, typically used by read only I/O signals.
This access level cannot be changed.
Only allowed to write to signals from RAPID instructions and local clients (for example FlexPendant) in manual mode.
This access level cannot be changed.
All clients, local and remote, have write access.
This access level cannot be changed.
Signals that are installed with access level internal cannot be viewed or accessed from user applications.
This access level cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: In this example, it is possible to modify only I/O signals with this access level with RAPID and local clients in manual mode. Remote clients cannot modify these I/O signals.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Name belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Name specifies the logical name of the access level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the access level is used as a reference to the specific access level when configuring the I/O signals.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Rapid belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Rapid specifies the level of access granted to RAPID instructions.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Specify the level of access that should be granted to RAPID instructions when accessing objects associated with this access level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Read only.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Local Client in Manual Mode belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Local Client in Manual Mode specifies the level of access granted to local RobAPI clients in manual mode.
A local client is a client using RobAPI and is connected directly to the controller, for example the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the level of access that should be granted to local RobAPI clients in manual mode, when accessing objects associated with this access level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Read only.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Local Client in Auto Mode belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Local Client in Auto Mode specifies the level of access granted to local RobAPI clients in automatic mode.
A local client is a client using RobAPI and is connected directly to the controller, for example the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Specify the level of access that should be granted to local RobAPI clients in automatic mode when accessing objects associated with this access level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Read only.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Remote Client in Manual Mode belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Remote Client in Manual Mode specifies the level of access granted to remote RobAPI clients in manual mode.
A remote client is a client or application using RobAPI and not being connected directly to the controller, for example RobotStudio.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Specify the level of access that should be granted to remote RobAPI clients in manual mode when accessing objects associated with this access level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Read only.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Remote Client in Auto Mode belongs to the type Access Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Remote Client in Auto Mode specifies the level of access granted to remote RobAPI clients in automatic mode.
A remote client is a client or application using RobAPI and not being connected directly to the controller, for example RobotStudio.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Specify the level of access that should be granted to remote RobAPI clients in automatic mode when accessing objects associated with this access level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Read only.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Device , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: A device, type device is a logical software representation of a real I/O device that is connected to an industrial network within the controller. I/O devices allow you to control electronic devices and read sensor data. They are used for controlling I/O signals in the robot system.
For internal slave device options, a predefined device is created at startup.
For more information, see Internal Device and Connected to Bus.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: By specifying an I/O device, a logical representation of the real I/O device is created. The I/O device configuration defines the specific parameters that will control the behavior of the I/O device.
The Device is used when defining the I/O signals and device commands in the I/O system.
For more information, see Device Command.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Defining a new I/O device:

listitem.paragraph: Configure the industrial network and
Make sure that the appropriate device trust level is available (either by creating it or using a predefined device trust level).

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see Device Trust Level.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The I/O device has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: Maximum number of user I/O devices in the robot system are 50.
Maximum number of I/O devices on one industrial network is 20 (except for the PROFINET Master/Slave option which allows 50 I/O devices).

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information on safety signals, see
Operating manual OmniCore
.

paragraph.phrase: U137, placed in process cabinet C5

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Name specifies the name of the I/O device.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the I/O device is used as a reference to the specific I/O device when configuring the I/O signals and device commands.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Connected to Industrial Network belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Connected to Industrial Network specifies which industrial network this I/O device is physically connected to.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Identification Label belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Identification Label provides a way to label the real I/O device.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Identification Label is an optional way to provide a label that will help the operator to identify the I/O device physically.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 80 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Trust Level belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Trust Level defines the behavior for I/O devices at different execution situations in the robot controller.

The Trust Level only affects physical devices controlled by an industrial network master in the robot controller. An internal slave device is not controlled by an industrial network master in the robot controller and is therefore not affected by the Trust Level setting.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is used to specify the I/O device behavior as per the user requirements at different error situations in the robot controller.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is DefaultTrustLevel .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string corresponding to the name of a defined Device Trust Level type.
A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: State when System Startup belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter State when System Startup defines which logical state the I/O device shall have after startup of the robot system..

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter State when System Startup value defines the logical state that the robot system shall try to set for the I/O device when system startup. The available options are:

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Activated.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Simulated belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Simulated specifies that the I/O device should be treated as simulated.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Simulated defines that the I/O device is simulated on the industrial network it is connected to.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Fast Device Startup belongs to the type Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Fast Device Startup specifies if the I/O device should use a faster connection attempt algorithm or not.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
The parameter Fast Device Startup is used mainly to speed up tool change applications. The usual PROFINET connection attempt takes a few seconds to complete, but with Fast Device Startup enabled devices, this time is shortened to less than a second. For more information, see
Application manual PROFINET Controller/Device
.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The option 3020-1 PROFINET Controller and 3020-2 PROFINET Device must be installed.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The Ethernet switches between the controller and the I/O device that uses the Fast Device Startup functionality. It must be configured to disable the auto crossover and automatic speed detection functions on used connectors. The speed rate is set to 100Mbps (full duplex).

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Deactivated .
Select Support to set the desired port speed. For port speed, select 100 Mbps and the port speed is adjusted to 100 Mbps , so autonegotiation is turned off for the port.
Hence, it is possible to change the settings on a built-in switch for a PROFINET I/O device.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Device Command , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The Device commands for an I/O device used on a specific industrial network are defined through an industrial network option. Each industrial network needs to use own configuration type specific for the network. Device commands can be used on the following type of industrial networks:

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
The device command, type
Device Command type is used to send device commands to specific I/O devices on the industrial network.
This is done:

listitem.paragraph: At start.
When connecting the I/O device after a power fail.
When activating the I/O device from RobotStudio or the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The Device Command has the following limitations:

listitem.paragraph: Maximum 300 device commands can be defined in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Name specifies the name of the command.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining the name with maximum 80 characters.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Device belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the name of the I/O device the command is connected to.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining the name of the I/O device with maximum 32 characters.
Names that differ only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: The Device type.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Download Order belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Download Order specifies the sequence number in which this command shall be downloaded to the I/O device that have several commands assigned to it.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use Download Order to control the order in which the commands are downloaded (and executed) on an I/O device.
Lower download orders are downloaded before higher download orders.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Path belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Path specifies the network path to the parameter.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining the path with maximum 30 characters.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: Description of example:

listitem.paragraph: 6 is the length of the path - that is, the number of hexadecimal figures until the next comma.
Path (20 01 24 08 30 01) is a software description of DeviceNet class, instance and attribute. A further description can be found in the ODVA DeviceNet Specification 2.0.
C6 is the hexadecimal value for the data type identifier.
1 is the data size - that is, the number of bytes as a hexadecimal value.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Service belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Service defines the explicit service that should be performed on DeviceNet or EtherNet/IP object instance or attribute pointed out in Path . For more information, see Path.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Service is used to define the type of action to be used.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The option DeviceNet Master/Slave or EtherNet/IP must be installed

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Set_Attribute_Single .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Following values are allowed:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Value belongs to the type Device Command , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Value specifies the value for this command.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 200 characters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Device Trust Level , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: Device Trust Level defines the behavior for I/O devices at different execution situations in the robot controller.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Using device trust levels is a simple way to control the behavior of the robot and event generation for I/O devices.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The maximum number of device trust levels handled by the controller is 10.

td.paragraph: Default for an I/O device if nothing else is defined.

listitem.paragraph: there is no system action performed but an error event is reported, when the I/O device is disconnected.
an information event is reported, when the I/O device is reconnected.

td.paragraph: Default for an internal I/O device if nothing else is defined.

listitem.paragraph: there is no system action performed when the I/O device is disconnected.
there is no event reported, when the I/O device is reconnected.
I/O devices with this trust level are not allowed to be deactivated. It is always set to Deny Deactivate .

wrapper.paragraph: InternalDeviceTrustLevel shall only be used for internal devices which cannot be disconnected.

td.paragraph: Default for a safety I/O device if nothing else is defined.

listitem.paragraph: there is no system action performed and no error event is reported, when the I/O device is disconnected.
there is no event reported, when the I/O device is reconnected.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the name of the device trust level.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Deny Deactivate belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies if it is possible to deactivate the I/O device or not.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is Allow Deactivate .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Deny Deactivate or Allow Deactivate

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action when Disconnected belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the system action to perform when the communication with an I/O device is lost.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is No Action

td.paragraph: All NORMAL tasks will be stopped. Besides that, the system is set to system failure state (SYS_FAIL). All jogging and program start orders will be rejected. Only a new normal restart resets the system.
All NORMAL tasks will be stopped. The system is forced to Motors off state. Changing the system to Motors on resets the system.
All NORMAL tasks will be stopped but can be restarted. Jogging is also possible.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Report when Disconnected belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the event reporting when the communication with an I/O device is lost.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action when Faulty belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the system action to perform when the signals are not accessible and I/O device is changed to a bad state.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is No Action

td.paragraph: All NORMAL tasks will be stopped. Besides that, the system is set to system failure state (SYS_FAIL). All jogging and program start orders will be rejected. Only a new normal restart resets the system.
All NORMAL tasks will be stopped. The system is forced to Motors off state. Changing the system to Motors on resets the system.
All NORMAL tasks will be stopped but can be restarted. Jogging is also possible.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Report when Faulty belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the event reporting when an I/O device is changed to bad state.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is Generate Error

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Report when Reconnected belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the event reporting when the communication with an I/O device is re-established again.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is Generate information (state change)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Energy Saving Active belongs to the type Device Trust Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies if the I/O device shall be selected for energy saving or not.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is No.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Internal Device , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: For the internal slave device and the anybus industrial network options, a predefined Internal Device is created at system startup. For more information, see Device Type.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph:
This is an example for a DeviceNet internal slave device. For more information about DeviceNet, refer
Application manual DeviceNet Master/Slave
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Vendor Name belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Vendor Name specifies the name of the I/O device vendor.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is optional and only used as information.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 80 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Product Name belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Product Name specifies the product name for this I/O device according to industrial network type standard.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is optional and only used as information.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 80 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Identification Label belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Identification Label provides a way to label the real I/O device.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Identification Label is an optional way to provide a label that will help the operator to identify the I/O device physically.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 80 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Simulated belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Simulated specifies that the I/O device should be treated as simulated.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Simulated defines that the I/O device is simulated on the industrial network it is connected to.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is No

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Input Size belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Input Size defines the data size in bytes for the input area received from the connected EtherNet/IP scanner.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Input Size is an EtherNet/IP specific parameter.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph:
The option
EtherNet/IP Scanner/Adapter
, Ethernet/IP Anybus Adapter , DeviceNet Master/Slave or DeviceNet Anybus Slave must be installed.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: For option DeviceNet Master/Slave , default value is 8.
For option Ethernet/IP Anybus Adapter , default value is 64

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: For option Ethernet/IP Anybus Adapter , allowed values are the integers 0-255 (0-2040 signal bits), specifying the data size in bytes
For option DeviceNet Master/Slave , allowed values ranges from -1 to 64.

For option
EtherNet/IP Scanner/Adapter
, allowed values ranges from 0 to 505.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Output Size belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Output Size defines the data size in bytes for the output area sent to the connected EtherNet/IP scanner

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Connection Output Size is an EtherNet/IP specific parameter.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph:
The option
EtherNet/IP Scanner/Adapter
, EtherNet/IP Anybus Adapter , DeviceNet Master/Slave or DeviceNet Anybus Slave must be installed.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: For option DeviceNet Master/Slave , default value is 8.
For option EtherNet/IP Anybus Adapter , default value is 64

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: For option EtherNet/IP Anybus Adapter , allowed values are the integers 0-255 (0-2040 signal bits), specifying the data size in bytes
For option DeviceNet Master/Slave and DeviceNet Anybus Slave allowed values ranges from -1 to 64.

For option
EtherNet/IP Scanner/Adapter
, allowed values ranges from 0 to 505.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Input Size belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Input Size is used to configure the input slot configuration of the PROFINET internal device.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: It will configure the input slot size for the PROFINET internal device. This size must match the connecting PLCâs or other PROFINET controllerâs defined output slot size. .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The option PROFINET Controller/Device or PROFINET Device must be installed.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 64 bytes (512 signal bits).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Output Size belongs to the type Internal Device , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Output Size is used to configure the output slot configuration of the PROFINET internal device.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Output Size is only valid for the PN_Internal_Device. It will configure the output slot size for the PROFINET internal device. This size must match the connecting PLCâs or other PROFINET controllerâs defined input slot size. .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The option PROFINET Controller/Device or PROFINET Device must be installed.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 64 bytes (512 signal bits).

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph:
This section describes the type Signal
Signal, type , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: An I/O signal is the logical software representation of:

listitem.paragraph: Inputs or outputs located on an I/O device that is connected to a Industrial Network within the robot system (real I/O signal).
An I/O signal without a representation on any I/O device (simulated I/O signal).

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see The Unit type.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: By specifying an I/O signal, a logical representation of the real or simulated I/O signal is created. The I/O signal configuration defines the specific system parameters for the I/O signal that will control the behavior of the I/O signal.
Many of the parameters depend on the type of the I/O signal, therefore it is recommended that the parameter Type of Signal is assigned first.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Before defining a new I/O signal, make sure that the appropriate Signal Safe Level and Access Level are available (either by creating them or using a predefined Signal Safe Level and Access Level respectively). For more information, see The Access Level type and Signal Safe Level.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: A maximum of 12000 user I/O signals can be defined in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Predefined signals
wrapper.paragraph: There are a number of predefined I/O signals in the robot controller. Depending on installed options there can also be other predefined I/O signals.

wrapper.title: Example digital input
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of a digital input I/O signal (DI).

wrapper.title: Example analog output
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of an analog output I/O signal (AO).

wrapper.title: Example group input
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of a group input I/O signal (GI).

wrapper.title: Example simulated digital input
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of a simulated digital input I/O signal (DI).

wrapper.title: Example simulated analog output
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of an simulated analog output I/O signal (AO).

wrapper.title: Example simulated group input
wrapper.paragraph: The following is a typical example of a simulated group input I/O signal (GI).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Name specifies the name of the logical I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the I/O signal is used as a reference to the specific I/O signal when:

listitem.paragraph: Accessing the I/O signal (that is reading or writing its value) in RAPID.

Configuring cross connections, for more information, see
Application manual I/O Engineering
.
Configuring system inputs and system outputs, for more information, see The System Input type and The System Output type.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Type of Signal belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Type of Signal specifies the signal's representation, behavior, and direction.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Each I/O signal must be classified as one of the predefined types. The type of I/O signal will determine the behavior of the I/O signal as well as how it will be represented and interpreted.

As the behavior of the I/O signal depends upon its type, the settings of other parameters will vary, therefore it is recommended that the Type of Signal parameter is assigned before any other parameter for the I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Assigned to Device belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Assigned to Device specifies which I/O device the I/O signal is connected to (if any). For more information, see The Unit type.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: An I/O signal that is not mapped against an I/O device (that is Assigned to Device is not defined) will be considered as simulated.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string, either:

listitem.paragraph: Empty (unspecified), that is a simulated I/O signal, or
Defining the name of a defined I/O device.

wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Identification Label belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Signal Identification Label provides a free-text label to an I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Identification Label is optional for use in providing a label for the physical contact or cable that this I/O signal configuration represents.

Assign an easy-to-understand name (free text) to the I/O signal to make it easy to physically identify. For example, map the I/O signal to a physical identification such as a cable marking or an outlet label.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string of maximum 80 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Device Mapping belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Device Mapping specifies which bit(s) in the I/O memory map of the assigned I/O device, the I/O signal is mapped to.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: All I/O signals except simulated I/O signals must be mapped.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: An I/O signal must be completely mapped to bits on the same I/O device. For example, it is not possible to map a group signal to bits on different I/O devices.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 80 characters.
The string should contain the mapping order of the individual bits of the I/O signal, using the following syntax:

listitem.paragraph: Refer to a bit in the I/O memory map by the index of the bit, the bits are indexed from 0 (zero) and upwards.
If the I/O signal is mapped to several continuous bits, these can be given as a range: <first bit in range> - <last bit in range>
If the I/O signal is mapped to several discontinuous bits and/or ranges, these should be separated by commas: <bit/range>, <bit/range>, <bit/range>

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Overlapping of device maps is not recommended. That is, the Device Mapping must not refer to the same bit more than once. A lot of unwanted scenarios can appear when different logical signals are mapping on the same physical bit.
One example is if two overlapping group signals are used in one cross connection where one is actor and inverted and one is resultant. This scenario will cause an endless loop.
Restrictions for overlapping signals is necessary because of the importance to have predictability in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed with restrictions
wrapper.paragraph: The following rules are present for overlapping signals of type:

listitem.paragraph: Group Output/Digital Output
Group Input/Digital Input
Group Output/Group Output
Group Input/Group Input

wrapper.paragraph: The overlapping signals are allowed with the following restrictions:

listitem.paragraph:
Overlapping signals must have the same parameter value for Signal Safe Level
ActionWhenStartup .
The Signal Safe Level parameter ActionWhenStartup ( Default ) must be consistent on the overlapping bit(s) level.
It is not allowed to have two overlapping signals where one signal is actor and one signal is resultant in a cross connection.

wrapper.title: Allowed with event log warning
wrapper.paragraph: The following rules are present for overlapping signals but with an event log warning.

listitem.paragraph: Group Output/Analog Output
Group Input/Analog Input
Digital Output/Analog Output
Digital Input/Analog Input
Analog Output/Analog Output
Analog Input/Analog Input

wrapper.paragraph: Overlapping of analog signals with digital or group signals is not recommended due to the complexity in comparing a scalable value with a bit value.

wrapper.title: Not allowed
wrapper.paragraph: The following overlapping signals are not allowed:

listitem.paragraph: Digital Input/Digital Input
Digital Output/Digital Output

wrapper.title: Allowed size of the signal

listitem.paragraph: Digital signals must be mapped to exactly one bit.

Analog signals must be mapped between 2 and 32 bits
A simulated analog I/O signal is by default mapped to 23 bits but the number of bits can be defined by the I/O signal configuration parameter Number Of Bits . .

Group signals must be mapped between 1 and 32 bits
A simulated group I/O signal is by default mapped to 23 bits but the number of bits can be defined by the I/O signal configuration parameter Number Of Bits . .

wrapper.paragraph: For safety group signals, the Device Mapping will automatically be rearranged when Number Of Bits is selected. The signal with the highest size will be placed first, and the signal with the lowest size placed last.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: Examples of valid mapping of a digital signal (1 bit):
Examples of valid mapping of an analog or group signal (2-32 bits):
Example of invalid mapping (bit 7 is overlapped):

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Category belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Category provides a free-text categorization to an I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Category is optional to use for categorizing the I/O signals so that tools (for example software tools) can filter and sort signals based on these categories.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: I/O signals defined as Safety or Internal are hidden for the user in RobotStudio and FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The category of all safety-related I/O signals (internally loaded by the system) are set to Safety.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Access Level belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System . For more information, see The Access Level type.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Access Level specifies which clients have write access to the I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Access Level defines the write access of the I/O signal for different categories of I/O controlling applications, such as RobotStudio and RAPID programs.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Default.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string corresponding to the name of a defined Access Level type.
A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Default Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Default Value specifies the I/O signal default value.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value:

listitem.paragraph: is used for initializing the I/O signal at different execution situation in the robot system, see Signal Safe Level.
is used for the evaluation of cross connections whenever the I/O signal is not accessible, that is for example when the I/O device to which the I/O signal is assigned is disconnected.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to set digital input values on a real I/O device unless it is Simulated . Even the Default Value set for a digital input in the configuration file will not get reflected after loading it to the controller.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Depending on the type of I/O signal, the following values are allowed:

td.paragraph: Any value in the range Minimum Logical Value to Maximum Logical Value . For more information, see Minimum Logical Value and Maximum Logical Value.
Any value in the range 0 to 2size-1 (size = number of bits in the Device Mapping parameter or in the Number Of Bits parameter for simulated group signals). For more information, see Device Mapping.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: For I/O signals mapped against the same bits in the I/O memory map, there are certain limitations. For more information, refer to Additional information in Device Mapping.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Safe Level belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System . For more information, see Signal Safe Level.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Safe Level specifies the behavior of logical output I/O signals at different execution situations in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is used to specify the logical output signal behavior as per the user requirements at different execution situation like system startup, when signal becomes accessible, signal is not accessible and system shutdown.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is DefaultSafeLevel.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Filter Time Passive belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System . For more information, see Filter Time Active and Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Filter Time Passive specifies the filter time for detection of negative flanks (that is I/O signal physical value goes from active to passive).

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The passive filter time filters I/O signals from noise that could otherwise be interpreted as a pulse of the I/O signal.

The passive filter time specifies the period in ms (milliseconds) that the physical value of the I/O signal must remain passive before the I/O signal will be considered passive and the logical I/O signal is changed to passive, that is if the time period that the physical value is passive is shorter than Filter Time Passive , the logical signal is not changed.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is applicable on digital input and group input I/O signals only, that is Type of Signal must be set to one of these types or this parameter will be ignored.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Note that many I/O devices have built-in hardware for filtering I/O signals. This filter time is then added to the value of Filter Time Passive .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Filter Time Active belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System . For more information, see Filter Time Active and Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Filter Time Active specifies the filter time for detection of positive flanks (that is I/O signal physical value goes from passive to active).

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The active filter time filters I/O signals from noise that could otherwise be interpreted as a pulse of the I/O signal.

The active filter time specifies the period in ms (milliseconds) that the physical value of the I/O signal must remain active before the I/O signal will be considered active and the logical I/O signal is changed to active, that is if the time period that the physical value is active is shorter than Filter Time Active , the logical I/O signal is not changed.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is applicable on digital input and group input I/O signals only, that is Type of Signal must be set to one of these types or this parameter will be ignored.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Note that many devices have built-in hardware for filtering I/O signals. This filter time is then added to the value of Filter Time Active .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Invert Physical Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Invert Physical Value specifies whether the physical representation should be the inverted of the logical representation.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use this parameter to apply an inversion between the physical value of the I/O signal and its logical representation in the system.

listitem.paragraph: The logical value of an input I/O signal will be the inversion of its physical value
The physical value of an output I/O signal will be the inversion of its logical value.

wrapper.paragraph: Inverting a group I/O signal will make each individual bit in the group inverted.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable on digital or group I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to one of these types or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Analog Encoding Type belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Analog Encoding Type specifies how the value of an analog I/O signal is interpreted.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use this parameter to specify if the physical representation of an analog I/O signal should be interpreted as a signed (twos complement) or unsigned value.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable on analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Two complement.

td.paragraph: If the physical analog range for a specific I/O signal is symmetric around 0, for example -32768 to +32767, the I/O signal is most likely coded as Two complement.
Unsigned is used for I/O signals ranging from 0 and upwards.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum Logical Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Maximum Logical Value specifies the logical value that will correspond to the Maximum Physical Value .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The logical values offer a way to access the I/O signals (for example through RAPID programs) by using logical quantities rather than physical.

By setting up the extremes (minimum and maximum values) of the logical and physical values the system will be able to calculate scale and offset factors for transforming I/O signal values between the different quantities.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be greater than the value of the Minimum Logical Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: If both Minimum Logical Value and Maximum Logical Value are set to zero (0), the logical values will be directly mapped against the physical values:

listitem.paragraph: minimum logical value = minimum physical value (For more information, see Minimum Logical Value and Minimum Physical Value.)
maximum logical value = maximum physical value (For more information, see Maximum Logical Value and Maximum Physical Value.)

wrapper.paragraph: Hence there is no scaling or offset factor between the logical and physical representation of the value of an I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The logical value is a representation of a signal that makes it possible to handle the signal in quantities known from the real world feature it corresponds to rather than the physical value used to control it. For example it would be more natural to set the speed of a moving axis in mm/s (the logical value) rather than the amount of voltage needed to attain that speed (the physical value).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum Physical Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Maximum Physical Value specifies the physical value that will correspond to the Maximum Bit Value .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The physical value directly corresponds to the value of the I/O signal that this system parameter corresponds to, for example the amount of voltage given by a sensor or the current feed into a manipulator.

By setting up the extremes (minimum and maximum values) of the bit and physical values the system will be able to calculate scale and offset factors for transforming signal values between the bit and physical quantities.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to one of the analog signal types or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be greater than the value of the Minimum Physical Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: If both Minimum Physical Value and Maximum Physical Value are set to zero (0), the physical values will be directly mapped against the bit values:

listitem.paragraph: minimum physical value = minimum bit value, (for more information, see Minimum Physical Value and Minimum Bit Value.)
maximum physical value = maximum bit value, (for more information, see Maximum Physical Value and Maximum Bit Value.)

wrapper.paragraph: Hence there is no scaling or offset factor between the physical and bit representation of the value of an I/O signal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum Physical Value Limit belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Maximum Physical Value Limit specifies the maximum allowed physical value, acting as a working range limiter.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Maximum Physical Value Limit limits the allowed maximum physical value, for example if a bit or logical value is given that would exceed this limit, the physical value is automatically adjusted to Maximum Physical Value Limit .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be greater than the value of the Minimum Physical Value Limit .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: If both Minimum Physical Value Limit and Maximum Physical Value Limit are set to zero (0), the physical value limits will be directly mapped against the physical values:

listitem.paragraph: minimum physical value limit = minimum physical value, (for more information, see Minimum Physical Value Limit.)
maximum physical value limit = maximum physical value, (for more information, see Maximum Physical Value.)

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum Bit Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Maximum Bit Value specifies the bit value that will correspond to the Maximum Logical Value . For more information, see Maximum Logical Value.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The bit value is the I/O signalâs representation when transmitted on the network.
The bit value is used when calculating the physical and logical values. For more information, see Maximum Physical Value.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be greater than the value of the Minimum Bit Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: If both Minimum Bit Value and Maximum Bit Value are set to zero (0) then the bit values will be calculated based on the selected Analog Encoding Type . For more information, see Minimum Bit Value and Analog Encoding Type.
If Analog Encoding Type is set to Twos complement:

listitem.paragraph: maximum bit value = 2(no of bits in Device Mapping)-1-1
minimum bit value = 2(no of bits in Device Mapping)-1

wrapper.paragraph: If Analog Encoding Type is set to Unsigned:

listitem.paragraph: maximum bit value = 2(no of bits in Device Mapping)-1
minimum bit value = 0

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Minimum Logical Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Minimum Logical Value specifies the logical value that will correspond to the Minimum Physical Value . For more information, see Minimum Physical Value.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
See
Maximum Logical Value
.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog I/O signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be less than the value of the Maximum Logical Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Minimum Physical Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Minimum Physical Value specifies the physical value that will correspond to the Minimum Logical Value .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: See Maximum Physical Value .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to one of the analog I/O signal types or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be less than the value of the Maximum Physical Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph:
See
Maximum Physical Value
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Minimum Physical Value Limit belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Minimum Physical Value Limit specifies the minimum allowed physical value, hence it acts as a working range limiter.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: See Maximum Physical Value Limit .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog I/O signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be less than the value of the Maximum Physical Value Limit .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph:
See
Maximum Physical Value Limit
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Minimum Bit Value belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Minimum Bit Value specifies the bit value that will correspond to the Minimum Logical Value .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
See
Maximum Bit Value
.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to analog I/O signals, that is Type of Signal must be set to an analog I/O signal type or this parameter will be ignored. For more information, see Type of Signal.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value must be less than the value of the Maximum Bit Value .

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: See Maximum Bit Value .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Number Of Bits belongs to the type Signal , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Number Of Bits specifies the number of bits used for simulated group I/O signals.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Can be used to specify the number of bits to be used for simulated group I/O signals.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only applicable to group I/O signals not assigned to any I/O device, simulated I/O signals. For more information, see Device Mapping.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 23.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Signal Safe Level , which belongs to the topic I/O System . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Signal Safe Level defines the behavior of logical output, digital, group and analog signals at different execution situations in the robot system. For more information, see Safe Level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Safe Level is used to define the behavior of the logical output signals in different execution situations in the robot system like system startup, when signal becomes accessible, signal is not accessible and system is shutdown. It is user defined and makes the signal behavior more flexible, user friendly at different situation.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The maximum number of signal safe levels handled by the robot system is 10.

td.paragraph: This is the default signal safe level.

listitem.paragraph: the signal is using its default value, when system startup and when the signal becomes not accessible.
when the signal becomes accessible and the system is shutdown, the signal takes the last written value.

td.paragraph: This signal safe level cannot be changed.
For more information, see Default Value.
This is the safety signal safe level. It is used by safety signals in the robot system.

listitem.paragraph: the signal is using its default value when system startup and when the signal becomes accessible or not accessible.
when the system is shutdown, the signal safe level takes the last written value.

td.paragraph: This signal safe level cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: This is an example of a signal safe level.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Signal Safe Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the name of the signal safe level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the signal safe level is used as a reference to the specific signal behavior when configuring the logical output signals.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is an empty string.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

The string must follow the RAPID rules described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Overview
.
The name must be unique among all named objects in the I/O system configuration.
Names differing only in upper and lower case are considered to be equal.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action When Startup belongs to the type Signal Safe Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the value for a logical output signal after startup of the robot system.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Set default value, for more information, see Default Value.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: For logical ouput signals mapped against the same bits in the I/O memory map, there are certain limitations. For example, logical output signals of type Digital Output mapped on Group Output. To prevent unpredictable signal values for these logical output signals at system startup, the conditions are:

listitem.paragraph: The logical output signals must have the same value for the parameter Action When Startup .
If the parameter Action When Startup use the value Set default value, the defined default value must match for each logical output signal on a bitwise level.
