wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see Device Mapping.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action when Signal Accessible belongs to the type Signal safe Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the value for a logical output signal when its physical state becomes accessible.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Set last value

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Set default value, for more information, see Default Value.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action when Signal Not Accessible belongs to the type Signal Safe Level , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the value for a logical output signal when its physical state becomes not accessible.

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: Set default value, for more information, see Default Value.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Action when System Shutdown belongs to the type Signal SafeLevel , in the topic I/O System .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Specifies the value for a logical output signal when the robot system is shutdown.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Set default value, for more information, Default Value.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This chapter describes the types and parameters of the Man-machine communication topic.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph:
The man-machine communication
Man-machine communication topic contains parameters for, among other things, creating customized lists for instructions and I/O signals, simplifying everyday work.
The types for Most Common Instructions are identical and therefore only described in one section, but valid for all three types.

section.title:
The Backup Settings type
Backup Settings, type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Backup Settings which belongs to the topic Man-machine communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The Backup Settings shall be configured when the FlexPendant backup application shall suggest a specific name or path for the backup, or when the user shall be prevented from changing these settings in the FlexPendant backup application.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Only one set of parameters of the type Backup Settings can be configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Backup Settings , in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the suggested name for the backups created from the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the backup.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining the name.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The suggested name is not defined only by this parameter. If Unique Name is set to Yes and if a backup already exists with the same name, an increasing number is added to the end of the name. For more information, see Unique name.
If the Name parameter is undefined, the default backup name SystemName_Backup_Date (for example, SystemX_Backup_20100101) is suggested.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Path belongs to the type Backup Settings , in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Path defines the suggested path for the backups created from the FlexPendant.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The path for the backup.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string defining the path.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If the Path parameter is undefined, the default backup path BACKUP is suggested.

wrapper.title: Example 1
wrapper.paragraph: The environment variable BACKUP can be used.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Unique name belongs to the type Backup Settings , in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Unique name defines if the backup shall be overwritten or get a unique name if it already exists a backup with name Name .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A unique name is suggested if the value of Unique name is set to Yes. An increasing number is added at the end of the name if a backup with the same name already exists. The user will get the option to overwrite the old backup if the value of Unique name is set to No and if a backup with the same name already exists.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Disable name change belongs to the type Backup Settings , in the topic Man-machine communication.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Disable name change prevents the users from changing the name and the path from the FlexPendant backup application.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Setting the value of the Disable name change parameter to Yes prevents the users from changing the suggested name and path in the FlexPendant backup application.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
The default value is No.

section.title: The Block IO in MotorsOff type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Block IO in MotorsOff which belongs to the topic Man-machine communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The type Block IO in MotorsOff enables a function that blocks changes of I/O signals in manual mode unless the controller is in motors on state. This restriction is only applicable in RobotStudio I/O views. This is not a safety function, and does not guarantee that a signal is not changed on the controller when the I/O view is blocked.
The controller does not need to be restarted for this functionality to take effect.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This function is useful to restrict incidental changes on the I/O of the controller when the robot cell is not ready. As it causes unexpected behavior of the robot or connected devices.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: There can be only one instance of the type Block IO in MotorsOff in the system. The name of the instance must not be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Enabled belongs to the type Block IO in MotorsOff , in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Set Enabled to True to activate the function Block IO in MotorsOff .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: True or False.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 which belongs to topic Man-machine communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The system contains lists of instructions to use when programming the robot. There are also three lists available to adapt to personal requirements. These are called most common instruction, type
Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 .
The three lists are set up of a number of parameters equal between the lists. Therefore the parameters are described together in this manual.

wrapper.title: Required parameters
wrapper.paragraph: Only the system parameter Name requires a value.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Instructions and their optional arguments and syntax are described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Example: Instruction without argument
wrapper.paragraph: To create a MoveJ instruction without arguments, only the parameter Name is required if Name is set to MoveJ , exactly as spelled in RAPID.

wrapper.title: Example: Instruction with argument
wrapper.paragraph: To create a MoveL instruction with the option Time set to the alternative T for motion tasks, use the following values.

By setting Name to MoveL/T, the button label in the picklist will clearly state to the user that this is a MoveL instruction, using the Time option. The parameter number we use is 5, see table below, and we use alternative 2 for [\T]. Since Name is not set to only MoveL , we must use Instruction Name to specify to the system that it is a MoveL instruction. Only for Motion Task states that it will only be available for motion tasks.
The syntax for the MoveL instruction is:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name to be visible on the button in the picklist.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Name is set to an instruction or procedure spelled exactly as in RAPID, no other parameters require a value. But, if Name contains more information, as recommended when using instructions with arguments, then the parameter Instruction Name specifies the actual instruction syntax. For more information, see Instruction Name.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The instruction name, a string with maximum 32 characters, e.g. "MoveJ".
Do not use a backslash (\) in the name! Names using a backslash will cause errors, unlike when programming in RAPID.

If an additional switch or argument is used, it is recommended to include this in the name for clarity and append the name with a slash (/) and the argument, e.g. "ArcL/On". Furthermore if an optional argument is included in the name then the parameter Instruction Name must be set to the instruction.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

td.paragraph: The instruction ArcL with the argument On .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Parameter Number belongs to the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 in the topic Man-machine communication . For more information, see Instruction Name.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Parameter Number specifies which argument should be used for instructions with optional arguments.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
If an instruction with optional arguments is used, then Parameter Number specifies which of the arguments should be used. The instructions with parameter numbers are described in
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.
If left blank, no optional argument is used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A positive integer value, starting from 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: If Parameter Number is used, then Alternative Number must also be used. For more information, see Alternative Number.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Alternative Number belongs to the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 in the topic Man-machine communication . For more information, see Instruction Name.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Alternative Number defines which of the optional argument's alternatives to be used for the instruction.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If the instruction has optional arguments, then Alternative Number specifies which of the alternatives to use. The Parameter Number specifies which argument to be used. For more information, see Parameter Number.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Parameter Number must be used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed (depending on the number of alternatives available for the instruction):

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Instruction Name belongs to the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Instruction Name defines which instruction to use if the parameter Name contains more information than only the instruction. For more information, see Name.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If the instruction contains optional arguments, it is recommended to mark this in the parameter Name. Then Instruction Name is used to specify the instruction, as spelled in RAPID.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The instruction name, a string with maximum 32 characters, as spelled in RAPID.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Only for Motion Task belongs to the types Most Common Instruction - List 1 , Most Common Instruction - List 2 , and Most Common Instruction - List 3 in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Only for Motion Task defines if the instruction only should be visible in Motion Tasks, i.e. should control the robot movement, e.g. MoveJ .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Only for Motion Task to True if the instruction only should be visible to Motion Tasks.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: True or False.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

section.title: The Most Common I/O Signal type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Most Common I/O Signal which belongs to the topic Man-machine communication . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
It is possible to have hundreds of I/O signals in the system. To simplify working with them it is possible to group them to a list of the mostly used signals. This list is defined by the type most common I/O signal, type
Most Common I/O Signal .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A signal must be configured in the system for the signal name.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: This is a typical example of an often used I/O to be included in the list.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Name belongs to the type Most Common I/O Signal , in the topic Man-machine communication . For more information, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The Signal Name is the I/O signal to be part of the Most Common List.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A signal must be configured in the system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A signal configured in the system, a name with a maximum of 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Type belongs to the type Most Common I/O Signal , in the topic Man-machine communication .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Signal Type defines the type of signal to be used in the common list.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The following values are allowed.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This chapter describes the types and parameters of the Motion topic. Each parameter is described in the section for its type.
The topic Motion is extensive, with some 40 types. This manual revision covers the most commonly used parameters and types.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph:
motion, topic
Motion contains parameters associated with motion control in the robot and external equipment. The topic includes configuring the calibration offset and the working space limits.

wrapper.title: Configuration results
wrapper.paragraph: Changed motion parameters requires a restart of the controller. Otherwise the changes will not have any effect on the system.
An exception to the rule is the motion supervision parameters which do not require a restart. See the type Motion Supervision section for more information.

wrapper.title: The robot and the base frame
wrapper.paragraph: Normally, the base frame of the robot coincides with the world frame. However, the base frame can be moved relative to the world frame.
The programmed positions are always related to the world frame. Therefore, all positions are also moved, as seen from the robot.

wrapper.title: How to define the base frame
wrapper.paragraph: To define the base frame:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Robot .
Select the robot to define the base frame for.
Edit the parameters defining the base frame:
For detailed information about each parameter, see the descriptions in The Robot type.
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The illustration shows some examples of frame definitions.

wrapper.title: The robot and the gravity
wrapper.paragraph: Normally, the gravity does not need to be defined when the robot is mounted on the floor or parallel to the floor. However, the robot can be mounted, for example, on a wall or upside down. In these cases, the robot orientation relative to the gravity needs to be defined.

wrapper.title: How to define the gravity
wrapper.paragraph: To define the gravity:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Robot .
Select the robot to define the gravity for.
Edit the parameters defining the gravity:
Gravity Alpha , for more information, see Gravity Alpha.
Gravity Beta , for more information, see Gravity Beta.

If both angles are needed to describe the robot orientation then the orientation is described by first rotating the robot around X in the base coordinate system with the Gravity Alpha parameter and then around Y in the rotated coordinate system with Gravity Beta parameter.
For detailed information about each parameter, see the descriptions in the Robot type section.
Save the changes.

section.title: How to restrict the work area for articulated robots

wrapper.title: Robot work area
wrapper.paragraph: The work area for an articulated robot is restricted by limiting the working range for the axes. The work area can also be restricted using hardware stops.
To restrict the robot work area for articulated robots:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Arm .
Select the arm to edit.
Edit the parameters Upper Joint Bound and Lower Joint Bound to set the respective limit of the work area for this joint in radians. For more information, see Upper Joint Bound and Lower Joint Bound.
Save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see How to restrict the work area for parallel arm robots.

section.title: How to restrict the work area for parallel arm robots

wrapper.title: Robot work area
wrapper.paragraph: The work area for a parallel arm robot is restricted by defining a cube in which the TCP0 is allowed to move.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.347in 1.736in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: Lower work area x, y, z
Upper work area x, y, z

wrapper.paragraph: The coordinates are defined in the base coordinate system and the work area is checked with respect to the predefined tool, tool0. It is not possible to check the position with respect to another tool.
To restrict the robot work area for parallel arm robots:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Robot .
Edit the parameters Upper Work Area and Lower Work Area for the coordinates x, y, and z. For more information, see Upper Work Area x, y, z and Lower Work Area x, y, z.
Save the changes.

wrapper.paragraph: The system parameters that define the work area for parallel robot are valid only for IRB 340 and IRB 360 robots.
For more information, see How to restict the work area for articulated robot.

section.title: How to define arm check point

wrapper.title: Arm check point
wrapper.paragraph: If an extra load, such as a transformer or a welding-bar roller, is attached to arm 3, a point on this equipment can be defined as a check point. The robot will then monitor the speed of this point so that it does not exceed 250 mm/s in manual reduced speed mode.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=5.522in 2.111in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=-1.760in; yoffset=-0.097in

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The value for the Use Check Point parameter must be identical to the name used for the arm check point.

wrapper.title: Bound check point
wrapper.paragraph: The check point can also be restricted to stay outside a defined cube, when the robot is moving. The cube is defined by six coordinates, three upper and three lower, see illustration, all being related to the robot base coordinate system. Thus the defined cube will work as a stationary world zone, where the inside of the cube is the forbidden area for the arm check point.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.582in 1.910in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

td.paragraph: Lower check point bound x, y, z
Upper check point bound x, y, z

wrapper.title: How to define arm check point
wrapper.paragraph: To define the arm check point:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Arm Check Point .
Edit the parameters for the check point.
For detailed information, see The Arm Check Point type.
Make a note of the Name parameter value to use later.
Save the changes.
In the topic Motion , choose the type Arm .
First select arm 3 to connect the check point to the arm. Then edit the parameter Use Check Point . The value has to be identical to the name used for the arm check point (step 2-3 above).
For detailed information, see The Arm type.
Save the changes.
To restrict the check point, choose the type Robot in the topic Motion .
Edit the parameters Upper Check Point Bound and Lower Check Point Bound for the six coordinates.
For detailed information about the parameters, see section Robot type.
For detailed information, see Upper Checkpoint Bound x, y, z and Lower Checkpoint Bound x, y, z.
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: The Product manual for the robot.

wrapper.title: Arm load
wrapper.paragraph: The arm load is used for defining loads from equipment mounted on robot arms. If the arm load is not defined when equipment is mounted on the robot arms, the performance of the robot is negatively affected.
For more information about arm loads, see the type Arm Load .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The mass, the mass center, and the moment of inertia of the load have to be measured or calculated before defining the arm load.

wrapper.title: Arms for relating arm load to
wrapper.paragraph: The arm loads can be related to all arms of the robot. For the arms 1, 2, and 3, see the following illustration. Generally all loads are defined according to its joint intersection. The y coordinate is relative to the center of the robot base. The load for arm 4 is an exception and is defined according to the joint intersection for axis 3 in the synchronization position. The load for track motion is defined according to the robot base frame.

td.paragraph:
View from back, yb
zb for the robot base

wrapper.paragraph: If more than one load is mounted on the same arm, the total weight and the center of gravity for the loads have to be calculated.

wrapper.title: How to define an arm load
wrapper.paragraph: To define an arm load:

listitem.paragraph: In the topic Motion , choose the type Arm Load .
Select the arm load to define, or create a new.
Enter or change the parameters of the arm load and save your changes. It is not necessary to restart the system at this point.
For detailed information about each parameter, see The Arm Load type.
In the topic Motion , choose the type Arm and select the arm that the load is mounted on.
For detailed information, see The Arm type.
For the selected arm, choose the Use Arm Load parameter and select the name of the arm load in the list of defined loads.
Save the changes and restart the system.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
The service routine LoadIdentify is described in
Operating manual OmniCore
.

section.title: How to optimize drive system parameters

wrapper.title: The drive system parameters
wrapper.paragraph: The drive system can be configured so that it corresponds to the robot's installation. The parameters related to the drive system are organized in two types.

td.paragraph: ... use the parameters of the type
tolerance for the mains power supply

wrapper.title: Default and optimal values
wrapper.paragraph: All drive system parameters have nominal values after installation. For improving the robot's performance, these parameters can be adjusted according to the robot's actual installation.
Parameter settings outside the range of the robot's installation may negatively affect the robot's performance.

wrapper.title: How to optimize the mains tolerance
wrapper.paragraph: To optimize the tolerance for the mains power supply:

listitem.paragraph: In the topic Motion , choose the type Mains .
Edit the Mains Tolerance Min parameter according to the robot's installation.
For detailed information about each parameter, see The Mains type.
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Example to show how the mains tolerance can affect the robot performance
wrapper.paragraph: The systems with 220-230V single phase mains can be optimized using the mains tolerance. For example, for the IRB140T 6kg robot with the default settings 220V mains and mains tolerance min -0.15, the max speed for the corresponding joints become as shown in the following table.

Setting the mains tolerance min to 0.0 means to have a mains of 220V single phase. At 230V this is equivalent to 230V -4.3%. For more detailed performance data, see the respective robot product specification.

Changing the mains tolerance min can create a situation where the system stops due to a too low DC-bus voltage, rectifier saturation, or some other error code. In this case the tolerance must be increased.

wrapper.title: Motion supervision
wrapper.paragraph: Motion supervision is functionality for collision detection with the option Collision detection.

wrapper.title: How to tune the motion supervision
wrapper.paragraph: To tune the motion supervision:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Motion Supervision .
For more information, see The Motion Supervision type.
Decide which robot to tune the supervision for.
Edit the parameters for motion supervision. For detailed information about each parameter, see the descriptions in the type Motion Supervision .
Save the changes.

section.title: How to define transmission gear ratio for independent joints

wrapper.title: Transmission gear ratio
wrapper.paragraph: An independent joint can rotate in one direction for a long time, resetting the measurement system regularly. A small round-off in the transmission gear ratio can build up to large errors over time. The transmission gear ratio must therefore be given as an exact fraction (for example, 10/3 instead of 3.3333).
Define the transmission gear ratio by setting Transmission Gear High to the numerator and Transmission Gear Low to the denominator.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameters Transmission Gear High and Transmission Gear Low are only useful if you have the RobotWare option Independent Axes .
When a joint is not in independent mode, it uses the parameter Transmission Gear Ratio instead of Transmission Gear High and Transmission Gear Low .

wrapper.title: How to calculate transmission gear ratio
wrapper.paragraph: If the proportions for the transmission gear ratio are complex, count the cogs to get the exact ratio.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=3.156in 3.038in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: In the illustration, the total transmission gear ratio is:

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=0.726in 0.347in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: N1, N2, n1 and n2 represent the number of cogs on each gearwheel.
To get an exact representation of the transmission gear ratio:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Transmission .
Decide which for joint to define the transmission gear ratio.
Set the parameter Transmission Gear High to the value N1 x N2.
Set the parameter Transmission Gear Low to the value n1 x n2.

wrapper.paragraph: For detailed information, see The Transmission type.

wrapper.title: External torque
wrapper.paragraph: When external equipment, for example a cable or a coiled hose, affects any joint significantly, the external torque should be defined using the following formula:
T = external torque [Nm]
A = constant torque [Nm]
k = scale factor for position dependent torque [Nm]
Î¸ 0= joint position when position dependent torque is zero [rad]

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=2.288in 1.340in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.paragraph: If the estimated value of a significant external torque is too low, there can be unnecessary path deviations and the manipulator might be damaged. If the estimated value is too high, the performance of the manipulator is reduced due to restrictive acceleration limits.

wrapper.title: How to define external torque
wrapper.paragraph: To define external torque:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Arm .
For more information, see The Arm type.
Select the arm to edit.
Set the desired values for the parameters External Const Torque , External Proportional Torque , and External Torque Zero Angle .
For more information, see External Const Torque, External Proportional Torque, and External Torque Zero Angle.
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: A coiled hose is mounted and affects joint 6 as follows:
0 Nm at 0 degrees.
5 Nm at 200 degrees.
This external torque can be defined using the following formula: A = 0, Î¸ 0 = 0, k = 5 / (200 Ã (pi / 180))

wrapper.title: Supervision level
wrapper.paragraph: It is possible to change the default supervision levels if a system needs to be more or less tolerant to external disturbances. A higher tune factor than 1.0 gives a more tolerant robot system, and vice versa. For example, increasing the tune factor from 1.0 to 2.0, doubles the allowed supervision levels, which makes the robot system more tolerant to external disturbances.
Increasing the tune factors can reduce the lifetime of the robot.

wrapper.title: How to define the supervision level
wrapper.paragraph: To define the supervision level:

listitem.paragraph: In the Motion topic, choose the type Arm .
For more information, see The Arm type.
Select the arm to change.

For the selected arm, set the desired values of the parameters Jam Supervision Trim Factor , Load Supervision Trim Factor , Speed Supervision Trim Factor , and Position Supervision Trim Factor . For more information, see Jam Supervision Trim Factor, Load Supervision Trim Factor, Speed Supervision Trim Factor, and Position Supervision Trim Factor.
Save the changes.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Acceleration Data , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type
Acceleration Data, type
Acceleration Data is used to specify some acceleration characteristics for axes without any dynamic model. This is the case for certain additional axes.
For axes that have a dynamic model, Acceleration Data must still be specified even if a more complex model is normally used for the acceleration characteristics.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Acceleration Data , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the set of Acceleration Data .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Name is used to reference a set of Acceleration Data from the parameter Use Acceleration Data in the type Arm .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Nominal Acceleration belongs to the type Acceleration Data , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Worst case motor acceleration.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Nominal Acceleration to a value of the acceleration the axis can always perform (even when gravity and friction are unfavorable).
Nominal Acceleration is always used by axes without any dynamic model. For axes with dynamic model, it is only used in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 1000, in rad/s2 (or m/s2) on the arm side.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Nominal Deceleration belongs to the type Acceleration Data , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Worst case motor deceleration.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Nominal Deceleration to a value of the deceleration the axis can always perform (even when gravity and friction are unfavorable).
Nominal Deceleration is always used by axes without any dynamic model. For axes with dynamic model, it is only used in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 1000, in rad/s2 (or m/s2) on the arm side.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Arm , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The
Arm, type
Arm type contains a number of parameters that defines the characteristics for an arm. There is one set of parameters of the type Arm for each joint.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the set of parameters for type Arm .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Joint belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Joint is a flag for each axis that indicates whether the axis can be changed to independent mode.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Normally, all external axes and robot axis 6 allow independent mode. To prevent one of these axes moving independently, set Independent Joint to Off for that axis.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Joint is only useful if you have the RobotWare option Independent Axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Upper Joint Bound belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Upper Joint Bound defines the upper limit of the working area for this joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Upper Joint Bound can be used to limit the working area (in radians) of the joint.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to use a value that is larger than the maximal allowed limit for the specific joint. Trying this will cause the system to use the maximal allowed value instead.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is valid only for articulated robots. For more information, see How to restict the work area for articulated robot.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between +-1256640 radians.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Lower Joint Bound belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Lower Joint Bound defines the lower limit of the working area for this joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Lower Joint Bound can be used to limit the working area (in radians) of the joint.

wrapper.title: Note
wrapper.paragraph: It is not possible to use a value that is smaller than the minimal allowed limit for the specific joint. Trying this will cause the system to use the minimal allowed value instead.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is valid only for articulated robots. For more information, see How to restict the work area for articulated robot.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between +-1256640 radians.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Upper Joint Bound belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the upper limit of the working area for the joint when operating in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Upper Joint Bound is used together with Independent Lower Joint Bound to limit the work area for a joint that is in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Upper Joint Bound is only useful if you have the option Independent Axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Any number (in radians).

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Lower Joint Bound belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the lower limit of the working area for the joint when operating in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Lower Joint Bound is used together with Independent Upper Joint Bound to limit the work area for a joint that is in independent mode.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Independent Lower Joint Bound is only useful if you have the option Independent Axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Any number (in radians).

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Position belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Position defines the position of the axis when it was fine calibrated.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This value should specify a well-defined position in which the axis can be positioned repeatedly. This position is then used when updating Calibration Offset and revolution counter. For more information, see id(20475)Calibration Offset_en.xml.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -1000 and 1000, specifying the position in radians.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Product Manual for the manipulator.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Performance Quota belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Performance Quota can be used to reduce the acceleration for the joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Setting Performance Quota value to 1.0 gives normal performance, but if less acceleration is desired, a lower value can be entered.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.15 and 1.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Jam Supervision Trim Factor belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Jam Supervision Trim Factor defines the tune factor for jam supervision. For more information, see How to define supervision level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The tune factor influences the maximum time allowed at zero speed with maximum torque.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.1 and 10.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Load Supervision Trim Factor belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Load Supervision Trim Factor defines the tune factor for load supervision. For more information, see How to define supervision level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The factor influences the maximum time allowed at non-zero speed with maximum torque.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.1 and 10.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Speed Supervision Trim Factor belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Speed Supervision Trim Factor defines the tune factor for speed supervision. For more information, see How to define supervision level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The factor influences the maximum allowed speed error.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.05 and 10.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Position Supervision Trim Factor belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Position Supervision Trim Factor defines the tune factor for position supervision. For more information, see How to define supervision level.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The factor influences the maximum allowed position error.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.1 and 10.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: External Const Torque belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: External Const Torque defines the external constant torque. For more information, see How to define external torque.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value of External Const Torque is used in the formula for calculation of external torque.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 100,000, specifying the constant torque in Nm.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Arm Load belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Arm Load defines the name of the arm load that is used for this arm.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The arm load is set in the type Arm Load .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters, defining an Arm Load type. For more information, see The Arm Load type.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Check Point belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Check Point determines which Arm Check Point that should be used.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use Check Point is a reference to the parameter Name in the type Arm Check Point .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: An Arm Check Point must be configured before Use Check Point can refer to it.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Use Check Point can only be used for articulated robots.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: Arm Check Point.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: External Proportional Torque belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: External Proportional Torque defines the scale factor for position-dependent torque.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value of External Proportional Torque is used in the formula for calculation of external torque. For more information, see How to define external torque.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100,000 and 100,000, specifying the scale factor in Nm/rad.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: External Torque Zero Angle belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: External Torque Zero Angle defines the joint position when position-dependent torque is zero.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value of External Torque Zero Angle is used in the formula for calculation of external torque. For more information, see How to define external torque.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100,000 and 100,000, specifying the position in radians.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Load Id Acceleration Ratio belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Load Id Acceleration Ratio can be used to reduce the acceleration of the joint during load identification.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Reducing the acceleration of the joint during load identification can be useful if the torque supervision is triggered when identifying payloads with large inertia. If this happens, try to reduce the value of Load Id Acceleration Ratio until the problem disappears.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.02 and 1.0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Angle Acceleration Ratio belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Angle Acceleration Ratio defines the maximum angle acceleration ratio for the motor sensor.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter should only be changed by ABB.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.02 and 1.0.
Default value is 1.0.

title.phrase: Deactivate Cyclic Brake Check for axis

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Deactivate Cyclic Brake Check for axis belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Deactivate Cyclic Brake Check for axis defines if the arm should be excluded from the SafeMove function Cyclic Brake Check .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If an axis should be excluded from Cyclic Brake Check , set the parameter Deactivate Cyclic Brake Check for axis to On.

The axis must also be deactivated in the configuration of Cyclic Brake Check . See
Application manual Functional safety and SafeMove
.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off.
On means that the Cyclic Brake Check is deactivated for the axis.
Default value is Off.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Change to Logical Axis belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Change to Logical Axis can be used to change the Logical Axis in the type Joint if it is read only. This is normally the case for ABB positioners (IRBP) and the ABB track motions (IRBT). If the value is zero, then no change will happen and the value in the Joint will be used as normal. For more information, see Logical Axis.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value of Logical Axis is used by RAPID programs to identify individual axes in mechanical units.
Two mechanical units can have the same value set for Logical Axis, but then they cannot be activated at the same time by a RAPID program.
Robots from ABB normally use the values from 1 to 6, while additional axes use from 7 to 12.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be used for robots from ABB.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value from 0 to 12.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Additional axes
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Thermal Supervision Sensitivity Ratio belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Thermal Supervision Sensitivity Ratio can be used for installation adjustment parameter (0.5 = approximate disconnected supervision)

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If the error occurs, in spite of cold motor due to extra cooling or low ambient temperature, the sensitivity of the thermal supervision can be reduced. Decrease the system parameter Thermal Supervision Sensitivity Ratio in steps of 0.1. Check the motor temperature during and after tuning.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value from 0.5 to 2.0.
Default value is 1.0.
With too low value the supervision is deactivated and the motor can be overheated and damaged.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Brake applied movement detection factor belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Brake applied movement detection factor defines the factor of the default detection level of movement when brake applied.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: For example, set this factor to 0.1 to make the detection ten times more sensitive of the movement when the brake is applied, and set the factor to more than 1 to make the detection less sensitive. A zero value means that the function is deactivated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 10. Default value is 1 for robots where this detection is activated and 0 otherwise.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Lead through stability margin
Lead through stability margin belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Lead through stability margin can be used to adjust the behavior of the low-level joint control.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Lead through stability margin is used joint-wise and should be decremented in case of unexpected buzzing noise coming from the joint.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Lead through stability margin is only used for the following robots:
Setting this parameter for any other robot will not have any effect.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.01 and 1.
Default value 0.8.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Lead through load compensation deadband
Lead through load compensation deadband belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Lead through load compensation deadband can be used to tune the assumed maximum joint torque from cables and other disturbances affecting the robot arm, when the parameter Lead through load compensation in the type Robot is set to Always .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value is set joint-wise. A larger value makes the robot less sensitive to drift caused by torque disturbances acting on the joint, but also makes the robot feel less soft.
This parameter does not need a restart of the controller to apply the changes. Hence, it is possible to test directly after changing the parameter value.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Lead through load compensation deadband is only used for the following robots:
Setting this parameter for any other robot will not have any effect.
The parameter is only used when Lead-through Mode is set to Axis 1-6 .
This parameter only has effect when the parameter Lead through load compensation in the type Robot is set to Always .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 50.
Default value 10.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Joint Id
Joint Id belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Joint Id can be used to change the joint id number used when creating a safety configuration. If the value is zero, the value of the logical axis ( Logical Axis ) configured in the type Joint will be used as the default value. Changing the default value may be required when more than one joint in the same cabinet share the same logical axis number, for example, in ABB positioners (IRP/IRBP). For more information, see Logical Axis.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value of Joint Id is used by the robot controller to identify individual joints in the safety configuration. For each joint included in the safety configuration, the Joint Id number must be unique within its cabinet. Robots from ABB always use the values from 1 to 6.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be used for robots from ABB.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value from 0 to 12.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Ultra Accuracy stability margin belongs to the type Arm , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Ultra Accuracy stability margin can be used to adjust the behavior of the low-level joint control.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Ultra Accuracy stability margin is used joint-wise and should be decremented in case of unexpected buzzing noise coming from the joint when running in ultra accuracy mode.
Decrement in steps of 0.1 until the joint is stable.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The ultra accuracy mode is only used for GoFa CRB 15000 and requires the option 3101-10.
Setting this parameter for any other robot will not have any effect.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.01 and 1.
The default value is 1.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Arm Check Point , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic. For more information, see How to define arm check point.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: Arm Check Point, type If an extra load, such as a transformer or a welding-bar roller, is attached to arm 3, a point on this equipment can be defined as a check point. The robot will then monitor the speed of this point so that it does not exceed 250 mm/s in manual reduced speed mode. For more information, see Check Point Bound Limit Outside Cube.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Arm Check Point , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm check point.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the arm check point. A check point can be used to let the robot monitor the speed of that specified point

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 24 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Position x , Position y , and Position z belong to the type Arm Check Point , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm check point.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Position x defines the x-coordinate of the position of the check point, specified on the basis of the current frame of the arm (in meters).
Position y defines the y-coordinate of the position of the check point, specified on the basis of the current frame of the arm (in meters).
Position z defines the z-coordinate of the position of the check point, specified on the basis of the current frame of the arm (in meters).

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -3 to 3, specifying the position in meters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Arm Load , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section. For more information, see How to define arm loads.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
Arm Load, type
Arm Load is used for defining loads from equipment mounted on robot arms. If the arm load is not defined when equipment is mounted on the robot arm, the performance of the robot is negatively affected.
The Arm configuration defines which Arm Load to use for the arm.

wrapper.title: Predefined arm loads
wrapper.paragraph: There are four predefined arm loads in the robot controller. They are r1_load_1, r1_load_2, r1_load_3, and r1_load_4. For track motion, the predefined arm load in the robot controller is t1_load_1. The predefined arm loads must be adjusted to match the load and selected for the arm that it belongs to before use.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Arm Load , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm loads.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name specifies the name of the arm load setting it belongs to.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mass belongs to the type Arm Load , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm loads.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mass specifies the mass of the equipment mounted on a robot arm.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 50000, specifying the weight in kg.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mass Center x , Mass Center y , and Mass Center z belongs to the type Arm Load , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm loads.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mass Center x specifies the x-coordinate of the mass center for an arm load in the arm frame.
Mass Center y specifies the y-coordinate of the mass center for an arm load in the arm frame.
Mass Center z specifies the z-coordinate of the mass center for an arm load in the arm frame.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -30 and +30, specifying the coordinate in meters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Inertia x , Inertia y , and Inertia z belong to the type Arm Load , in the topic Motion . For more information, see How to define arm loads.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Inertia x defines the x-component of the arm load's moment of inertia relative to the load's mass center around the arm's coordinate axes.
Inertia y defines the y-component of the arm load's moment of inertia relative to the load's mass center around the arm's coordinate axes.
Inertia z defines the z-component of the arm load's moment of inertia relative to the load's mass center around the arm's coordinate axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 1000, specifying the moment of inertia in kgm2.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Brake which belongs to the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type
Brake, type
Brake is used to specify brake parameters for a specific joint. For more information, see The Joint.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the brake.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Control Off Speed Limit belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Control Off Speed Limit defines the speed for selection of delay time.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value for Control Off Speed Limit should not be modified.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 1.
Default value is 0.02.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Control Off Delay belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Control Off Delay specifies the time of normal control before the motor torque is set to zero.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Control Off Delay is used when the joint is at zero speed when the brake algorithm is activated. The controller must be active to avoid the joint to fall by gravity before the mechanical brake is engaged.
Time must be longer than the time for mechanical brake to engage.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 30 seconds.
Default value is 0.010.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control On Delay belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control On Delay specifies the time of normal control before the motor torque is set to zero.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control On Delay is used if the joint is moving when the brake algorithm is activated. The controller must be active to avoid oscillations when the mechanical brake is engaged.
The time must be longer than the time for mechanical brake to engage. Normally set to same value as parameter Control Off Delay . For more information, see Control Off Delay.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 30 seconds.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control Min Delay belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control Min Delay defines the minimum delay time.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Control Min Delay should not be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 5 seconds.
Default value is 0.010.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Absolute Brake Torque belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Absolute Brake Torque defines the brake torque to be used for a simulated electrical brake.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Absolute Brake Torque should not be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 100000 Nm.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Ramp Speed Limit belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Ramp Speed Limit is the point of torque reduction for simulated electrical brake.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Brake Ramp Speed Limit should not be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 1.
Default value is 1 (equal to 100%).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Brake Time belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: A time-out occurs if a large additional axis use the motor to brake during emergency stop and the stop time exceeds the default value of 5 seconds. The time-out results in stopping all the drive units and the brake torque from the motors are set to zero torque. A warning message is generated. By increasing the Max Brake Time , the servo motors help the axes to decelerate down to zero speed during the whole brake sequence.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Measure or calculate the maximum brake time for the axis (including safety margin). If the default value of 5 seconds is exceeded, change the parameter to appropriate value.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is 5.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Static Arm Torque belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter static torque should be highest that the brake needs to withstand, when the additional axis is positioned in maximum gravity. The value is entered in [Nm] and calculated to the motor side.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Max Static Arm Torque needs to be calculated and entered into the configuration to run the Cyclic Brake Check (CBC) on ABB motor units. CBC uses this value when testing the brake at error-level.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: To calculate the parameter for an axis that has no gravity, for example a track, the below formula may be used:
Max Static Arm Torque = Tbrake min/1.35
Tbrake min can be found in the product specification for the specific motor unit, see Product specification Motor Units and Gear Units.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
For more information about Cyclic Brake Check, see
Application manual Functional safety and SafeMove
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Brake Release Time belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter is the maximum time for release of the brake.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter is used to wait until the brakes are released. The time can be increased if the brakes are slow.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: 0-2 and the default value is 0.15 sec.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Brake Type belongs to the type Brake , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Brake Type defines which type of brake is used for this type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Control Parameters , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
Each set of parameters of the type
Control Parameters, type
Control Parameters belongs to a joint (robot joint or additional axis).
The parameters in Control Parameters define what compensations should be made for the friction in the joint.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: Changing the parameter values in Control Parameters is only useful if you have the RobotWare option Advanced Shape Tuning.
The type Control Parameters is only used by robot models IRB 1400 and IRB 1410. All other robot models use the type Friction Compensation instead. The parameters are the same however.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
, chapter Advanced Shape Tuning.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Control Parameters , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name to use for the control parameters.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW On belongs to the type Control Parameters , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW On determines if the RobotWare option Advanced Shape Tuning is active or not.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Friction FFW On to Yes if you want to use Advanced Shape Tuning.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW Level belongs to the type Control Parameters , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW Level is set to the level of friction in the robot axis. By setting a value that closely corresponds to the real friction, and using the RobotWare option Advanced Shape Tuning, the friction effects can be compensated.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Friction effects can cause path deviations when performing advanced shapes. By compensating for the friction with the correct friction level value, these effects can be minimized.
Permanent adjustments of the friction level can be made with Friction FFW Level . The friction level can also be temporarily tuned with RAPID commands.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A decimal number between 0 and 15 in Nm.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW Ramp belongs to the type Control Parameters , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Friction FFW Ramp is set to the speed of the robot axis when the friction has reached the constant friction level defined in Friction FFW Level . See illustration below.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Friction effects can cause path deviations when performing advanced shapes. Friction FFW Ramp is used when compensating for these friction effects.
Permanent adjustments of the friction ramp can be made with Friction FFW Ramp . The friction ramp can also be temporarily tuned with RAPID commands.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0.001 and 10 in radians/second.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=1; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=4.066in 1.997in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Drive System , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type drive system, type
Drive System is used to identify and specify each drive system used in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Drive System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the name for the drive system.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use DC-link belongs to the type Drive System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use DC-link determines which dc-link (rectifier) unit should be used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Trafo belongs to the type Drive System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Trafo determines which transformer should be used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Drive Unit belongs to the type Drive System , in the topic Motion . For more information, see The Drive Unit type.

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Drive Unit determines which drive unit should be used.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

section.title:
The Drive Unit type
Drive Unit, type

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Drive Unit , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type
Drive Unit is used to identify and specify each drive unit used in the robot system.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The Drive System.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Drive Unit , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the name for the drive unit.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Drive Unit Position belongs to the type Drive Unit , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Drive Unit Position defines the logical position on the Drive Unit network, starting with 1, then 2, 3, and so on.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 9.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Force Master , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
force master, type
Force Master is used to define how a servo gun behaves during the two faces of the gun closing:

listitem.paragraph: when approaching the point where position regulation is replaced by force control
during force control.

wrapper.paragraph: Values for position, torque, force, etc. are specified for calibration and gun closing.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Force Master can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Non-editable parameters
wrapper.paragraph: The following parameters are visible but not editable in the software configuration tools:
As a consequence, the above parameters are not described in the manual.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the Force Master .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Name is used to reference a Force Master from the parameter Use Force Master in the type SG Process .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Force Master Control belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Force Master Control determines which Force Master Control should be used. For more information, see The Force Master Control type.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use Force Master Control is a reference to the parameter Name in the type Force Master Control .

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: A Force Master Control must be configured before Use Force Master Control can refer to it.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Use Force Master Control can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: References Bandwidth belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The frequency limit for the low pass filter for reference values. During position regulation, when approaching the plate thickness, position and speed values will be filtered in this low pass filter to avoid sharp step functions.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A high value on References Bandwidth will make little use of the low pass filter.
If the servo tool is vibrating due to irregular movements, References Bandwidth can be set to a lower value. A low value will make the servo tool movements slower.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: References Bandwidth can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 1 and 124 (Hz).
The default value is 25 Hz.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Ramp Time belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Determines if the ramping of the tip force should use a constant time or a constant gradient.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If the tip force should be ramped up to its ordered value during the time specified in Ramp Time , set Use Ramp Time to Yes. The ramp rate will then vary to make the ramp time constant.
If the tip force should be increased at a constant rate, specified in Ramp when Increasing Force , set Use Ramp Time to No. The ramp time will then vary to make the ramp rate constant.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Use Ramp Time can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp when Increasing Force belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp when Increasing Force decides how fast the torque is ramped up to the ordered torque after contact position is reached at a close gun command.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A higher value of Ramp when Increasing Force will make the tip force build up faster.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp when Increasing Force is only used if Use Ramp Time is set to No.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp when Increasing Force can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 1 and 10000, specifying the torque increase in Nm/s.
The default value is 70 Nm/s.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp Time belongs to the type Force Control , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp Time decides how fast the torque is ramped up to the ordered torque after contact position is reached at a close gun command.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A lower value of Ramp Time will make the tip force build up faster.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp Time is only used if Use Ramp Time is set to Yes.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Ramp Time can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.001 and 1 (seconds).
The default value is 0.07 s.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision LP Bandwidth belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Frequency limit for the low pass filter used for tip wear calibration. Position and speed reference values will be filtered in this low pass filter to avoid sharp step functions.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The only reason for changing Collision LP Bandwidth is if repetitive tip wear calibrations give varying results. A lower value for the low pass filter can stabilize the servo tool during the calibration.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Collision LP Bandwidth can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 124 (Hz).
The default value is 25 Hz.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Alarm Torque belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Alarm Torque determines how hard the tool tips will be pressed together during the first gun closing of new tips calibrations and tool change calibrations.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Alarm Torque is used for the first gun closing of new tips calibrations and tool change calibrations. This affects the position calibration.

The best way to determine the collision position (where the tool tips meet) is to keep closing the gun until the motor torque reaches the value specified in Collision Alarm Torque . The distance the gun then has moved beyond the collision position is defined by the parameter Collision Delta Position .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Alarm Torque can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 50 (Nm).
The default value is 1.5 Nm.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Speed (m/s) belongs to the type Force Master , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Speed (m/s) determines the servo gun speed during the first gun closing of new tip calibrations and tool change calibrations. These calibrations affect the position calibration.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The only reason for changing Collision Speed (m/s) is if repetitive tip wear calibrations give varying results. A lower speed can improve the repeatability.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Speed (m/s) can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 5 (m/s).
The default value is 0.02 m/s.

wrapper.title: Parent
