That is, move to the circle point and complete the circle to the end point in the opposite direction than programmed. This could be dangerous.
The circle path will be better defined if the circle point is near the midth of the path, for example, use the instructions CirPathMode\CirPointOri or SingArea\Wrist .
To minimize the risk set Restrict Placing of Circlepoints to Yes. Then the robot will stop with an error message if the TCP is not within the safe limits.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
Default value is Yes.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: The following reasons will stop the robot if Restrict Placing of Circlepoints is set to Yes.

listitem.paragraph: Circle point is too close to start point.
Circle point is too close to end point.
Circle is too large, that is more than 240 degrees.

wrapper.paragraph: If a circle point is modified (modpos) then the planned path is recalculated so that when restarting the program the robot will follow the new path if the conditions for restricted placing of circlepoints are fulfilled, regardless of if the function is activated or not.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: The example shows a planned path from P10 to P20 in anti clockwise direction (A). If the robot is standing between P10 and P20 when execution is started then the robot might want to use the other direction (B). If Restrict Placing of Circlepoints is set to Yes then an error message is displayed that the TCP is not within safe limits.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=1.611in 1.413in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motion Supervision belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motion Supervision defines which set of motion supervision parameters to be used for this motion planner. For more information, see The Motion Supervision type.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
Motion supervision is used to activate, deactivate or adjust the collision detection functionality. For detailed information about collision detection, see the
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
, chapter Collision Detection .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Permanent Off belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Permanent Off is used to turn off all motion supervision to save CPU power.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Max Level belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The maximum allowed supervision level, both for program execution and jogging.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Max Level stops the operator from tuning the supervision level to values that are too high.

The supervision level for program execution is a combination of the parameter Path Collision Detection Level and a tuning value set with the RAPID instruction MotionSup . Motion Supervision Max Level is a maximum limit for this combined value. For more information, see Path Collision Detection Level.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Changing this parameter only affects the system if the option Collision Detection is installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer in the interval 10 to 500 (percent).
The default value is 300.

wrapper.title: Example
wrapper.paragraph: Motion Supervision Max Level is set to 300.
Path Collision Detection Level is set to 250.
A RAPID program uses the instruction MotionSup to tune the supervision level with 200%.
Normally this would lead to a supervision level of 500% (2.5 * 2 = 5), but since Motion Supervision Max Level is 300, the supervision level will not exceed 300%.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Time Event Supervision belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Time Event Supervision is used to detect if a programmed event can be accurately positioned or not. If not, the system will stop and display a warning.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If the event cannot be accurately positioned, suggested program modifications are to either lower the programmed speed or to increase the distance between the start of the segment and the desired event position.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: High Interpolation Priority belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: High Interpolation Priority is used to allow the system to temporarily increase the priority of the path planning in critical situations.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: When the warning "50082 Deceleration limit" occurs at installations, this parameter can be useful. See also Path Resolution.

Using High Interpolation Priority might affect the performance of the application, for example, spot welding or sealing. Thus it is very important to verify the process performance after the parameter has been set.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Speed Control Warning belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: By setting Speed Control Warning to Yes, a warning will be given when the robot moves slower than the programmed speed.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: When several robots (and other mechanical units) are in synchronized movement mode, in a MultiMove application, all simultaneous move instruction finish at the same time. This means that if one robot has a longer path or a slower programmed speed than another robot, the speed of the second robot is decreased.

If a robot is working with an application where the speed is important (e.g. arc welding or gluing), Speed Control Warning can be used to give a warning when the actual speed is slower than the programmed speed.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only useful when using the RobotWare option MultiMove.
The speed is only supervised for robot TCP speed. No warning is given for the speed of additional axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: When several tasks are in synchronized movement mode, all these tasks are planned by the same Motion Planner (the first Motion Planner of those involved in the synchronization). If this Motion Planner has Speed Control Warning set to Yes, all the synchronized robot speeds are supervised. If it has Speed Control Warning set to No, no robot speeds are supervised.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Speed Control Percent belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If Speed Control Warning is set to Yes, a warning will be issued when the actual speed is slower than this percentage of the programmed speed.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If a robot is working with an application where the speed is important (e.g. arc welding or gluing), Speed Control Percent defines the slowest speed (in percent of programmed speed) that is acceptable.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is only useful when using the RobotWare option MultiMove.
The speed is only supervised for robot TCP speed. No warning is given for the speed of additional axes.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A number between 0 and 100 (in percent of programmed speed).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Interpolation Buffer Startup Adjust belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Interpolation Buffer Startup Adjust defines how to adjust the default value for the interpolation buffer created at start from finepoint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Interpolation Buffer Startup Adjust changes the default value by increasing or decreasing the number of steps in the buffer, calculated by the motion planner at start from finepoint.

A value less than zero will decrease the number of steps and this will reduce the time to start from finepoint (see additional information for risks). A value greater than zero will increase the number of steps. This can be used if there are unexpected corner path failures (code 50024) in the first move instruction after a finepoint.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer in the range -2 to 2.
Default value is 0 and default number of steps will be used.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Reducing the number of steps in the buffer will increase the risk that the robot stops with the corner path failure warning (50024) on the first move instruction after a finepoint. A reduced value can in some cases result in deceleration limit error (50082). In these cases, the value should be increased.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Additional Interp. Object Batch belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Additional Interp. Object Batch is used to increase the number of interpolation objects available in the system. The value 0 means the default number of interpolation objects is available. Increasing the parameter value by one implies allocating one additional batch of interpolation objects.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter is useful if AccSet is used with very low values or a very slow external axis is used in the system. Typically the value is increased after the error 50426 (Out of interpolation objects) is triggered.
The additional interpolation objects use system memory and it is therefore not recommended to add extra safety margin on the number of batches allocated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 2 specifying the number of additional batches of interpolation objects that are available in the system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Bandwidth of path pose filter belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Bandwidth of path pose filter is used to set the cut off frequency for a low pass filter that filters the path pose used for weaving. The path pose is constantly calculated from the actual path and the tool Z direction. When this pose changes too rapidly, the robot might jerk slightly or trigger the error message 50375, Dynamic load too high . The Bandwidth of path pose filter is used to smoothen these changes in the pose.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Setting this value to a lower value creates a smoother change of the path pose. If a rapid change of pose is needed, a higher value can be set as long as it does not create jerky movements.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.01 and 20, specifying the cut off frequency in Hz.
The default value is 1 Hz.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
, instruction CorrCon .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Number of Internal Event Objects belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Number of Internal Event Objects defines the number of internal event objects for the motion planner.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Number of Internal Event Objects is used to allocate internal event objects. The objects are used in different situations, e.g. when running the Trigg instructions in RAPID. When using intensive TriggLIOs the controller can get lack of internal event objects, in such event this parameter can be used to solve the problem and increase the number of internal objects.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 500.
Default value is 100.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Enable High Accuracy Pos Sync belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Enable High Accuracy Pos Sync is used to highly increase the position accuracy when synchronization is made between mechanical units with different bandwidth.
The functionality may have slight negative effect on motion start time after finepoint and may lead to minor increase of cycle time.
The functionality is turned off by default.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set this value to Yes to improve the position synchronization.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
Default value is No.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Setup Optimized Start from Finepoint belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Setup Optimized Start from Finepoint enables the robot to start faster from a finepoint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value for Setup Optimized Start from Finepoint is Yes . When the RAPID instruction DeactEventBuffer is used then the optimized start from finepoint functionality is automatically enabled. And if the event buffer is configured and activated using the RAPID instruction ActEventBuffer , the optimized start from finepoint functionality is automatically disabled.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No
The default value is Yes.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

title.phrase: Use check point limitation in world

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use check point limitation in world belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Use check point limitation in world enables the robot to limit check point speed in world coordinate system in teach mode. Thus, the additional speed from a track motion is added to the check point speed and the robot speed is reduced.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The default value for Use check point limitation in world is No . This function is especially useful when combining SafeMove with a robot on track. SafeMove supervises the speed of check points in world coordinate system. If this function is not active, there is a risk that SafeMove will trigger overspeed error when robot and track is moved simultaneously. For more information, see Arm check point and How to define arm check point.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No

wrapper.title: Default value
wrapper.paragraph: The default value is Yes .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Cartesian threshold for short segments belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: For a movement to be considered short, the TCP movement, the maximum rotating axis movement, and the maximum linear axis movement must simultaneously be smaller than the Cartesian threshold for short segments , the Threshold for short segments in rad , and the Threshold for short segments in m , respectively.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Cartesian threshold for short segments is used to detect and warn you about extremely short movement instructions. Short movement instructions can lead to problems like high CPU load and events being executed out of order.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.0 to 0.1, specifying the distance in meters.
The default value is 0.0001 m.

title.phrase: Threshold for short segments in rad

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Threshold for short segments in rad belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: For a movement to be considered short, the TCP movement, the maximum rotating axis movement, and the maximum linear axis movement must simultaneously be smaller than the Cartesian threshold for short segments , the Threshold for short segments in rad , and the Threshold for short segments in m , respectively.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Threshold for short segments in rad is used to detect and warn you about extremely short movement instructions. Short movement instructions can lead to problems like high CPU load and events being executed out of order.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.0 to 0.1, specifying the angle in radians.
The default value is 0.001 radians.

title.phrase: Threshold for short segments in m

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Threshold for short segments in m belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: For a movement to be considered short, the TCP movement, the maximum rotating axis movement, and the maximum linear axis movement must simultaneously be smaller than the Cartesian threshold for short segments , the Threshold for short segments in rad , and the Threshold for short segments in m , respectively.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Threshold for short segments in m is used to detect and warn you about extremely short movement instructions. Short movement instructions can lead to problems like high CPU load and events being executed out of order.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.0 to 0.1, specifying the distance in meters.
The default value is 0.0001 m.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max allowed short segments belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Max allowed short segments determines the maximum number of short consecutive movement instructions allowed before a warning is displayed. When a non-short movement instruction is executed, the internal counter for short movements is reset to zero.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter can be increased to allow up to 100 short subsequent movement instructions. Set the value to -1 to stop the internal counter for short movements.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -1 to 100.
The default value is 1.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum allowed path correction belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Maximum allowed path correction defines the maximum allowed path correction for the robot to follow the actual path.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.01 to 0.5, specifying the distance in meters.
The default value is 0.05.

title.phrase: Max acc when ramping up speed

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max acc when ramping up speed belongs to the type Motion Planner , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: When deactivating the system input LimitSpeed , the parameter Max acc when ramping up speed defines an upper limit of the path acceleration that the mechanical unit can have when ramping to the programmed speed. So, when activating LimitSpeed , the speed is ramped down as quickly as possible, but when deactivating LimitSpeed , the acceleration is limited by this parameter.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Default value is 10 m/s2.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph: System input LimitSpeed.

Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Motion Process Mode , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.
Incorrect use of Motion Process Mode parameters can cause movements and torques that can damage the robot. You must bear this in mind when setting the Motion Process Mode parameters.

wrapper.title: Available motion process modes
wrapper.paragraph: A motion process mode consists of a specific set of tuning parameters for a robot. Each tuning parameter set, that is each mode, optimizes the robot tuning for a specific class of applications.
There following modes are predefined:

listitem.paragraph: Optimal cycle time mode â this mode gives the shortest possible cycle time and is normally the default mode.
Accuracy mode â this mode improves path accuracy. The cycle time will be slightly increased compared to Optimal cycle time mode .
Low speed accuracy mode â this mode improves path accuracy. The cycle time will be slightly increased compared to Accuracy mode .

Low speed stiff mode - this mode is recommended for contact applications where maximum servo stiffness is important. Could also be used in some low speed applications, where a minimum of path vibrations is desired. The cycle time will be increased compared to Low speed accuracy mode .

Press tending mode â Changes the Kv Factor , Kp Factor and Ti Factor in order to mitigate tool vibrations. This mode is primarily intended for use in press tending applications where flexible grippers with a large extension in the y-direction are used.

Collaborative mode â This mode is recommended for collaborative applications where robot should run smoothly. The cycle time will be increased compared to optimal cycle time mode. This will only have any effect on GoFa CRB 15000.

wrapper.paragraph: There are also four modes available for application specific user tuning:

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph: The concept of Motion Process Mode simplifies application specific tuning which previously has been performed by using TuneServo and AccSet in the RAPID program. The predefined modes should be useful in many cases with no further adjustments needed.
The TuneServo and AccSet instructions can still be used for adjusting the tuning but it is recommended to use Motion Process Mode instead.

If a more specific tuning is needed, some tuning parameters can be modified in each Motion Process Mode . These parameters are described in the following. In this way, the user can create a specific tuning for a specific application. Note that all parameter settings are relative adjustments of the predefined parameter value.
Relative adjustment of acceleration = predefined_accset_acc_factor_for_specific_mode x accset_acc_factor x acc_factor_of_accset_instruction / 100
The Motion Process Mode can be changed by changing the parameter Use Motion Process Mode for type Robot .

listitem.paragraph: The Motion Process Mode concept is currently available for all six- and seven-axes robots except paint robots with TrueMove1.
The Mounting Stiffness Factor parameters are only available for the following robots:
IRB 120, IRB 140, IRB 1200, IRB 1520, IRB 1600, IRB 2600, IRB 4600, IRB 6620 (not LX), IRB 6640, IRB 6700.
For IRB 1410, only the Accset and the geometric accuracy parameters are available.
The following robot models do not support the use of World Acc Factor (i.e. only World Acc Factor = -1 is allowed):

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the motion process mode.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motion Process Mode Type belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Choice of predefined mode parameters.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter determines the set of predefined parameters for a user defined mode. The value must be one of the following strings:
If the system has multiple robots it is necessary to replace rob1 by rob2, rob3, etc.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Acc Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Acc Factor changes the acceleration.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Acc Factor = 0.8 reduces the acceleration by 20%, Accset Acc Factor = 1.5 increases the acceleration by 50%. For Optimal cycle time mode, the acceleration is the highest possible and values above 1.0 will not affect the acceleration. Decreased acceleration increases cycle time but reduces path errors, vibrations, and overshoots.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 5.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Ramp Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Ramp Factor changes the acceleration ramp time (jerk).

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Ramp Factor = 0.5 increases the acceleration ramp time by a factor of 2. Accset Ramp Factor = 0.2 increases the acceleration ramp time by a factor of 5. Increased acceleration ramp time, increases cycle time but reduces path errors, vibrations, and overshoots. In most cases, the Accset Acc Factor is more efficient for obtaining this and should therefore be the first choice.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 1.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Fine Point Ramp Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Fine Point Ramp Factor changes the deceleration ramp time (jerk) when moving into a fine point.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Accset Fine Point Ramp Factor = 0.5 increases the deceleration ramp time by a factor of 2, when moving into a fine point. Accset Fine Point Ramp Factor = 0.2 increases the deceleration ramp time by a factor of 5. Increased deceleration ramp time in fine point increases cycle time for each fine point but reduces vibrations and overshoots in fine points, and is a more cycle time efficient way to solve such problems (compared to using Accset Acc Factor or Accset Ramp factor ).

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 1.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Dh Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Dh factor affects the smoothness of the robot path by adjusting the effective bandwidth of the mechanical unit.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A Dh Factor less than 1 decreases the effective bandwidth of the mechanical unit and increases the smoothness of the robot path. For Optimal cycle time mode , the bandwidth is the highest possible and values above 1.0 will not affect the path. Decreased bandwidth reduces overshoots and path errors due to vibrations. However, at high speed, larger corner zones than programmed will be noticeable. A decreased Dh Factor increases cycle time for each fine point only. Thus, Dh Factor is a more cycle time efficient way to reduce vibrations and overshoots than the use of Accset Acc Factor .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 5.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Joint Acc Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Joint Acc Factor reduces the acceleration for a specific joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Joint Acc Factor = 0.6 reduces the acceleration for a specific joint by 40%. Joint Acc Factor can be used to reduce path errors and vibrations caused by the acceleration of specific joints. For example, axis 4-6 during TCP reorientation.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.01 and 1.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Joint Speed Max Factor
Joint Speed Max Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Joint Speed Max Factor reduces the maximum speed for a specific joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The allowed max speed for a specific joint is reduced by a particular percentage depending on the value of the Joint Speed Max Factor parameter. For example, if the value of Joint Speed Max Factor is 0.6, it reduces the allowed max speed for a specific joint by 40%.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.01 and 1.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: World Acc Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: A positive value of World Acc Factor activates a function that reduces the world acceleration dynamically. Use of World Acc Factor decreases path errors and increases the cycle time slightly. However, since the world acceleration reduction is dynamic and depends on the path characteristics, the use of World Acc Factor is often a cycle-time efficient way of improving path accuracy, compared to the use of Accset Acc Factor or Accset Ramp Factor .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The recommended setting for improving path accuracy is World Acc Factor = 1. World Acc Factor = -1 deactivates this function. Path accuracy can be further improved, to the cost of longer cycle time, by decreasing the recommended value (for example, = 0.75). Cycle time can be shortened, to the cost of less accuracy, by increasing the recommended value (for example, World Acc Factor = 1.5). The use of World Acc Factor is recommended for cutting applications and other applications where path accuracy is important.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The following robot models do not support the use of World Acc Factor (that is, only World Acc Factor = -1 is allowed):

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between -1 and 100.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
- WorldAccLim .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Geometric Accuracy Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Geometric Accuracy Factor can be used to adjust the geometric accuracy of the path. The final geometric accuracy is the default setting for a specific motion mode multiplied by Geometric Accuracy Factor .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: For Motion Process Mode = Accuracy Mode , the default setting ( Geometric Accuracy Factor = 1) is recommended. For other modes, the accuracy can be improved by setting Geometric Accuracy Factor = 0.1.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 10.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Df Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Df Factor affects the predicted mechanical resonance frequency of a particular axis.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Df Factor = 0.95 reduces the predicted mechanical resonance frequency of a particular axis by 5%. The most common use of Df Factor is to compensate for a foundation with inadequate stiffness, i.e., a flexible foundation. In this case, the Df Factor for axis 1 and 2 is lowered, typically to a value between 0.80 and 0.99. Use of Df Factor for axis 3 â 6 is rare and is normally not recommended. Df Factor for axis 1 and 2 can be automatically tuned by using TuneMaster. Correctly adjusted, not too low and not too high, Df Factor reduces vibrations and overshoots, without affecting cycle time. For robots where Mounting Stiffness Factor is available, Df Factor is not needed for compensation of flexible foundations.
For more information, see Mounting Stiffness Factor.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 1.5.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Kp Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Kp Factor affects the equivalent gain of the position controller.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: An increased Kp Factor can reduce path errors and increases the servo stiffness. However, oscillations due to mechanical resonances can be increased in some cases. In most cases where the position or speed controller parameters ( Kp Factor , Kv Factor and Ti Factor ) need to be changed, Kv Factor is the most important parameter and Kp Factor is not changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.2 and 5.0.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Kv Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Kv Factor affects the equivalent gain of the speed controller.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: An increased Kv Factor can reduce path errors due to, e.g., drive train ripple and friction. An increased Kv Factor also increases the servo stiffness. However, oscillations due to mechanical resonances can be increased in some cases. A Kv Factor which is too high causes motor vibrations and must be avoided. Always be careful and be observant for increased motor noise level when adjusting Kv Factor and do not use higher values than needed for fulfilling the application requirement.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.2 and 5.0.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Ti Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Ti Factor affects the integral time of the controller.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: A decreased Ti Factor can reduce path errors and increases the servo stiffness. However, oscillations due to mechanical resonances can be increased in some cases. In most cases where the controller parameters ( Kp Factor , Kv Factor and Ti Factor ) need to be changed, Kv Factor is the most important parameter and Ti Factor is not changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.1 and 5.0.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

title.phrase: Mounting Stiffness Factor X, Y, Z

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Mounting Stiffness Factor belongs to the type Motion Process Mode , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Mounting stiffness factor describes the stiffness of the robot foundation.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Mounting Stiffness Factor can be used for compensating for a foundation with inadequate stiffness, i.e., a flexible foundation. Correctly tuned Mounting Stiffness Factor will minimize overshoots and reduce vibrations. Mounting Stiffness Factor = 1.0 is default and give the best behavior when the foundation is stiff according to the Robot Product Manual (see, requirement on foundation - minimum resonance frequency). A lower value will improve the robot behavior when the requirement on foundation is not fulfilled and a lower value means a more flexible foundation. There are three parameters for the x-, y-, and z-direction (torsional stiffness in base coordinate system). Mounting Stiffness Factor can be automatically tuned by TuneMaster.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0.01 and 1.0333.

phrase.paragraph: RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Motion Supervision , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
Motion Supervision, type The type Motion Supervision is used to activate, deactivate or adjust the collision detection functionality. For detailed information about collision detection, see the
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
, chapter Collision Detection .

wrapper.title: No controller restart required
wrapper.paragraph: Most of the motion supervision parameters do not require a restart of the controller when modified.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The type Motion supervision is mainly used to configure the installed option Collision detection. For a system without this option, changing the values for most of the parameters does not affect the system. For more information, see How to tune the motion supervision.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the motion supervision setup.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Path Collision Detection belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Path Collision Detection turns the collision detection on or off for program execution.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Setting Path Collision Detection to On turns on the collision detection, Off turns off the collision detection.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Jog Collision Detection belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Jog collision Detection turns the collision detection on or off for jogging.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: Changing this parameter only affects the system if the option Collision detection is installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Path Collision Detection Level belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Path Collision Detection Level modifies the supervision level for the collision detection for program execution by a specified percentage value.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
The supervision level for collision detection in program execution is specified as a percentage. A large value makes the function less sensitive. The default value is 100%. For detailed information, see the
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
and How to tune the motion supervision.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: Changing this parameter only affects the system if the option Collision detection is installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value in the interval 1 to 500, specifying the supervision level in %.
The default value is 100%.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Jog Collision Detection Level belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Jog Collision Detection Level modifies the supervision level for the collision detection for jogging by a specified percentage value.
For more information, see How to tune the motion supervision.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
The supervision level for collision detection in jogging is specified as a percentage, where a large value makes the function less sensitive. The default value is 100%. For detailed information, see the
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Changing this parameter only affects the system if the option Collision detection is installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value in the interval 1 to 500, specifying the supervision level in %.
The default level is 100%.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Detection Memory belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Detection Memory defines how much the robot moves back on the path after a collision.
The parameter requires a restart of the controller when modified.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph:
The movement of robot back on the path after a collision is specified in seconds. If the robot was moving quickly before the collision, it will move further back than if the speed was lower. For detailed information, see the
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value in the interval 0 to 0.5, specifying the movement in seconds.
For the IRB 14050 and CRB 15000 robots the default value is 0 s and hence the robot does not back off.

Setting the value to 0 s (disabling backing after collision) may leave the robot in a state with residual forces remaining after a collision. This could trigger new collisions when trying to move away from that position. To move away robustly after a collision, the following are some of the recommended solutions:

listitem.paragraph: Enable lead-through for a short period of time to release the tension.
Set the value of MotionSup\ to Off before executing the move instructions.
Use ContactL instead of MoveL.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Manipulator supervision belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Manipulator supervision turns the supervision for the loose arm detection on or off for IRB340 and IRB 360.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Manipulator supervision to On to turn supervision on. The supervision level is set with parameter Manipulator supervision level . A loose arm will stop the robot and cause an error message.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: For the changes to take effect, a restart is required.
The Manipulator supervision parameter is used only by IRB 340 and IRB 360.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: On or Off
The default value is On.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Manipulator supervision level belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Manipulator supervision level modifies the supervision level for the loose arm detection for the manipulators IRB 340 and IRB 360.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The supervision level for loose arms is specified as a percentage, where a large value makes the function less sensitive. The default value is 100%.
The supervision function is turned On or Off with parameter Manipulator supervision .

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Changing this parameter only affects the system if the option Collision detection is installed.
For the changes to take effect, a restart is required.
The parameter Manipulator supervision level is used only by IRB 340 and IRB 360.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value in the interval 1 to 500, specifying the supervision level in %.
The default value is 100%.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Collision detection at standstill belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Collision detection at standstill enables the detection of any collision, even at standstill, when the value is set to TRUE.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: TRUE or FALSE.
Default value is FALSE. The default value for the IRB 14050/CRB 15000 robot is TRUE.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Collision Detection Zero Speed Time
Collision Detection Zero Speed Time belongs to the type Motion Supervision , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Collision Detection Zero Speed Time modifies the wait time after a collision. This is needed to make sure that the Robot is standing still before backing away.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: If Motion Supervision is used in time critical applications and when the collisions are typically happening at low speeds with the tools that are not flexible, the value of Collision Detection Zero Speed Time can be reduced. Otherwise, it is not recommended to change this parameter since a low value of Collision Detection Zero Speed Time can cause additional errors when backing away from the collision.
The main effect of this parameter is seen if the Motion system parameter Ind collision stop without brake â is set to ON since then there is no need to apply and release the brakes.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Changes in this parameter affect the system only if the Collision detection option is installed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value in the interval 50 ms to 1000 ms. The default value is 400 ms.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Motion System , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
Motion System, type
Motion System includes parameters that are common for the entire system.

wrapper.title: Non-editable parameters
wrapper.paragraph: The following parameters are visible but not editable in the software configuration tools:
As a consequence, the above parameters are not described in the manual.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name specifies the name of the Motion System type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Min Ambient Temperature Cabinet belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Min Ambient Temperature Cabinet defines the minimum ambient temperature where the cabinet is situated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100 to 100 C, specifying the temperature in degrees Celsius.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Ambient Temperature Cabinet belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Max Ambient Temperature Cabinet defines the maximum ambient temperature where the cabinet is situated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100 to 100 C, specifying the temperature in degrees Celsius.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter does not have to be changed if the controller is equipped with an extra fan for the cabinet.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Min Ambient Temperature Robot belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Min Ambient Temperature Robot defines the minimum ambient temperature where the robot is situated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100 to 100 C, specifying the temperature in degrees Celsius.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Ambient Temperature Robot belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Max Ambient Temperature Robot defines the maximum ambient temperature where the robot is situated.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -100 to 100 C, specifying the temperature in degrees Celsius.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Coll-Pred Safety Distance belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The function Collision Avoidance monitors a detailed geometric model of the robot. If two bodies of the model come too close to each other, the controller warns about a predicted collision and stops the robot. The system parameter Coll-Pred Safety Distance determines at what distance the two objects are considered to be in collision.
The geometric model for the robot is integrated in RobotWare. The geometric models for external or surrounding equipment are set up in RobotStudio.
The functionality is activated by a system input, see Collision Avoidance.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0.001 and 1 meters.
The default value is 0.001.

wrapper.title: Limitation
wrapper.paragraph: Coll-Pred Safety Distance is only activated together with the option Collision Avoidance .

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Ind collision stop without brake
Ind collision stop without brake belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Ind collision stop without brake is used to set that detected collisions can be handled independently in RAPID tasks that are executed independently. For example, if ROB_1 and ROB_2 are running in independent RAPID tasks and ROB_2 detects a collision, only the RAPID task for ROB_2 is stopped.
The independent stop does not use the physical brake.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The main usage for Ind collision stop without brake is for MultiMove configurations but when used for a non-MultiMove configuration the stop method without physical brake will be used anyway.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: This requires the option Collision Detection in the system.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The collision stop without brake is slightly slower than when using the physical brakes. This can cause the robot to get stuck against a fixed object after a collision which in turn can trigger other supervision functions. To avoid that the robot gets stuck after a collision, the value of the system parameter Collision Detection Memory can be increased, see Collision Detection Memory.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: TRUE or FALSE.
Default value is FALSE.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
Disable SafeMove Assistance
Disable SafeMove Assistance belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Disable SafeMove Assistance is used to turn off the functionality SafeMove Assistant.
Use the parameter SafeMove assistance speed factor to set the speed reduction factor.
The functionality SafeMove Assistant is only active in automatic mode.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.
The default value is No , meaning that SafeMove Assistant is enabled.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
SafeMove assistance speed factor
SafeMove assistance speed factor belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: If the robot has a minor overshoot or in any other way triggers a SafeMove speed violation, the parameter SafeMove assistance speed factor can be reduced to avoid unnecessary violations. The default setting of 0.96 corresponds to that the path planner will use 96% of the speed limit in the active safety configuration.
Avoid programming movement with different speed data at the exact border of a safety zone.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numerical value between 0 and 1.
Default value is 0.96.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph:
SafeMove assistance zone margin
SafeMove assistance zone margin belongs to the type Motion System , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter SafeMove assistance zone margin is used as a margin distance, in meters, to avoid triggering speed violations in SafeMove. It determines roughly how far before a speed-limited zone the robot will have reached the actual speed limit. Likewise, when the robot is moving out of a speed-limited zone, it will not start accelerating towards the programmed speed until it has moved this distance outside the zone.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numerical value between 0 and 1.
Default value is 0.01.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the Motor type which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type motor, type
Motor describes the motor used for each axis. There is one configuration of the type Motor for each axis.
Note that only external axes are visible, the robot's axes motors are configured on delivery and should not be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motor , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the motor.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motor Type belongs to the type Motor , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motor Type defines which type of motor is used for this type.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The type Motor Type defines the motor data. For more information, see The type Motor Type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motor Calibration belongs to the type Motor , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Motor Calibration defines which type of motor calibration to be used.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The type Motor Calibration defines the motor's calibration data. For more information, see The Motor Calibration type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Motor Calibration , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
With the parameters in the motor calibration, type
Motor Calibration type, you can calibrate the robot's motors by entering the calibration values.
The robot is calibrated on delivery. If needed, the motor calibration configuration is done during robot calibration. However, if the values are known, they can be specified directly.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: If calibration or commutator offset parameters are set, the corresponding offset valid parameters have to be set to YES , otherwise the offset parameter will not be used.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name specifies the name of the motor calibration setting it belongs to.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Name is used to reference the Motor Calibration from the parameter Use Motor Calibration in the type Motor .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Commutator Offset belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Commutator Offset defines the position of the motor (resolver) when the rotor is in the predefined commutation position relative to the stator.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: ABB motors normally uses Commutation Offset value 1.57080.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -6.283186 and 6.283186, specifying the offset in radians.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Commutator Offset Valid belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Commutator Offset Valid specifies whether the commutator offset is defined or not. For more information, see Commutator offset.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Offset belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Offset defines the position of the motor (resolver) when the arm is in the calibration (zero) position.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -6.283186 and 6.283186, specifying the offset in radians.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Offset Valid belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Offset Valid specifies whether the calibration offset is defined or not. For more information, see Calibration offset.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: Yes or No.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Sensor Position belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Calibration Sensor Position defines the calibration sensor position on the arm side.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The value is set in degrees.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -180 and 180 degrees.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Factory Calibration Method belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The factory calibration is done when the robot is calibrated in the factory, before delivery from ABB.
Using the values in the below table you can determine which method was used to calibrate the robot's motor.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be modified.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: Latest Calibration Method belongs to the type Motor Calibration , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter Latest Calibration Method defines what method that was last used to calibrate the motors of the robot.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be modified.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Motor Type , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type motor type, type
Motor Type is used to describe characteristics for the motor.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: The parameter values for Motor Type can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values can be observed for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the Motor Type .

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Name is used to reference a motor type from the parameter Use Motor Type in the type Motor .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Pole Pairs belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Defines the number of pole pairs for the motor type.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Pole Pairs to the number of pole pairs (i.e. number of poles divided with 2) that the motor has.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Pole Pairs can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visible for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: An integer between 0 and 20.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Inertia (kgm**2) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Motor and resolver inertia on motor side. The unit is kgm2.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: For a rotating object, the inertia describes the tendency to resist a change in rotational speed (corresponding to mass for an object moving linearly). For a motor, the inertia depends on the mass and the mass distribution of the rotor. The value of inertia is used for advanced servo control and can be found in the motor specification.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between 0 and 10.
The default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Stall Torque (Nm) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The continuous stall torque, i.e. the torque the motor can produce at no speed and during an infinite time.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Stall Torque (Nm) to the stall torque (T0) specified by the motor manufacturer.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Stall Torque (Nm) can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visible for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 100000 Nm.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: ke Phase to Phase (Vs/rad) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Nominal voltage constant.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: ke Phase to Phase (Vs/rad) is the induced voltage (phase to phase) that corresponds to the speed 1 rad/s.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: ke Phase to Phase (Vs/rad) can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visiblie for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 10 (Vs/rad).

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph: Some motor manufacturers specify the value kt instead of ke . ke can then be calculated according to the formula:

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Max Current (A rms) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Max current without irreversible magnetization.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Max Current (A rms) to the root-mean-square of the maximum current the motor can withstand without irreversible demagnetization.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Max Current (A rms) can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visible for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 100 (A rms).

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Phase Resistance (ohm) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Nominal winding resistance per phase at 20 degrees Celsius.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Phase Resistance (ohm) to the stator phase resistance (R20) specified by the motor manufacturer.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Phase Resistance can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visible for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 100 ohm.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Phase Inductance (H) belongs to the type Motor Type , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Nominal winding inductance per phase at zero current.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Phase Inductance (H) to the stator phase inductance (L0) specified by the motor manufacturer. The value should be measured at a frequency of about 120 Hz to correspond to what the drive expects. If the inductance is measured phase to phase the value is divided by 2.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: Phase Inductance (H) can only be changed for additional axis motors. The values are visible for robot motors, but cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A numeric value between 0 and 100 H.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Process , which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of the type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
A process can be called from the parameter Use Process in the type Joint . The parameters in the type process, type
Process point out a process in the type Linked M Process or SG Process that will be used for that joint. For more information, see Use Process and The Linked M Process type.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Process , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the identity of the process.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Name of the process is used by a joint to call the process.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is useful only if you have either of the RobotWare base functionality Electronically Linked Motors or option Spot Servo .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use SG Process belongs to the type Process , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use SG Process defines which SG Process to use.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use SG Process refers to a process ID defined by the parameter Name in the type SG Process .
SG Process is used to define a servo toolâs behavior.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: SG Process can only be used for servo tools.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Linked Motor Process belongs to the type Process , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Linked Motor Process defines which linked motor process to use.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Use Linked Motor Process points to a process ID defined by the parameter Name in the type Linked M Process .
The linked motor process is used to define a joint's behavior for Electronically Linked Motors .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Relay which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type relay, type
Relay defines the characteristics of the relays that are used for the mechanical units, e.g. brake relays and run relays.
All relays for a robot supplied from ABB are defined on delivery. This means that adding or editing parameters of the Relay type is only necessary when additional axes are installed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Relay , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: The name of the relay.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Name is used to refer a Relay from the parameters Use Activation Relay , Use Brake Relay , and Use Connection Relay in the type Mechanical Unit .

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Output Signal belongs to the type Relay in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Output Signal defines the logical name of the output signal to the relay.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Characteristics of relays for manipulators need to be defined when additional axes are installed.
The value of Output Signal must be identical to the name of the signal, including upper and lower case letters.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The logical signal name must be defined in the type Signal in the topic I/O . For more information, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Input Signal belongs to the type Relay in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Input Signal defines the logical name of the input signal to the relay.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Characteristics of relays for manipulators need to be defined when additional axes are installed.
The value of Input Signal must be identical to the name of the signal, including upper and lower case letters.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The logical signal name must be defined in the type Signal in the topic I/O .
The signal must be defined as "safety" and "INTERNAL".
For more information, see The Signal type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Overview
wrapper.paragraph: This section describes the type Robot which belongs to the topic Motion . Each parameter of this type is described in a separate information topic in this section.

wrapper.title: Type description
wrapper.paragraph:
The type robot, type
Robot contains a number of parameters that are common for a robot in the robot system. The robot is a mechanical unit with more than one joint. Parameters of this type are used to define which joints the robot consists of and the base frame of the robot.
A maximum of 8 instances of the type Robot can be configured in a system.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Name belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Name defines the name of the robot.

wrapper.title: Limitations
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter cannot be changed.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Robot Type belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Robot Type defines what robot type is used. The parameter contains information about robot reach (m) and handling capacity (kg).

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Old SMB belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: This parameter is not used.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Robot Calibration belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use Robot Calibration defines if Absolute Accuracy is active for the robot.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: Set Use Robot Calibration to "r1_calib" to activate Absolute Accuracy for the robot.
In a MultiMove system, set the value for robot 2 to "r2_calib", robot 3 to "r3_calib" and robot 4 to "r4_calib".

td.paragraph: Absolute Accuracy is activated for the robot.
Absolute Accuracy is deactivated for the robot.
Absolute Accuracy is deactivated for the robot.
Should only be used if no other value is selectable.

wrapper.title: Related information
wrapper.paragraph:
Absolute Accuracy is described in
Application manual Controller software OmniCore
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Use Joint 1 , Use Joint 2 , Use Joint 3 , Use Joint 4 , Use Joint 5 , and Use Joint 6 belong to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Use joint 1 defines which joint data to use as the robot's first joint.
Use joint 2 defines which joint data to use as the robot's second joint.
Use joint 3 defines which joint data to use as the robot's third joint.
Use joint 4 defines which joint data to use as the robot's fourth joint.
Use joint 5 defines which joint data to use as the robot's fifth joint.
Use joint 6 defines which joint data to use as the robot's sixth joint.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The joints are defined in the type Joint . For more information, see The Joint type.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters, specifying an already defined joint.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame x , Base Frame y , and Base Frame z belong to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame x defines the x-direction of the base frame position in relation to the world frame (in meters).
Base Frame y defines the y-direction of the base frame position in relation to the world frame (in meters).
Base Frame z defines the z-direction of the base frame position in relation to the world frame (in meters).
For more information, see How to define base frame.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -1000 and 1000, specifying the relation in meters.

title.phrase: Base Frame q1, q2, q3, q4

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame q1 , Base Frame q2 , Base Frame q3 , and Base Frame q4 belong to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame q1 defines the first quaternion (q1) of the base frame orientation in relation to the world frame.
Base Frame q2 defines the second quaternion (q2) of the base frame orientation in relation to the world frame.
Base Frame q3 defines the third quaternion (q3) of the base frame orientation in relation to the world frame.
Base Frame q4 defines the fourth quaternion (q4) of the base frame orientation in relation to the world frame.
For more information, see How to define base frame.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -1 and 1 specifying the orientation.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame Moved by belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Base Frame Moved by defines the name of robot or single that moves the base frame of the robot. For more information, see How to define base frame.
When a robot is coordinated with 3rd party track, the performance of the track will be reduced to match limitations from the robot.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A string with maximum 32 characters.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Gravity Alpha belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Gravity Alpha defines the orientation of the robot with respect to the gravity.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Gravity Alpha is a positive rotation of the robot around the X-axis in the base coordinate system to define the robot orientation relative to the gravity. The value is set in radians. For more information, see How to define gravity.

If the robot is mounted on a wall (rotated around the X-axis) the robot base frame and Gravity Alpha needs to be changed to reflect the installation. Gravity Alpha should then be Â± Ï/2 (1.570796). For more information about base frame, see How to define base frame.
Gravity Alpha is calculated in the following way:
Gravity Alpha = AÂ° x 3.141593/180 = B radians, where A is the mounting angle in degrees and B is the mounting angle in radians.
For suspended robots (180Â°), use Gravity Beta instead of Gravity Alpha , see Gravity Beta.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The Gravity Alpha parameter is not supported for all robot types. It is not supported for IRB 140, IRB 1410, IRB 1600ID No Type, IRB 4400, IRB 6400R, IRB 6400 except for IRB 6400 200/2.5 and IRB 6400 200/2.8, IRB 6600, IRB 6650, IRB 6650S and IRB 7600 except for IRB 7600 325/3.1.
The parameter is supported for all robots on track when the 7 axes high performance motion parameter is set.
If the robot does not support Gravity Alpha , use Gravity Beta along with the recalibration of axis 1 to define the rotation of the robot around the X-axis.
To define the rotation of the robot around the X-axis with help of Gravity Beta :

listitem.paragraph: Install the robot.
Move axis 1 to one of the two positions where the rotational axis for joint 2 is parallel to the floor.
Note the axis 1 angle for this position (normally Â± 90 degrees). This is needed in Step 6.
Make a fine calibration of axis 1 to set this position as the new zero position.

Update Gravity Beta to the correct tilting angle of the installation. If the robot is tilted forward around axis 2 in the new calibration position, the beta value should be positive. If the robot is tilted backward around axis 2 in the new calibration position, the beta value should be negative.

Update the working range of the robot since the zero position for axis 1 is changed. Otherwise, axis 1 may run into its mechanical stops. If the calibration position is positive, reduce the Upper Joint Bound angle by the angle as measured during the calibration. If the calibration position is positive, reduce the Lower Joint Bound angle by the angle as measured during the calibration.

wrapper.paragraph: For more information, see Upper Joint Bound and Lower Joint Bound.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -6.283186 and 6.283186 radians.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph:
The value for Gravity Alpha can be changed in runtime (without restart) with the RAPID instruction WriteCfgData . See
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.
To be able to change Gravity Alpha in runtime, the initial value of Gravity Alpha at startup must be < > 0 ( not zero).
Values smaller than 0.0001 at startup is rounded off to zero and voids the ability to change the value in runtime.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Gravity Beta belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Gravity Beta defines the orientation of the robot with respect to the gravity.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Gravity Beta is a positive rotation of the robot around the Y-axis in the base coordinate system to define the robot orientation relative to the gravity. The value is set in radians. For more information, see How to define gravity.

If the robot mounted upside down or on a wall (rotated around the Y-axis) the robot base frame and Gravity Beta needs to be changed to reflect the installation. Gravity Beta should be Ï(3.141593) if mounted upside down and Â± Ï/2(1.570796) if mounted on a wall. For more information about base frame refer to How to define base frame.
Gravity Beta is calculated in the following way:
Gravity Beta = AÂ° x 3.141593/180 = B radians, where A is the mounting angle in degrees and B is the mounting angle in radians.

image.data: align=aleft; angle=0.000; cropped=0; float=0; impang=0.000; impby=Ref; impsize=4.990in 5.069in; nsoffset=0.000in; position=below; sideways=0; xoffset=0.000in; yoffset=0.000in

wrapper.title: Allowed values
wrapper.paragraph: A value between -6.283186 and 6.283186 radians.
Default value is 0.

wrapper.title: Additional information
wrapper.paragraph:
The value for Gravity Beta can be changed in runtime (without restart) with the RAPID instruction WriteCfgData . See
Technical reference manual RAPID Instructions, Functions and Data types
.

wrapper.title: Parent
wrapper.paragraph: Gamma Rotation belongs to the type Robot , in the topic Motion .

wrapper.title: Description
wrapper.paragraph: Gamma Rotation defines the orientation of the robot foot on the travel carriage.

wrapper.title: Usage
wrapper.paragraph: The Gamma Rotation is a rotation of the robot around its Z-axis. It defines the robot rotation relative to the positive direction of the travel carriage (track motion). The value is set in radians.

wrapper.title: Prerequisites
wrapper.paragraph: The Gamma Rotation parameter is useful only for robots on track when the 7 axes high performance motion parameter is set. This parameter is not used for all robot types.

wrapper.title: Allowed values
